story:
My name is Marcos Duran. I am a Brooklyn based dance artist originally from California. I've been dancing in NYC for well over 4 years now, and I mustered up the courage to focus on my own creative work! My performance group is in the process of 2 new works: a 9 person comedic dance theater piece called "Sidewalk Chalk In The Rain", and an emotionally charged trio called "Exit to Wonderland".

Take a closer look: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tEpIQAl8Irg&...

Since August 2012, I have been choreographing and directing an incredibly talented and versatile group of 9 dancers and actors- Desira Barnes, Randy Burd, Bahareh Ebrahimzadeh, Rebecca Lubart, Amy Moore, Joanna Nobbe, Santiago Venegas, Emily Vetsch and Robert Winslow.  We have had successful preview shows in NYC at Dixon Place (Nov, '12), The Center for Performance Research (Dec, '12), Mascher Co-Op Fidget Space in Philadelphia (Dec, '12). 

Why Indiegogo? The process so far has been made possible by my innate need to create new work as well as the sheer generosity of my performers and their free time. The time has come to ask for all you art and dance theater lovers out there for your help. What we need is basic. Your donation will go toward paying for rehearsal space, as well for monetary compensation for the performers.

We just had our first successful show as apart of the Green Line Series: 

APRIL 12  "Exit to Wonderland" 

                   92nd Street Y Buttenweiser Hall 

                    http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/351592

And we have two more coming up!

APRIL 27  "Sidewalk Chalk In The Rain"

                   Triskelion Arts 4th Annual Comedy In Dance Festival 

               http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/316703

MAY 30     "Exit to Wonderland" 

                   ADAPT East Coast International Dance Festival 

With any of the suggested donations ----> YOU CAN SUPPORT Comedy in Dance! YOU CAN SUPPORT Dance Theater! YOU CAN SUPPORT Marcos Duran Performance Group! From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you!

Please spread the word and share this campaign with any dance theater lovers who maybe be interested in supporting our work!

If you would like more information, please contact: movingduran@gmail.com 

Artist BIOs:

Marcos Duran (artistic director, choreographer) secretly began improvising with movement as a teenager in San Jose, California. At the age of 17 he began modern dance training with Kellye Dodd at Independence High School. He acquired a BFA in Dance from UC Santa Barbara in 2006, where he received a Corwin Award in Choreography, co-produced an evening length Honor's Project, and toured as a soloist in Jose Limon's Psalm and in Christopher Pilafian's Blindspot. He launched into his professional career as an internationally touring company member with Jerry Pearson's Santa Barbara Dance Theater, for which he twice returned as a guest artist. He served as a guest artist with Jean Isaac's San Diego Dance Theater, Malashock Dance, and as the videographer for Dance Monks in San Francisco. Before moving to NYC in 2008, he also had the pleasure of performing with the companies of Keith Johnson, Stephanie Nugent, Misa Kelly, Gary Masters, and presented work in Santa Barbara, San Diego and San Francisco, via invitations from the Santa Barbara Dance Alliance, Jean Issacs and Benjamin Levy respectively. NYC performances have been with Risa Jaroslow & Dancers, Christy Harris/ Bill Young, Eun Hee Lee, Daniel Charon, Faye Driscoll, Meredith Glisson and Jenni Hong among others. Since 2008 Marcos has presented dance theater works at Judson Church through Movement Research, Brooklyn Rooftop Series, 14th Street Y, Jennifer Mueller's The Works Studio, WAX, Eun Hee Lee's Famoso Festival, Dixon Place, The Center for Performance Research, Santa Barbara International Dance Festival and Mascher/Fidget Space in Philadelphia. He is a 2013 Artist In Residence at the Center for Performance Research in Brooklyn.

Desira Barnes (performer) is a California grown artist. She received her BA in Dance from San Jose State University , under the direction of Gary Masters in 2008. Desira balances her time between being a Freelance Artist and her Pilates practice. She has danced for Faye Driscoll, Dajhia Ingram and is currently dancing for Sasha Soreff Dance Theater.

Randy Burd (performer) is a graduate of New World School of the Arts where he received a Bachelors of Fine Arts while under the direction of Daniel Lewis. Mr. Burd has performed with Sokolow Theatre Dance Ensemble, alex/xan: the Median Movement, Korhan Basaran, Alan Danielson, Marcos Duran, Beth Soll & Young Soon Kim.

Bahareh Ebrahimzadeh (performer) has a BA in Dance from CSULB and has gained much professional experience dancing with Keith Johnson/Dancers (honored with a Lester Horton for their performance in "Presence of Absence") Invertigo Dance Theatre, and BARE Dance Company. Most recently she is making work in New York City and dancing with fabulous artists such as Marcos Duran.

Rebecca Lubart (performer) has had the pleasure of performing the works of A.O.M.C., Alexandra Beller/Dances, Nancy Bannon, Tough Cookie Dance, David Dorfman Dance, Meredith Glisson, Jessica Herring, David Hurwith, Vanessa Justice Dance,  Ana Isabel Keilson, Scott Lyons and Company, Juliette Mapp, Project:Smith, and others. Super thanks to Marcos Duran!

Amy Moore (performer) is currently based in Brooklyn, NY.  She earned a BFA in Performance and Choreography from the University of South Florida, Tampa.  After finding her way to New York City, Amy has worked under the direction of Bill Young and Christy O’Harris for White Space and is honored to currently be working with Marcos Duran Performance Group, and Shannon Gillen + Guests.

Joanna Nobbe (performer) is pursuing her interest in humanity through movement as an artist, academic, and future physical therapist. She is currently taking lots of science classes to prepare her for PT school and completing her final year in the Feldenkrais Method professional training program. She is a member of ArtBark International and dances with several inspiring people in New York City. 

Santiago Venegas (performer, textile designer, and singer-songwriter) is from Bogota, Colombia.  Featured New York performances include "Re:Galli Blonde" by Justin Vivian Bond at The Kitchen, "Puppy Love: A Stripper's Tail"  by Erin Markey at P.S. 122., and "Sidewalk Chalk In The Rain" by Marcos Duran at Dixon Place. Venegas debuted new work as part of La Mama’s Squirts series in Jan 2013.

Emily Vetsch (performer, adventure seeker) co-directs Glitter Kitty Productions, founded 2011.  Emily is currently a member of The Hudson Vagabond Puppets.  She also has had the fortune performing with: Anabella Lenzu Dance Drama, Cori Kresge Dance, and Ballet Idaho, as well as Tai Dang, Noemie Lafrance, Asun Noales, Nelly Van Bommel, Ofelia Loret de Mola, Takehiro Ueyama, Kate Hutter, Jeff Davis, Kelsey Robinson, Nora Petroliunas, and Meryl Thurston.  Working with Marcos Duran has been a pleasure!

Robert Winslow (performer) graduated from North Carolina State University in 2008 with a B.A. in Visual Arts Applications. He has a passion for design, fashion, and art. Working with Marcos Duran Performance Group is his debut back onto the stage since high school theater.

story:
My name is Jacquie and I’ve been performing since I made my theatrical debut in the eponymous role of my Preschool’s production of Goldilock and the Three Bears—I’ve been dramatic, off stage and on, ever since.  I started Dented Can Cabaret a couple of years back to produce my one woman cabaret, Lies My Mother Told Me.

My friend Molly is a strong, intelligent, funny, caring, kind, thoughtful, creative, vibrant, and beautiful young woman.  She was diagnosed with Leukemia in September and just finished her second round of chemo.

 Her friends rallied around her but felt like they wanted to do more beyond well wishes and beach days—like helping her family get out here from New Jersey more often, helping with some of her daily bills, and keeping her in chocolate pudding. The holidays are upon us and because Cancer at Christmas Sucks we here at Dented Can Cabaret decided to make our Christmas show, Holiday on the Rocks, a benefit to support Molly and help her get through her illness.

This show features three actors, 4 burlesque performers, and a show girl chorus bringing a Christmas Review that can be described as Carol Burnett and Dame Edna hosting a TV holiday special, complete with comedy, an audience participation drinking game, and your favorite holiday classics--on the rocks and with a twist.

Two other performances of Holiday on the Rocks will help absorb the cost of producing this show, but our main concern is the cost of the venue the night of the benefit and some of the equipment rental.

We’re setting the “minimum goal” pretty low so that we can receive what generosity we’re able to attract.

Thank you in advance!

~The Dented Can Cabaret crew

story:
"If there are as many minds as there are heads, then there are as many kinds of love as there are hearts"

Who's Involved

Cast (in order of appearance):
Eliades/Palomo .............................. Logan Jennings
Santiago ......................................... Igor Kuwonu
Chester .......................................... Gabriel Kerr
Ofelia ............................................. Sarita Kvam
Conchita ........................................ Victoria Ugarte
Marela ........................................... Zsuzska Beswick
Juan Julian .................................... Ryan Rodriguez
 
Production Team:
Cristina Ramos, Gabriel Kerr, Jonathan Orea, Nissy Aya, Dominique Nieves, Dominique Bratton, Nicole Lugo, Caitlin Anderson, and Donnie Alonzo

Our Story

Since the first time I read the Pulitzer Prize winning play Anna in the Tropics by Nilo Cruz, I've been in love. Few works of literature capture the essence of a time, a place, a culture, a family, or just humanity the way this play does. In it, Cruz tells the story of a Cuban family, working in a tobacco factory in Ybor City (Tampa, Florida) in the delicate time just before the Great Depression. A new arrival, a lector from Cuba, brings with him a key to release these characters' souls, with all their insecurities and passions. That key is Tolstoy's Anna Karenina. And the lector's reading of that Russian classic will change the family's life forever.

 

Now, with your help, we can bring this monumental play to the Columbia stage! As an independent study through the Anthropology Department, with help from the Student Organization of Latinos and the Columbia University Forum on Cuba, our team of talented actors and creative designers are putting together a masterful production of this play, complete with live music, period costumes, and pure determination. The curtain will come up at the Glicker Milstein Theatre (Barnard) on Friday April 6th for an 8pm performance, Saturday April 7th for a 2pm performance, and that same Saturday evening for an 8pm performance.

 

The Impact

This will be the first distinctly and deliberately Latino (and, by extension, Cuban) play created at Columbia. Every step of the process has been done with the support of the Latino community on campus and with a focus on creating a show that is as multi-dimensional and diverse as the entire Columbia community. 

 

The production is a fun and exciting experiment in combining all the arts to create the richest portrayal possible of this time, place, and family.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This production will be made possible by donations from people like YOU. Because it is an independent study, the normal arts grants are unavailable to us. In addition, although we are receiving a lot of man power and advertising help from Columbia groups, we are not a recognized group ourselves and therefore do not get funding from the Columbia higher ups. So YOUR help is imperative for our success. Your donations will be used for everything from technical costs to costume pieces, making you an integral and much appreciated part of this production. Our goal is set at $750 but we can truly use all the help we can get!

 

As a token of our gratitude for your invaluable help, we have some fun and exciting perks for you to choose from! Depending on your donation amount you can get anything from a signed poster to a Cuban dance lesson! Check out the right hand side of this page for all your amazing options. And you can always feel free to donate multiple times to get multiple perks, or donate more than the minimum for whichever perk you like.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways for you to help make this production of Anna in the Tropics everything it can be! Use the share buttons to tell your friends and family about us, pass around the link to your email contacts, or just talk about us! Spreading the word helps turn $1 into $1000 and we will be endlessly grateful for that.

 

You can also support us with just your physical presence by coming to see the show on April 6 & 7 at the Glicker Milstein Theatre at Barnard!! Tickets will be going on sale soon and will be available through the Columbia Ticketing website or at the TIC in Lerner Hall. We hope to see you there!

story:
BUREAU OF MISSING PERSONS

Written by Lila Rose Kaplan

Directed by Sarah Rasmussen 

A piece of chalk. Big band music. A pocketful of leaves. These clues lead Angela on a quest from her apartment on the Upper West Side to a cave in Moscow to search for someone who is missing. Inspired by the stories of Borges, BUREAU OF MISSING PERSONS is a magical tale that explores how we heal.

Featuring: Maren Bush, Lucy DeVito, Jason Liebman, Ryan McCarthy, and Pamela Shaw.

Set and Costumes By: Moria Clinton, Lighting By: Porsche McGovern, Sound By: Sam Kusnetz, Stage Manager: Kaitlin Nemeth, Creative Line Producer: Amanda Feldman 

We are so thrilled to give BUREAU OF MISSING PERSONS it's NYC debut at The 4th Street Theatre this coming June 14th - 29th. 

  

HOW IT CAME TO BE…

When I started this play it was called Death of the Doily and it was about a school for manners. My grandmother was dying and I couldn’t face it. When she passed, I saw how little space we have to grieve and heal right now. Everything goes so fast. The world is moving so fast that we miss people who are standing right in front of us. Suddenly, I realized I wasn’t writing about a school for manners, I was writing about a Bureau of Missing Persons. I imagined a place where all the people you’ve lost, a place where they go.

 

PLEASE CONSIDER MAKING A DONATION

As we mention in our video, we have a wonderful-amazing-super team. We booked a beautiful, yet trendy theater to perform in, and we have already raised $23,000 out of $30,000 to put on this beautiful play, so all we need is that last $7000! 

This $7,000 will go toward paying our creative team, rehearsal space, props, as well as for a blue scarf or two or twenty. 

Your support would mean the world to us!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can't contribute now and would like to help out in another way, please consider making a bit of noise about us and this campaign. Post this link to your Facebook profile or Twitter feed! 

 

THANK YOU

We want to thank you in advance for your generosity.

We look forward to seeing you at the theater in June!

story:
My passion in life has always been theatre. My dream has always been to have my own theatre company; A theatre company that produces a complete season every year.

Music City Theatre Company was created in 2008 by myself & has so far produced three very successful productions. My current goal is to launch the company full time in January 2013.

Our mission is to bring the Nashville community material that is diverse, unique, & inventive while taking risks beyond the capacity of what a typical theatre company would.

Our seasons will be a mix of musicals & plays - published & original works. Also, through Music City Actors Studio, we will also be educating the community through acting lessons, workshops, & special events.

Music City Theatre Company will put on 5-7 major productions each year.

Sound equipment, lights, rights to productions, musicians, scripts, costumes, props, printing of tickets & posters...EVERYTHING is expensive. Since most spaces do not have a stage and lights built in, that will be the first task. It takes a lot of money to have your own theatre space, but it is my dream. If you do not reach for your dreams, no one else will.

I have been acting since I was 5; Directing since I was 16; My degree is in Theatre Performance. It is in my heart. Hopefully you will find it in your heart to help us out!

Music City Theatre Company was created in 2008 by myself & has so far produced three very successful productions. My current goal is to launch the company full time in January 2013.
Our mission is to bring the Nashville community material that is diverse, unique, & inventive while taking risks beyond the capacity of what a typical theatre company would.
Our seasons will be a mix of musicals & plays - published & original works. Also, through Music City Actors Studio, we will also be educating the community through acting lessons, workshops, & special events.
Music City Theatre Company will put on 5-7 major productions each year.
Sound equipment, lights, rights to productions, musicians, scripts, costumes, props, printing of tickets & posters...EVERYTHING is expensive. Since most spaces do not have a stage and lights built in, that will be the first task. It takes a lot of money to have your own theatre space, but it is my dream. If you do not reach for your dreams, no one else will.
I have been acting since I was 5; Directing since I was 16; My degree is in Theatre Performance. It is in my heart. Hopefully you will find it in your heart to help us out!

story:
About "At The Flash"

"At The Flash" was written by Sean Chandler and David Leeper and is performed by David Leeper.  Having been together for over 22 years and now (thankfully) legally married, they wanted to create a piece of theater that represented how far the LGBT community has come and how far we need to go.

"It is so important that people understand our history.  Especially within our own community.  We can't take for granted the struggles we've been through.  Without those pioneers, we wouldn't be where we are today.  And we're still fighting! That's why this play is so important.  It tells a history that's funny, sweet and sometimes sad, but necessary." - David Leeper

After winning Pride Films and Plays 2012 Great Gay Play Contest,  David Zak (Executive Director of Pride Films and Plays) directed the World Premiere production in Chicago at the Center on Halsteds, Hoover-Leppen Theatre.  The West Coast Premiere followed in Los Angeles at Celebration Theatre.  Now, "At The Flash" has been invited to the International Dublin Gay Theater Festival! 

This play, performed by one actor, is a vibrant and exciting piece of theater that is not only entertaining, but it is also an important piece of theater for all audiences.  

Those who have seen it, regardless of their sexual orientation, have been deeply moved and found themselves seeing aspects of their own lives within the characters of the play.

Creatively, this play is an interwoven series of scenes following five different characters over five consecutive decades. As the action jumps back and forth between the characters, the audience sees how different, yet similar we all are.

To read reviews or more about the characters visit: http://www.attheflash.com

We're doing everything we can to raise the money to cover the cost of the production costs and travel to Dublin for the actor, director, writer and stage manager.  Our budget is in excess of $10,000 and although we have other venues we are pursuing, this campaign is our most promising!  Every dollar raised on here will go toward supporting this venture.  We are committed to going to Dublin so every little bit helps!

Besides the reward of helping a very important piece of theater get seen by international audiences, Pride Films and Plays is a non-profit theater and your donation is tax deductible. 

PLEASE share our venture on your Facebook, Twitter, Email...whatever social sites you take part in and spread the word!

story:
ALBUM DE FINISSANTS

Qu’est-ce qui se passe dans la tête des ados rivés à leurs pupitres, alors que les secondes piétinent sur l’horloge de l’école? Que transmet-on vraiment à ces élèves assis en rang 1500 heures par année? Quel savoir, quelles valeurs? Quel sens? 

Radiographie troublante de l’école secondaire, les voix intérieures des jeunes rivés à leurs pupitres ponctuent la trame du spectacle. Un flot tumultueux rappelant le slam, s’entrechoquent règles de grammaire, désirs lancinants, idées reçues, musique pop et quête éperdue de sens. Sur scène, un chœur de jeunes de 5e secondaire, véritables finissants, donnent corps à ce texte percutant aux côtés des acteurs qui en portent les mots avec fougue et intensité. Ensemble, ils nous entraînent dans une bouleversante traversée d’états aux allures de concert rock, de vidéoclip, où le rythme, propulsé par le texte, la musique et les images vidéo, se répercute dans les corps et renverse toutes les postures scolaires.

Coproduit par deux organismes artistiques sans but lucratif : Pirata Théâtre et Matériaux Composites et codiffusé par le Théâtre Denise-Pelletier à Montréal, ce projet donnera naissance, du 12 au 22 mars 2014, à une oeuvre théâtrale unique où 80 adolescents vivront une expérience sans précédents en se partageant 18 représentations devant des groupes scolaires et le grand public, sur une scène professionnelle aux côtés de 5 acteurs.

Ces véritables finissants sont issus de cinq écoles du Grand Montréal ( Écoles secondaires Léopold-Gravel et Armand-Corbeil de Terrebonne, École secondaire Leblanc de Laval, Collège de Montréal et École secondaire de la Pointe-aux-Trembles). C'est un projet d'envergure qui tisse des ponts entre le social et l'artistique et qui demande énormément d'investissement de la part de nos collaborateurs. Afin de bien encadrer les jeunes, nous avons réuni autour d'eux une équipe d'une quinzaine d'artistes professionnels. 

____________________________________________________________________

ALBUM DE FINISSANTS d'après le livre de Mathieu Arsenault

Adaptation et mise en scène d’Anne Sophie Rouleau assistée de Michelle Parent

DISTRIBUTION

Dany Boudreault, Alexandre Leroux, Xavier Malo, Michelle Parent, Annie Valin et un chœur d’élèves des Écoles secondaires Léopold-Gravel et Armand-Corbeil de Terrebonne, de l’École Leblanc de Laval, de l’École secondaire de la Pointe-aux-Trembles et du Collège de Montréal.

CONCEPTEURS ET COLLABORATEURS

Marie-Ève Fortier, Marianne Thériault, Samuel Thériault, Andréanne Deschênes, Josué Bertolino, Marie-Ève Archambault, Rachele Gemme et Magali Letarte

____________________________________________________________________

Afin de financer le projet, nous avons entrepris des démarches auprès des Conseils des arts, des élus, de fondations et de compagnies privées. Nous mettons également sur pied des activités de financement comme une vente de garage, la projection d'un documentaire sur le projet, la présentation d'un spectacle musical ainsi que cette campagne indiegogo.

Nous avons besoin de près de 50 000$ afin d'être en mesure de boucler le budget de production de ce spectacle. Une partie de cet argent est déjà assuré par la vente des billets (des représentations scolaires affichent déjà complet) par nos activités-bénéfices et par la vente d'espace publicitaire dans le programme. Cependant, il nous reste encore beaucoup de chemin à parcourir et nous avons besoin de vous!

En plus de financer la création d'un spectacle, vous financerez également une expérience extraordinaire et marquante pour près de 80 adolescents qui monteront sur une scène professionnelle. Pour vous présenter un spectacle sur eux et avec eux.

story:
Hi! I'm Susanna, an apprentice with Inspiracion Dance Chicago. We are a twelve-member Latin dance company from diverse backgrounds that performs new, exciting choreography in Chicago and offers free or subsidized community education to high school, college, and adult teams. Our next project is to increase our visibility and augment our training by traveling to train and perform at the 2013 Canada Salsa Congress in Toronto! Personally, this will be my first opportunity to perform at a salsa congress, and a major step in advancing my dance career. But I need your help.

We need to raise about $500 each to cover the cost of registration, costumes, gas, hotel, and food. So in addition to washing cars, baking cookies, and giving paid performances, we are turning to YOU- our friends and family- for support. In exchange, we offer our thanks and a video of the performance in Toronto. Your contribution will help us step up our game, and further, contribute to the vital work of offering community dance education in Chicago. Thank you!

*To see me rehearsing the piece we intend to bring to Canada: https://vimeo.com/74997732

*To see the debut of the piece performed: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KSy-SHpd-AI

story:
We need you to help raise the additional cost of producing 'Shrek the Musical' this October in West Bend, Wisconsin. 

 

Spotlight Productions has a rich history of producing family friendly musicals and comedies for 33 years in West Bend, Wisconsin.  THAT’S RIGHT - THREE DECADES. 

 

As an all volunteer company, Spotlight relies on the generosity and talent of committed individuals and families within our community. Our previous productions have been funded exclusively through our ticket sales (with our musicals helping to offset some of the costs for our Spring comedies).  The Artistic Director and Founder of the company along with almost every director in the company have a degree in Theatre, Music, or Dance.  We strive for a high standard of morality and artistic professionalism in our performances.  Of course, we also like to have a lot of fun.

 

Spotlight Productions is all about family and community.  It is not unusual for us to have 3 generations sharing the stage or entire families involved in a production.  Some of the kids in our first productions are now coming back as parents with children of their own to make memories together. 

 

Spotlight Productions is moving to a larger theatre space that brings with it some additional challenges.   

 

 Shrek the Musical allows us the opportunity to produce a newly released musical with family oriented fun while stretching our creativity in a new theatre space.

The limitations in our previous space were primarily the low ceilings and the small footprint of the stage.  We actually built two side stages, a thrust, and (starting with the yellow brick road for the Wizard of Oz) two bridges connecting those side stages.  Even with extreme creativity, finding space for 50 or more actors to share the stage was tough and choreography for these large musical numbers was nothing short of a miracle.

This leads us to the current exciting opportunity we have before us.  Our local school district is also undergoing a major effort to revitalize the high school theatre with some pretty major fundraising.  While the fruits of their efforts are still a long way off, we have been asked to help promote their campaign by bringing a major community based production onto the high school stage to showcase the possibilities. 

Doing so will require some creativity and a lot of flexibility as we need to design all of the set pieces to move on and off the stage so that regularly scheduled school performances can go on during the run of our show.  The size of the theatre will also increase our costs for the royalties for each performance.  And then there is the issue of sound.  One of the biggest drawbacks with the current school stage is the sound . . . it is just about as horrible listening to Donkey learn to yodel or seeing Shrek floss.  We will need to double the number of microphones that we have for this production and while we have amassed quite the collection of set pieces over 33 years, almost everything we have will be lost in this space.  That means starting from scratch and that is expensive.

 

WE NEED YOU

We are very optimistic about what we can do in this new space.  Our designers are already at work coming up with ideas for set pieces, creating costumes, and finding ways to pull off some pretty spectacular special effects.  However, we are estimating that we are $5,000 to $8,000 short in our budget for this production.  Again, we have a long history of being able to cover our costs with ticket sales and we intend to go back to this in the near future. (Bottom line - we aren't setting you up for an annual appeal.)

But for this show we need you!!!  Your support will allow us to dream bigger.  If we can reach our goal we will be able to do all 6 performances the way we have imagined them.  For the 100+ people who volunteer countless hours on the creation of this project over a 3 month period  - that would be a real gift.  With your help our set and costume designers can really spread their wings (literally in the case of creating Dragon) and show an audience how theatre can truly transform the ordinary into something magical.  You will also let Grandma and Grandpa hear how wonderful their grandkids sound.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

  • We would love to have you come out for the show.  Live theatre is nothing without an audience to appreciate it.  Performance Dates:   October 11, 12, 13, 18, 19, 20 at the West Bend High School Theatre.

  • Donate - if you have $5 or $500 the support you give will make an OGRE sized impact on our show.  We had fun coming up with our perks to the right - check them out.

  • Share - Like us, Tweet us, Pin us, Tag us, you know the drill.  The more people who see us, the more people who can't help but love us.

Donate - if you have $5 or $500 the support you give will make an OGRE sized impact on our show.  We had fun coming up with our perks to the right - check them out.


Share - Like us, Tweet us, Pin us, Tag us, you know the drill.  The more people who see us, the more people who can't help but love us.

story:
After looking at many, many wonderful actors, we have found our cast - we now have a dynamic quartet of talented actors who are excited to begin rehearsal to bring you the New York premier of Kallie.
Scroll down to learn more about them...

And also read about the latest additions to our production crew--
Brittany Vasta (Set Designer) and Ta'Nea Hill (Stage Manager)

For nearly 40 years The American Renaissance Theater Company (ARTC) has operated as a developmental workshop, and in its early years, was also a significant producing organization in New York.  The weekly workshop gives our members--professional actors, directors and playwrights, a supportive but challenging place to hone their skills. Our members work nationally and internationally in all areas of the entertainment industry.                    

Twice a year we invite the public to staged readings of the best works of the season
in our Spring Reading Series and WinterWorks.

We would now like to take the next step: presenting fully mounted Equity Showcase productions of the best works developed at ARTC. While maintaining our weekly workshops, we feel it is vitally important to provide this additional opportunity for our members to fully realize their work.  We hope you share our enthusiasm for a producing ARTC and will help us make it a reality with your fully tax-deductible donation.This June, with your generous help, ARTC will proudly present the New York premier of Stuart D'Ver's Kallie, the 2013 winner of the Jerry Kaufman award.

Set in the mind of the central character, Kallie is an exploration of memory wrapped in a pitch black comedy about delusion, reality -- and Groucho Marx. It is the tale of a young woman escaping an abusive relationship who rebels against her abuser, rebels against the drugs that have kept her in check, and rebels against the memories of her own past. The daughter of a successful Philadelphia surgeon, Kallie is a child of privilege. Yet, she is obsessed with delusions -- roaches who read her mind, rats who invade her body -- which have kept her enslaved to deadbeat lovers and dead end jobs. After a particularly vicious argument with her boyfriend, Kallie flees and embarks on an hallucinatory train trip to find her Dad and escape her inner demons. 

Along the way, she struggles with deviations from reality that are sometimes disconcerting, sometimes insane and sometimes insanely funny. Darkly surreal -- deeply comic -- Kallie is the story of one woman's journey from madness to love.

Stuart D'Ver's plays have been presented in New York at the Abingdon Theatre The Last Time, Sunny Climes, the Neighborhood Playhouse Feeling With Food, Circumstance, the Turtle Shell Clearing The Air, and the Estrogenius Festival Ladies of the Lake. The American Aunt,1929 won the 2008 Raymond J. Flores Award. Kallie was short-listed for the O'Neill Conference, was a finalist for the Episcopal Actors Guild's Thomas Barbour Award, and won the 2013 Jerry Kaufman Award. Mr. D'Ver holds a BFA from Ithaca College and an MFA from Columbia University. He is a member of Literary Managers and Dramaturgs of the Americas, Manhattan Oracles, Dramatists Guild and has served as Artistic Director of ARTC.

Elowyn Castle is the director of the New York Times Critics' Pick The Norwegians, at The Drilling Company, currently going into its second year. Other Off Broadway includes The Understanding for the Colleagues' Theatre Company; Happy Birthday Wanda June and Much Ado About Nothing at the Equity Library Theatre; Following The Yellow Brick Road...Down The Rabbit Hole at HERE and Love Play at La Mama. Also recently: The Cemetery Club for The Snarks; several productions for the Lighthouse Players including Arsenic and Old Lace and Musical Comedy Murders of 1940. For the Deep Ellum Opera Theatre in Dallas she directed Birth/Day, a new musical by Neil Wolfe and Ron Troutman based on the Frankenstein story. Other credits include Two Gentlemen of Verona and Othello for The National Shakespeare Company, and a production of Cowboy Mouth at the Dubrovnik Festival in Yugoslavia, and The Lady's Not For Burning and Love Letters at the Hedgerow Theatre in Philadelphia.
She is currently President of the Episcopal Actors' Guild and has served as Co-Artistic Director of ARTC.
SDC, AEA, SAG-AFTRA, ARTC

Louis Lopardi has won awards for Sound Design, Lighting, Original Music, Playwrighting, and Direction.  Awarded by the Musicians' Union for "promoting live music for the dance."  Sound Design credits include: Frankenstein, The Purgatory Project, Wozzeck, 12th Night, Macbeth, Cyrano de Bergerac, Priestley's They Came To The City, 12 "Film Noir" radio plays, 3 Fassbinder plays, and original music for Ladies In Retirement and Brecht's Galileo.
SDC       

Elowyn Castle, Stuart D'Ver and producers, Kathleen Swan and Bill Cosgriff, peruse the submissions as the casting process for Kallie begins.

Kathleen Swan is an actress and director and a veteran of numerous productions in Los Angeles, Boston and New York.  Acting highlights include co-starring in the Dino De Laurentiis film, Beyond the Reef, Broadway's Utter Glory of Morrissey Hall and Off-Broadway's Knucklebones.  She recently directed in four Playwrights Festivals at New York's Shell Theater, twice winning the audience award for Best Director.

For ARTC, she is completing her second year as co-Artistic Director (with Bill Cosgriff) as well as Producing Director.  She served as producer for ARTC's Spring Reading Series 2010/2011 and as co-producer with Bill Cosgriff in 2013.
Kathleen had an extensive career in academia, serving as Asst. Dean of Student Academic Affairs at Columbia University before returning to her roots in the performing arts.  AEA, SAG-AFTRA.


Bill Cosgriff has written six full-length plays and dozens of one-acts.  His comedy, Deathclaw 7: The Escape, was produced on Theatre Row and was a finalist in the Lark Theatre Company's Playwright's Week 2004.  His recent full-length, The Eighth Wonder, won a citation and grant in the Jerry Kaufman Awards 2010 and his ten-minute play, What Ever Happened To...The Three Sisters?, was showcased at the 78th St. Theatre Lab and is published in Stage This, Too! (2007).  His full-length, Rio Rita, was a finalist for the Eugene O'Neill Playwrights Conference in 2009 and won the 2013 Thomas Barbour Memorial Playwrights Award.
As an actor, in addition to much work in film and TV, Bill has appeared at Soho Rep, American Theatre of Actors (ATA), New Dramatists, the Ensemble Studio Theatre, Classic Theatre Company, Florida Studio Theatre, and the Dorset Theatre Festival.
Bill joins Kathleen in their second year as co-Artistic Directors of ARTC and was co-producer (with Kathleen) of the 2013 Spring Reading Series.
Member of the Dramatists Guild, AEA, SAG-AFTRA.


ARTC'ers have received grants and awards including the Rockefeller Foundation Fellowship for Playwriting, the Kaufman and Hart Award, the Shubert Fellow in Playwriting, the Puffin Foundation Award, the MCAF Award, the NC Playwright Fellowship, the Berilla Kerr Award, the Thomas Barbour Memorial Award, The American Theatre Critics/Steinberg New Play Award and Moondance International Film Festival Musical Theatre Award.

THE JERRY KAUFMAN AWARD

In 2007, ARTC and Carol Goldberg established the Jerry Kaufman Award, to recognize excellence in writing for the theater and to support our playwrights in the process of new play development.

  

In its early days, between 1975 and 1987, ARTC was a significant producer of new and classic plays in New York City. Until the 1987 death of founder, Bob Elston, ARTC produced over 55 full length plays as well as more than fifty concerts and one-person shows.

  

WE SHOWED OUR APPRECIATION TO THE STAFF
WITH TOP BANANA AWARDS.   

WON'T YOU HELP PUT US OVER THE TOP?
YOUR DONATION WOULD BE GREATLY APPRECIATED! 

Follow us on Facebook:
American Renaissance Theater Co.-ARTC


Video Credit: Jake Alan King   jakealanking@gmail.com
story_txt:
After looking at many, many wonderful actors, we have found our cast - we now have a dynamic quartet of talented actors who are excited to begin rehearsal to bring you the New York premier of Kallie.Scroll down to learn more about them...And also read about the latest additions to our production crew--Brittany Vasta (Set Designer) and Ta'Nea Hill (Stage Manager)For nearly 40 years The American Renaissance Theater Company (ARTC) has operated as a developmental workshop, and in its early years, was also a significant producing organization in New York.  The weekly workshop gives our members--professional actors, directors and playwrights, a supportive but challenging place to hone their skills. Our members work nationally and internationally in all areas of the entertainment industry.                    Twice a year we invite the public to staged readings of the best works of the seasonin our Spring Reading Series and WinterWorks.We would now like to take the next step: presenting fully mounted Equity Showcase productions of the best works developed at ARTC. While maintaining our weekly workshops, we feel it is vitally important to provide this additional opportunity for our members to fully realize their work.  We hope you share our enthusiasm for a producing ARTC and will help us make it a reality with your fully tax-deductible donation.This June, with your generous help, ARTC will proudly present the New York premier of Stuart D'Ver's Kallie, the 2013 winner of the Jerry Kaufman award.Set in the mind of the central character, Kallie is an exploration of memory wrapped in a pitch black comedy about delusion, reality -- and Groucho Marx. It is the tale of a young woman escaping an abusive relationship who rebels against her abuser, rebels against the drugs that have kept her in check, and rebels against the memories of her own past. The daughter of a successful Philadelphia surgeon, Kallie is a child of privilege. Yet, she is obsessed with delusions -- roaches who read her mind, rats who invade her body -- which have kept her enslaved to deadbeat lovers and dead end jobs. After a particularly vicious argument with her boyfriend, Kallie flees and embarks on an hallucinatory train trip to find her Dad and escape her inner demons. Along the way, she struggles with deviations from reality that are sometimes disconcerting, sometimes insane and sometimes insanely funny. Darkly surreal -- deeply comic -- Kallie is the story of one woman's journey from madness to love.Stuart D'Ver's plays have been presented in New York at the Abingdon Theatre The Last Time, Sunny Climes, the Neighborhood Playhouse Feeling With Food, Circumstance, the Turtle Shell Clearing The Air, and the Estrogenius Festival Ladies of the Lake. The American Aunt,1929 won the 2008 Raymond J. Flores Award. Kallie was short-listed for the O'Neill Conference, was a finalist for the Episcopal Actors Guild's Thomas Barbour Award, and won the 2013 Jerry Kaufman Award. Mr. D'Ver holds a BFA from Ithaca College and an MFA from Columbia University. He is a member of Literary Managers and Dramaturgs of the Americas, Manhattan Oracles, Dramatists Guild and has served as Artistic Director of ARTC.Elowyn Castle is the director of the New York Times Critics' Pick The Norwegians, at The Drilling Company, currently going into its second year. Other Off Broadway includes The Understanding for the Colleagues' Theatre Company; Happy Birthday Wanda June and Much Ado About Nothing at the Equity Library Theatre; Following The Yellow Brick Road...Down The Rabbit Hole at HERE and Love Play at La Mama. Also recently: The Cemetery Club for The Snarks; several productions for the Lighthouse Players including Arsenic and Old Lace and Musical Comedy Murders of 1940. For the Deep Ellum Opera Theatre in Dallas she directed Birth/Day, a new musical by Neil Wolfe and Ron Troutman based on the Frankenstein story. Other credits include Two Gentlemen of Verona and Othello for The National Shakespeare Company, and a production of Cowboy Mouth at the Dubrovnik Festival in Yugoslavia, and The Lady's Not For Burning and Love Letters at the Hedgerow Theatre in Philadelphia.She is currently President of the Episcopal Actors' Guild and has served as Co-Artistic Director of ARTC.SDC, AEA, SAG-AFTRA, ARTCLouis Lopardi has won awards for Sound Design, Lighting, Original Music, Playwrighting, and Direction.  Awarded by the Musicians' Union for "promoting live music for the dance."  Sound Design credits include: Frankenstein, The Purgatory Project, Wozzeck, 12th Night, Macbeth, Cyrano de Bergerac, Priestley's They Came To The City, 12 "Film Noir" radio plays, 3 Fassbinder plays, and original music for Ladies In Retirement and Brecht's Galileo.SDC       Elowyn Castle, Stuart D'Ver and producers, Kathleen Swan and Bill Cosgriff, peruse the submissions as the casting process for Kallie begins.Kathleen Swan is an actress and director and a veteran of numerous productions in Los Angeles, Boston and New York.  Acting highlights include co-starring in the Dino De Laurentiis film, Beyond the Reef, Broadway's Utter Glory of Morrissey Hall and Off-Broadway's Knucklebones.  She recently directed in four Playwrights Festivals at New York's Shell Theater, twice winning the audience award for Best Director.For ARTC, she is completing her second year as co-Artistic Director (with Bill Cosgriff) as well as Producing Director.  She served as producer for ARTC's Spring Reading Series 2010/2011 and as co-producer with Bill Cosgriff in 2013.Kathleen had an extensive career in academia, serving as Asst. Dean of Student Academic Affairs at Columbia University before returning to her roots in the performing arts.  AEA, SAG-AFTRA.Bill Cosgriff has written six full-length plays and dozens of one-acts.  His comedy, Deathclaw 7: The Escape, was produced on Theatre Row and was a finalist in the Lark Theatre Company's Playwright's Week 2004.  His recent full-length, The Eighth Wonder, won a citation and grant in the Jerry Kaufman Awards 2010 and his ten-minute play, What Ever Happened To...The Three Sisters?, was showcased at the 78th St. Theatre Lab and is published in Stage This, Too! (2007).  His full-length, Rio Rita, was a finalist for the Eugene O'Neill Playwrights Conference in 2009 and won the 2013 Thomas Barbour Memorial Playwrights Award.As an actor, in addition to much work in film and TV, Bill has appeared at Soho Rep, American Theatre of Actors (ATA), New Dramatists, the Ensemble Studio Theatre, Classic Theatre Company, Florida Studio Theatre, and the Dorset Theatre Festival.Bill joins Kathleen in their second year as co-Artistic Directors of ARTC and was co-producer (with Kathleen) of the 2013 Spring Reading Series.Member of the Dramatists Guild, AEA, SAG-AFTRA.ARTC'ers have received grants and awards including the Rockefeller Foundation Fellowship for Playwriting, the Kaufman and Hart Award, the Shubert Fellow in Playwriting, the Puffin Foundation Award, the MCAF Award, the NC Playwright Fellowship, the Berilla Kerr Award, the Thomas Barbour Memorial Award, The American Theatre Critics/Steinberg New Play Award and Moondance International Film Festival Musical Theatre Award.THE JERRY KAUFMAN AWARDIn 2007, ARTC and Carol Goldberg established the Jerry Kaufman Award, to recognize excellence in writing for the theater and to support our playwrights in the process of new play development.  In its early days, between 1975 and 1987, ARTC was a significant producer of new and classic plays in New York City. Until the 1987 death of founder, Bob Elston, ARTC produced over 55 full length plays as well as more than fifty concerts and one-person shows.  WE SHOWED OUR APPRECIATION TO THE STAFF WITH TOP BANANA AWARDS.   
WON'T YOU HELP PUT US OVER THE TOP?YOUR DONATION WOULD BE GREATLY APPRECIATED! Follow us on Facebook:American Renaissance Theater Co.-ARTCVideo Credit: Jake Alan King   jakealanking@gmail.com

story:
SE7EN - "Honoring Death, Celebrating Life"
Presented by Movement Artist 
Edwin Olvera

Hello Milwaukee my name is Edwin Olvera, I am a professional Movement & Performing Artist, and would like to invite & inform you on my latest site specific production. SE7EN “Honoring Death, Celebrating Life”.  SE7EN will premier on July 1-7 and consist of 7 performances, which will feature 7 different communities within the city of Milwaukee, the place we call home. This is a unique opportunity for us as individuals to come together and take an emotional journey on the roller coaster we call life.

SE7EN has a few movement pieces which explore dark emotions, like the fear of an economic disaster or the loss of a loved one. On the flip side, SE7EN features movement selections based on life, love, and the importance of vibrant health.

GOAL

Within the next 12 days here is how you can help bring SE7EN to life. SE7ENs total cost is $3526. This price factors in supplies, props, performers fees, and venus.

I invite you to participate in one or more ways. And here is how:

a) Financial Donations or sponsorship, that you can make thru SE7EN's IndieGoGo campaign

B) Physical Donations

C) Volunteer your time, 1) as a performer or 2) as an intern

Please consider investing in this event today. Everybit of effort counts!

SE7EN is a free public event.

To find out more about the Indiegogo Fundraiser campaign and SE7EN please visit my website. www.edwinolvera.com, my Facebook page, or my youtube channel.

Be well!

 

Edwin Olvera, a proud Wisconsinite, has spread his wings far and wide. His skill and ability has been of worldwide note as he has performed and taught in locations across the globe. After attending UW-Milwaukee’s Peck School of the Arts, Edwin joined the world renowned dance company, Pilobolus Dance Theatre, where he was an integral force in the choreographic and creation process over the course of four years. During this time, he was featured on countless television shows and commercial advertisements including Sesame Street, Born to Dance, and the NFL Channel. Edwin has collaborated with international artists Inbal Pinto and Basil Twist and has been featured in articles by both Dance and Dancer Magazine. His most current work includes choreography and artistic direction for an evening length performance in collaboration with the Emmy award nominated lighting and production company, IG Designs.

 

Finacial Break Down for SE7EN:

$500 - 4 Special Event Permit from Milwaukee Parks System

$300 - Christal Wagner dance partner for “Hold Me”

$200 - Travis leger - Playing Harmonica for “Day of Rest”

$50 -  Rasheeda Panniel America in “America is Dead”

$80 - 2 day rental of video project from Video Villains

$150 - 1 day Theatre Rental at Comedy Festival Theatre (Grand Ave Mall) for “Remember Me”

$700 - Special Event Insurance to cover all 7 days

$253.50 - ($$50.70 x 5 locations outdoors) Noise Variance Permit

$100 Special event Permit City of Milwaukee

$200 - Shelby Ruess Creator of Promotional Flyer

$500 - Robert Paul Ulrich Videographer (will record rehearsals, 7 day show & creator of DVD)

$51.49 - 1 American Flag

$107.88 - 120 LED lights

$123.99 - Stanley Tools 500 watt Portable Power Station

$110 - 100 Promotional flyers/ posters

$100 - props & materials for What if (costume)


total:$ 3,526.86
 
If we don't reach our goal, not to worry, all of the money collected will go to the performers and special events permits. 
 
Every bit of money helps supports Milwaukee pool of amazing talent. Help me supply work locally to the BEST in the MIDWEST!
 
Here are other ways you can help SE7EN reach its goal!
-Forward our campaign to your Facebook friends
-Post on your Facebook Wall
-Tell your friends, family and co-workers 
-E-mail other this info
 
My track record for success with Performances
-2012 Pumpworks Pridefest (5hrs show)
-Early Movers IndieGoGo 2012 (presented at librarys, MPS school systems and Daycares. Meet my goal of $800!)
-Midnight in Paris NYE MOCT 2013 feature a variety of Milwaukee's  talent
-"Guys and Dolls" Cudahy HS 2013
-SE7EN 2013 July 1-7th ;)

story:
Who We Are:

We're a group of five young theatre artists in Montreal Quebec who are taking our debut production on a Spring and Summer tour across Canada. We're passionate about producing exciting new Canadian plays that are quick and easily produced without the heavy technical artifice of modern conventional theatre. We focus on the foundations of good theatre, text, actors, and audience without stressing extraneous production elements.

All five members of our production team studied together in the Theatre program at Concordia University in Montreal. Our group first came together to produce Third Person as part of Concordia's Student Initiated Production Assignments (SIPA) Festival in November 2011, and it was enthusiastically received by the sold-out crowds at our small venue. However, this taste of success encouraged us to take our work to a much larger audience, and the notion of a cross-Canada tour was born! 
 
 
Our Company consists of:
 
Brandon Wicke - Playwright/Director
 
Kevin Ray - George
 
Nic Turcotte - Byron
 
Veronica Derby - Designer
 
Megan Holt - Stage Manager
 
 

What We're Up To:

Written by our Director, Brandon Wicke, during his time at Concordia University, Third Person tells the story of two young men, George and Byron, who find themselves in a strange clearing where mysterious text continually haunts them with predictions of their future and promises of universal knowledge. Camping out with only their tent and flashlight, the two must decide whether or not to trust in the writing's authority to dole out their fate, and perhaps even discover what true part they as human beings have in determining their own future. The writing refuses to make this pursuit easy on them however, making attempts to pit the two against one another and preying on their individual fears and anxieties until the two must make a choice whether to heed the antagonistic force's claims despite its questionable motives, or to turn their backs on it forever and leave still in ignorance as to the true nature of fate.

 
 
So far, we'll be bringing Third Person to:
 
SpringWorks Indie Theatre Fest in Stratford Ontario - May 15th & 19th at
                                                                                                      Factory 163
 
Montreal Fringe Festival - June 14th, 15th, 17th, 20th, 21st & 23rd at
                                                 Mission Santa Cruz
 
Toronto Production - July (Dates & Venue Yet to be Confirmed)
 
Vancouver Fringe Festival - September 5 - 15th
 
 
With more potential dates to come!

 

Where Your Money Will Go:

While we stress the importance of creating affordable and pared-down theatre, there are a number of expenses associated with our tour. Our Indiegogo campaign is aimed particularly at the purchase of a high quality video projector which is the backbone of our production's design. While we have explored renting projectors for each of our different performances, we believe that, due to projection's importance to our play, it is in our best interest to purchase our own and rehearse with it from the beginning of the tour. This will also allow us to use projection in future productions without further expense.


Our current list of expenses for the tour is as follows:

 

Montreal Fringe Application Fee: $57.49  

Montreal Fringe Participant Fee: $546.14

SpringWorks Festival  Application Fee: $35.00

Toronto Venue Rental Fees: estimated $625.00

Vancouver Fringe Participant Fee: $ 750.00

Transportation to Vancouver: $3750.00 (economy flights for 5 cast & crew)

Purchase of Video Projector: $1500 (taxes included)

 

Total: $7263.63

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Come see the show in a city near you and spread the word to friends and family! Word of mouth is an Independent Theatre Company's best ally in getting a sizeable support base to ensure our continued ability to produce great work. Follow us on Twitter at @OrphanedEgretTheatre to hear any news about our tour and more ways to help!

Also, if you happen to be involved in Theatre and have a venue, festival, or other opportunity that you would like to consider our production for inclusion in, please feel free to give us a shout at orphaned.egret.theatre@gmail.com and we would be ecstatic to work something out!

story:
PROFILE

My name is Amy Trompetter, and I am a puppeteer from NY.  I am raising airfare to fly to Jakarta to support three young, activist theater companies.

HOW DID THIS BEGIN?

Recently I collaborated with Thai and Burmese actors and puppeteers at Empty Space Chiang Mai and Gitameit Music Centers Yangon and Mandalay.  The video clip shows the mix of delicate traditional marionettes of Htwe Oo Myanmar and crude large-scale free-form masks inspired by work with the Bread and Puppet and Redwing Blackbird Theaters. That collaboration, "The Four Puppets" was featured at a Burmese contemporary theater festival in Yangon, and welcomed for its iconoclastic mix. 

WHAT CAME NEXT?

I toured Burma in 2011 with a large scale puppet/new music piece.  Now I have been invited to travel to Jakarta to join the three young theater companies from Burma, Indonesia and Thailand for the second phase of their project, UNDER AFTER and IN BETWEEN. The name, given by Empty Space director Manuel Lutgenhorst, refers to moving out from under artistic repression in the three countries.  Company members develop theatrical images and metaphors that cloak experience to ignite response, as politics and policies shift between dictatorships, autocracies and democracies. See Taring Padi video clip from phase one of UNDER AFTER and IN BETWEEN:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4XvP2YHYMtI&feature=youtube_gdata_player 

WHAT IS THIS PROJECT?

Thukama Khayee Thee, Taring Padi and Makhampom theater companies are meeting from Septmeber 8-23 in Yoyakarta to show each other recent works. They are also collaborating on a new piece about Kulan Progo farmers, on Java's South Coast, who are resisting the iron mining company's threats to usurp land cultivated by families for generations.  The goals of the project are to visit these farmers, create new works using music, theater, graphics and puppetry, and to finally bring new approaches to theater back to communities at home.

 WHERE DOES IT LEAD?

While in each other's company in Yogyakarta, we can plan future projects.  UNDER AFTER and IN BETWEEN is preparing for a third phase in Burma in 2013.  And I am developing a new project that begins with migrant workers, temporarily living in Yangon, and continues in their home villages in Shan State Hill Tribe areas of Burma in 2014.  The solidarity of our struggle is especially important as Burma opens up.

 WHAT DO WE NEED?

Goethe Society and Open Space Institute generously provided funding for the UNDER AFTER and IN BETWEEN project and travel expenses for participants from Southeast Asia.  Recently invited, I am raising my own travel money of $2500.  This covers air fare and expenses from NY to Jakarta and then to Yogyakarta and back. 

WHAT DO YOU GET?

Each donor can use this link http://www.ustream.tv/channel/emptyspacechiangmai to follow a live feed of our project.  This feed will be available, as possible, onsite during the worshop and performances in Indonesia, and as a permanent archive thereafter.  Empty Space director, Manuel Lutgenhorst, has promised to edit footage of the project and to put together a DVD and a booklet with text and photos of the process and final piece. If you cannot donate and are interested, follow the project on the link above or contact amy.trompetter@gmail.com.  I am happy to send relevant updates as our work progresses.  And please spread the word about this campaign.  Thank you!

Each donor can use this link http://www.ustream.tv/channel/emptyspacechiangmai to follow a live feed of our project.  This feed will be available, as possible, onsite during the worshop and performances in Indonesia, and as a permanent archive thereafter.  Empty Space director, Manuel Lutgenhorst, has promised to edit footage of the project and to put together a DVD and a booklet with text and photos of the process and final piece. If you cannot donate and are interested, follow the project on the link above or contact amy.trompetter@gmail.com.  I am happy to send relevant updates as our work progresses.  And please spread the word about this campaign.  Thank you!

story:
Hello, this is Erica Essner, artistic director of the Erica Essner Performance Co-Op. This July, my dance company has been invited to present an evening of work on the outdoor stage at the historic Jacob’s Pillow dance festival. This is a wonderful opportunity for us to present our new work, “Weathered,” in this beautiful setting in the Berkshires as part of the festival’s 80th anniversary season. Audiences young and old will attend this unique venue and see our company for the first time.

Won’t you consider making a donation to help us bring the company to Jacob’s Pillow this summer?

  • The evening will feature our latest dance, "Weathered," performed by a fantastic cast of dancers that includes Lucie Baker, Courtney Drasner, Marcos Duran, Josh Palmer and Hannah Seidel.
  •  Jacob's Pillow Dance is "one of America's most precious cultural assets" (Mikhail Baryshnikov) and "the dance center of the nation" (The New York Times).

This year the company celebrates our twenty-second anniversary. I founded the Erica Essner Performance Co-Op in San Francisco in 1990 and enjoyed a decade of performing, teaching and touring in the San Francisco Bay Area. In 2000, I moved the company to New York City where the company has had much success. Recent achievements include a commissioned dance for FlicFest in Brooklyn, site-specific work on The High Line and performances at the San Francisco International Arts Festival, Central Park SummerStage, Joyce SoHo, Rio de Janeiro Choreographic Center, Alaska Dance Theater and the Kaatsbaan International Dance Center.

Forceful and dynamic, our company builds vibrant movement from autobiography and theme. Our work has been described by the San Francisco Examiner as "exceptional...all the drama of story and character while putting movement at center stage." The key to each dance is our cast; their input and personal history contribute to the final “story.” Our collaborative-based company seeks broad audiences; to this end, we offer open rehearsals and forums that provide insight into the company’s creative process.

By contributing to our campaign you will help us share our work at "The Pillow," a treasured 163-acre National Historic Landmark and home to America's longest-running international dance festival.

With your help, we can raise the $5,000 needed to pay our dancers for rehearsals and performances, and to provide for their housing and transportation. (Our total budget is $10,000, of which we have already raised half!)

  • As a donor, you will receive unique perks, such as a private invitation to rehearsals, an autographed cast photograph and program acknowledgment.
  • If we don’t reach our goal, the funds raised will help defray the costs of dancers rehearsal and performance fees for this event.

It’s easy to donate. Just click the button on this page.

Please help spread the word by forwarding this campaign to friends who might support this project. You can do this by using the Indiegogo share tools on this page. Any amount helps get us on our way, you may choose to contribute your own amount to this campaign.

Thank you in advance for your support and contribution!

Erica Essner

Artistic Director

Erica Essner Performance Co-Op

story:
Short Summary

We are Work in Progress Productions, dedicated to encouraging young people to participate in the performing and creative arts while entertaining our community.

The Longwood area, where we rehearse and perform, is vast and full of many talented young people who lack opportunities. This show, like all our others over the past 9 years, is intended to bring the arts to a community that desperately needs it. This year, we want to go for "all the marbles" and become a recognized non-profit company.

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $5000 to pay the fees associated with becoming a non-profit. We hope you will decide to pledge any amount, and check out our fabulous prizes such as signed posters, unique artwork, and even a pianist for a night!

The Impact

Last year, we had a successful campaign just to raise money to build a set for a show. This year, our campaign is a little more far-reaching. We want this group to keep on nourishing the talent of young people in our community, and having the official non-profit status is a huge step towards longevity. Our church home (Middle Island Presbyterian Church) will be more willing to host us, which is a big deal, too. The reason this group has happened for the past nine years is that it impacts the young people; they want to do this, they want to have something to fill their summer and keep them active, they want to be a part of something. Non-profit status will solidify our place and our goals in the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't pledge at least $1, you can still help! Share our campaign with everyone you know! And come see our show at the end of July: SURE THINGS, a collection of one-act comedies by Christopher Durang and David Ives, directed by Evan Muthig and Victoria Shure, produced by Evan Muthig and Kevin Story, featuring 11 talented young actors.

We are Work in Progress Productions - Encouraging our Youth - Entertaining our Community.

Find out more at www.wipproductions.net.

story: Spiritually gifted 15-year-old Daja Wilson has been struggling to hold her family together since the tragic passing of her songstress mother. Fighting daily to be seen despite her father’s deep grief and her sister’s rage, she discovers it’s not so easy to hold on to those who want to let go.

story:
Thank you to all our fans, friends, and supporters who have helped us reach the goal we set for this campaign.  However, it's still not too late to join the team and the listed perks are still valid for each and every donation level.  While we have hit our target amount for the Sneak Peek and Ko Festival performances fundraising, we have a full production run slated for Fall 2011.  Any amount collected from this point forward will be applied to the artist fees, theatre rental, and production remounting expenses for this fall's World Premiere run in Los Angeles.  Thanks for visiting and supporting innovative Los Angeles theatre!

WHAT IS THIS?

Stranger Things is a new world premiere production by The Ghost Road Company directed by ensemble member Ronnie Clark.  Inspired by the works and ideas of existential philosopher Albert Camus, this musical play examines self-identity, loyalty and the choices we make to survive.  A domestic tragedy set in a desolate rural area far up North, Stranger Things features original music by David O. As it delves into the emotional undercurrent of isolated individuals, the play investigates how our relationships to others, or lack thereof, define us.


WHERE IS THIS?

Stranger Things has been invited to be a part of the Ko Festival in Amherst, Massachusetts.  For over 20 years, KoFest has been presenting “original works that surprise, provoke and inspire,” and Stranger Things is a perfect addition to this year’s festival theme of “Secrets.”  We will be performing the play on August 5-7, 2011.


WHY THIS?

The Ghost Road Company has covered two years worth of developmental fees for this production in addition to arranging for all the artists’ travel.  Your support will help us pay the design fees and expenses, mount two Sneak Peek performances here in Los Angeles prior to Ko, and pay for the shipping expenses associated with getting the scenic pieces to Massachusetts.  In addition to the perks we are offering for your help, The Ghost Road Company is a 501(c)3 so your donation is 100% tax deductible.


WHO ARE YOU?

Cast:

KATHARINE NOON (Mother)

CHRISTEL JOY JOHNSON (Helga)

DOUG SUTHERLAND (Johan)

BRIAN WEIR (Matt)

DAVID O (Composer/Musical Director)


Company:

KATHARINE NOON (Artistic Director)

MARK SELDIS (Producing Director)

KIM GLANN (Producer)

RONNIE CLARK (Director)

LAUREL OLLSTEIN (Dramaturg)

RONALD WINGATE, JR. (Ensemble Member)


Designers:

MAUREEN WEISS (Set Designer)

CHRIS WOJCIESZYN (Lighting Designer)

CRICKET MYERS (Sound Designer)

PAMELA SHAW (Costume Designer)


ABOUT US

The Ghost Road Company develops its productions through unique ensemble-devised creation techniques.  After identifying the inspirational source material, the group begins workshopping by introducing images, sounds, music, and other works that further reflect or illuminate the overall theme of the story.  Raw material for the play is then generated through many weeks of exploration that include: free-writing, improvisation, physical expression without text, Viewpoints-based compositions, and some of Augusto Boal’s Image Theatre exercises.  This collaborative process engages the performers’ connection to the world from the very beginning on multiple levels: physical, mental, and emotional.  And with the addition of David O as the musical composer and collaborator on Stranger Things, the ensemble is immersed vocally and rhythmically as well.


I LIKE ALL THIS, BUT...

The Ghost Road Company is a small group of year-long working theatre artists.  We stay so busy creating new theatre that we often don’t have enough time to spread the word about our projects.  You can help without going out-of-pocket by sharing this link with your friends and/or posting it to your facebook page.  The Ghost Road Company always accepts in-kind donations of any items you might have to get rid of that you think a theatre company could use.  And you’d be surprised at the uses we can find for things.  Our last production made use of about 30 nearly destroyed old suitcases!  To arrange in-kind donations, simply email us at info@ghostroad.org.  Thank you!!!

story:
Invitations/Into/Traces (or) all i want to do is invent a machine which creates surprises

 

I am making a piece for Summerworks called Invitations/Into/Traces (or) all i want to do is invent a machine which creates surprises. This movement-based performance looks at embodied audience-performer relationships, mapping the traces of those happenings and being where we are.

The Summerworks Theatre Festival is Canada's largest juried theatre festival and runs from August 9th -19th in Toronto. Invitations/Into/Traces is one of the only dance/movement pieces invited to perform in this year's festival and it is one of three pieces chosen as an 'off-site' work.

An excerpt of this piece debuted at the Bad-Ass Mini Dance Fest at the Harbourfront Centre earlier this March and was also performed at this year's Summerworks Launch Party. The piece performed in August will be a full length version of what what was started at the Bad-Ass festival and will be performed at the Gladstone Hotel.

Lisa Conway has been commissioned to create the music score, Julia Sasso has been brought on as mentor/outside eye and Layne Hinton has been collaborating on technical/installation elements. A zine titled The Dictionary of Difficult Things is being developed to accompany the show with the help of Natalie Boustead. I am also working closely with you (the audience) but you didn't know that until you read it just now.

www.summerworks.ca

 

Impact of Support

If you assist with the creation of this work, you will be supporting the development and definition of what Canadian contemporary dance is and what it can be.

And we need you...

Participating in theatre festivals awards many benefits to artists and companies, including a broad audience reach, support from seasoned festival staff, and the opportunity to meet and learn from other contemporary artists and companies. That being said, it can be difficult for small, independent companies to earn back their production costs in ticket revenue alone, as the festival takes a significant cut of the ticket price. That's where fundraising comes in.

Development costs needing to be covered during this campaign include:

  • Rehearsal space rental fees
  • Summerworks admission fee
  • Payment for collaborating artists and composers 
  • Printing of The Dictionary of Difficult Things zine

We sincerely appreciate your support for this project as well as your support of contemporary dance made in Canada.

 

About the Artist

Cara Spooner has been involved in performance related projects as a dancer, choreographer, designer and curator.  She has presented work in Toronto's Nuit Blanche, XPACE Cultural Centre, The Harbourfront Centre's HATCH, Pleasure Dome, The Festival of New Dance, the Goethe Institut and Stromereien11 in Zürich Switzerland. 

www.caraspooner.com

story:
Our Story

Capoeira Angola, an ancient martial art of African origin, is one of the many cultural weapons used to break the chains of enslavement in Brazil. Played close to the ground, Capoeira Angola combines fluid, dance-like movements with kicks, head butts, tripping sweeps and the appearance of playfulness or vulnerability. Music is played on traditional instruments to accompany the players, to teach the rhythmic heart of the art, and also to mask its power. In the eyes of the enslavers it appeared to be a playful acrobatic dance. Eventually its power was realized and Capoeira was outlawed. Death was the penalty paid by those caught playing Capoeira during the time of slavery. For almost 400 years Capoeira Angola was taught and practiced in secret, only in the 1930's did this African martial art become legal to teach and practice.


João Grande first learned Capoeira Angola in Bahia, Brazil in 1950 from Mestre Pastinha, who continues to be his primary source of inspiration. He also studied under Mestre Cobrinha Verde, another well known and well respected capoeirista of that time. Since then he has been a dedicated student of the art form.


Mestre João Grande is a Grand Master of Capoeira Angola with more than 50 years of experience, a highly respected figure in the world of capoeira he has received numerous awards and recognition. He’s been living and teaching Capoeira Angola in New York City for the past 22 years. To celebrate this great achievement he is offering a 4 day workshop, open to all capoeiristas in the world from all different styles.


The workshop will pay homage to Mestre Pastinha and Mestre Cobrinha Verde and will be based on the teachings that were passed on to Mestre Joao Grande by these two Grand Masters. This is a rare opportunity for those who practice and love capoeira, as well as for those who would love to learn this art form, to come together and share a unique experience.

 

The event will be held by the Capoeira Angola Center of New York from April 5th to April 8th and will consist of four days filled with Capoeira Angola movement, music and philosophy led by Mestre Joao Grande. There will also be classes and discussions in Afro-Brazilian dance and Afro-Brazilian culture.

 

 

We are expecting several special guests from the world of capoeira and look forward to honoring this beautiful art form as one solid community.

 

 

 

The Impact

There are very few living masters of Capoeira Angola with the depth of knowledge that Mestre Joao Grande has. The goal of the event is to give capoeiristas from all over the world the opportunity to experience Mestre Joao Grande's teachings and help preserve and spread the traditions of Capoeira Angola. The importance of maintaining the integrity of this art form, which has survived for more than 400 years, is immeasurable. 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise funds to sponsor special guests from Brazil, contemporaries of Mestre Joao Grande, well known Masters of the form and experts on Brazilan culture who will teach and provide context for the event. The funds will provide airfare and lodging for these special guests. Monies will also go toward financial aid for those traveling long distances and are in need of lodging as well as helping families in need pay for multiple children participating. We will also need to secure an event space that will accommodate the expected participants. Should we not reach our entire goal monies will go toward paying marketing and event collateral such as fliers, posters, post cards and t-shirts. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Another way you can help is by putting the word out and tell your friends about this great event. You can do that by e-mailing the link of our campaign to your friends. You can post it on Facebook or twitter. You can share with your co-worker or a company/group that might have interest in Capoeira. You can tell your friends and family, or use of any other legal way to get the buzz going. Our team would be very grateful to you. Thank you!

story:
Having brilliant, talented Chicago actresses perform as Victor Frankenstein and the Monster in ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN is going to be a thrill that we need your help to make happen!

 

With the ALL GIRL project, the Mammals are committed to providing extremely unique opportunities for Chicago actresses to play roles that are rarely if ever performed by women. The stories that we picked are 3 classics from the Western Canon with either none or relatively few female characters (ALL GIRL MOBY DICK, ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN, and ALL GIRL HEART OF DARKNESS).

In the spring of this year the Chicago Mammals produced ALL GIRL MOBY DICK with Amy Harmon as Ahab, Erin Orr as Ishmael/Moby Dick and a plethora of amazing actresses as the crew of the Peqoud.

Sold out houses and immense critical acclaim made producing ALL GIRL MOBY DICK one of most rewarding experiences that this theater company has been a part of. The second phase of this project is ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN slated for production in Fall of 2013. 

We need your help to bring the MONSTER to life!

Visualizing a classic piece of science fiction requires resources. We need your help getting the lumber, paint, and additional design elements. Also we need your help to keep our studio open, a safe place to mold and shape this amazing play and share it with our audience.

Thank you for helping us realize this goal. As perks for giving to our cause, we're giving free admissions to this and other future productions by the Chicago Mammals. We also have publications about who we are and the projects we do. Our hope is that these perks will be greatly anticipated by our truest fans, and that they will inspire you to help us make ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN LIVE!!!.
