story:
In a modern day tale of mythic proportions, two soul mates, unwittingly destined to end the world, set out on an adventure quest across the earth to find each other. The premier production of Thirty Thousand One completely melds dance and drama, with a dynamic mix of the mythic and the present day, the fantastical and the realistic - this show is not to be missed!

Thirty Thousand One is the first production of Pursuit Productions, an exciting new Chicago company founded by Ahmad Simmons and Kacie Smith. The mission of Pursuit Productions is to produce and present the work of innovative and emerging artists in the greater Chicago community that is collaborative in nature and pushes the boundaries of current artistic genres.

But we need YOUR HELP! To make the show a reality, we would greatly appreciate your charitable, tax-deductible donation!

We would also absolutely love to see you at the show, playing at Theater Wit August 2-12!

Note: Thirty Thousand One is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Thirty Thousand One must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

 

*****

Thirty Thousand One features an original script by Kacie Smith, complemented by Ahmad Simmons's choreography and Colin Fulton's score.

Thirty Thousand One is the first production of Pursuit Productions, an exciting new Chicago company founded by Ahmad Simmons and Kacie Smith. Pursuit Productions is dedicated to the melding of genres and media to explore stories, new and old, pertaining to the human pursuit of life, happiness and purpose. While currently focusing on dance and drama with founders Ahmad Simmons and Kacie Smith, the goal of Pursuit Productions is to expand and incorporate other artists of different media from across the Chicagoland area.

 

***** 

SHOW INFORMATION

August 2nd-12th @ Theater Wit
Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 pm
Sunday, August 5 at 7pm
Sunday, August 12 at 3pm

Buy tickets HERE!

 

The story is a modern day myth. The Creator places two perfect souls on the Earth at its inception and sets the Earth turning, promising that on the day those two souls unite, the Earth will come to an end. Fearing this end, the Earth keeps the two lovers apart for 30,000 lifetimes, but slowly learns the weariness of eternal life. At the start of our story, the two lovers, Ilsa and Simon, are in their thirty thousandth and first lifetime, and they show the signs of their souls’ extreme old age. The Earth, in agony from the weariness of continuing to turn and weighted down by humanity, calls out to the Creator to help bring Ilsa and Simon together. The Creator, by revealing to Ilsa and Simon their destiny, pushes the two souls into an epic quest across the Earth to find each other and unknowingly bring about the end of the world.

This piece explores the plight of the romantic in a world of cynics, the dreamers who hold on to a fantastical idea despite all odds. It also explores the suffering of the Earth at the hands of humanity, and the idea of death as an act of compassion.

Thirty Thousand One utilizes both worlds of dialogue and dance to their fullest extent. This piece also seeks to contrast the heightened expansiveness of the dance and original music of the story with 21st century characters and colloquial dialogue, thus highlighting that the fantastical can happen even now, in our own time.

 

*****

ARTISTIC COLLABORATORS

Katarina Podlesnaya (Producer)

Naomi Rosen (Producer)

Katie Caruso (Development Assistant)

Rachel Stubbleï¬eld-Tave (Stage Manager)

Sam Mueller (Assistant Stage Manager)

Colin Fulton (Composer, Sound Designer)

Yonit Olshan (Costume Designer)

Sarah Petty (Lighting Designer)

Henry Behel (Set Designer)

Angela Dice (Assistant Choreographer)

 

*****

CAST

Jessica Tomlinson… The Creator
Joshua Manculich… The Earth
Julie Matolo… Ilsa
Luke Couzens …Simon
Andrew Goetten… Barnes
Lorraine Freund… Narrator/Mother
Angela Dice… The Female
Nico Ager… Dudley/Pluto
Hayden Clifton… Ensemble
Emma Peterson… Ensemble
Marissa Horton… Ensemble
Brian Humphreys… Ensemble
Erin Kouwe… Ensemble
Michael McDonald… Ensemble
Cassandra Porter… Ensemble
Teagan Rose… Ensemble
Didi Scanlon… Ensemble
Pavel Tabutov… Ensemble

story:
Dear Friends and Supporters,

 

It is with great pleasure that I share the amazing news that my dance company, John J Zullo Dance/Raw Movement, has been invited to perform at the LaMama Spoleto Open in Spoleto, Italy this September. We will share my newest work ALL what THIS do HAS you HAPPENED see BEFORE. The work delves into my fascination with perception, perspective and memory and how we have to "know" what we "see" as well as our desire to remember what has happened before and how it changes as we remember it. It's a wonderful opportunity for me as artist to share my work with an international audience, arts presenters from Europe, and the chance for a residency next summer in Spoleto. It is an honor as I am the only US dance company on the program as well as a decades long dream to show my own work in Europe. I have been a performing artist in the work of other great artists for many years, but now is my opportunity to take the next step in my career as a dance-maker. And you can help make this happen.

 

The festival gives us the theater and press to perform as well as assistance with accomodations, however it is up to me to get us there. Thgis is where I need your help. The airfare is $1044.00 for each of us, with 6 of us needing to get to the festival. This is where you can help me make this dream opportunity a reality! I have raised $1900.00 so far but my total airfare is $6264.00. That's why you can help me with getting one of my dancers to Spoleto. Each and every dollars is greatly appreciated, no amount is too small (or too large!). 

 

For any other information you would like about me or my work please visit my website johnjzullodance.com or email me at john@johnjzullodance

 

I thank you in advance for supporting the sharing of new works and ideas.

Best

John J Zullo

story:
Voices of the South debuted An Old Forest Fairy Tale at the children's theater festival over Memorial Day weekend. Written by company member Virginia Ralph, it tells the story of a little girl who lives near Overton Park and develops a special relationship with the creatures of the Old Forest. At bedtime, she's whisked off to fairyland where she's invited to participate in a play performed by a whale (in a tree costume), a drum-playing polar bear, a redbird, two fairies, and the (ex) planet Pluto. The play within the play tells the true story of how the original CPOP members, derided at the time as a bunch of "old ladies in tennis shoes," saved Overton Park from being bulldozed to make way for Interstate 40.

According to Chris Davis of the Memphis Flyer, "It's a thoroughly charming hyper-local fantasy about conservation, and how ordinary people can join together, take a stand, and make a difference even if they're mocked and bullied."

To celebrate the designation of the 126-acre Old Forest State Natural Area at Overton Park, the current members of CPOP invite you to experience the magic of this play firsthand at a special screening where Sunshine Snyder, one of those brave ladies in tennis shoes, will also be in attendance!

This special show is Friday, September 28, at 7:00pm at the Evergreen Theatre (1705 Poplar Avenue). Everyone is welcome to join us for a pre-show reception starting at 6:00pm.

All funds raised from this campaign will go directly to Voices of the South in order to support the entire 12-show run from September 14-29.

story:
Dear Internet,

 

Mariah MacCarthy here, Producing Director of the brand-new Caps Lock Theatre, which does funny, human, ugly plays by whatever means necessary (check out our swanky website!). We're in our infancy, and so stoked to exist! But right now, the "by whatever means necessary" part is coming into play.

 

Why We Need You

We have a production coming up in April, The Foreplay Play, which is a dark comedy I wrote about a thwarted foursome between a lesbian couple and a straight couple. It's sexy and funny and sad. Love! Betrayal! Spin the Bottle! Twister! Cat Stevens! This play has it all.

The Foreplay Play stars an insanely attractive, unbelievably talented cast: Lindsey Austen, Nic Grelli, Parker Leventer, and Diana Oh. I love them very much and want to pay them. The fabulous Leta Tremblay is directing. I love her too. I want to pay her too.


We're doing it site-specifically in an apartment in Williamsburg, which allows the actors to do things like COOK ACTUAL CHICKEN in front of you and then EAT THE CHICKEN. Which means we need to buy chicken, as well as insurance to make sure everyone is safe. (Insurance is 1/3 of our total budget. A third! Dudes!)

Oh, and we want people to see the show, which means paying for things like postcards and press reps and stuff. And we have to rehearse somewhere, which usually isn't free.

Which means we need $3,000, and your help. Fortunately, there's something in it for you, too.

For a donation, someone from the Foreplay Play team will perform part or all of ANY SONG YOU REQUEST and put it on video for the whole internet to see.

$10 gets you at least 30 seconds of a song--most likely a verse, chorus, or bridge.
$20 gets you at least a minute.
$50 gets you the whole song.

 
Let me clarify what I mean by "perform": We might sing it. We might perform it as a dramatic monologue a la Travis Bedard. We might dance to it. We might enact a puppet show air band to it. YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT WE'RE GONNA DO.

Once you've donated, email capslocktheatre@gmail.com and tell me what song you'd like us to perform! We will endeavor to record and post your video within a week or so (if we decide to go all-out for your video, it might take longer, but we'll keep you posted either way). 

As I mention in the video, in addition to being able to request a song, you can request who does it! These members of the Foreplay Play team are at your disposal:

  • Director and all-around adorable human Leta Tremblay


  • Actor, guitar player, singer, and hip-hop dancer Nic Grelli (Nic has even offered to perform in some state of undress, if you so desire, as you will see if you keep scrolling.)
  • Actor, singer, and ukulele champ Diana Oh
  • And yours truly, playwright and rap beast Mariah MacCarthy

 

 

We are at your beck and call. In fact, we've already gotten started -- there are three videos of us making asses of ourselves at the end of this page to whet your appetite.

 

 

"But I'm Not Loaded!"

If you're poor, there are still so many ways you can help! We encourage you to team up with a friend or four and split the cost of a song! Just email us at capslocktheatre@gmail.com and we will make your wildest karaoke dreams come true.

Can't donate at this time? Feel free to share the campaign via facebook, twitter, email, carrier pigeon, smoke signal, interpretive dance, or however your little heart desires. We are also very open to GUEST ARTISTS! If you want to sing or shake your booty with us, email capslocktheatre@gmail.com to get involved!


Now on to the videos! First, the lovely Nidia Medina has already graciously donated $20, which got her a (mostly) naked Prince cover from Nic:

 

Next: a guy on the street gave me and Diana money to sing U2, which we did, while running through the East Village. I dare you to watch this video without smiling.

 

Finally, here's Diana and Leta singing Chris Brown.
 
There's so much more where that came from! Take advantage of us, please!
 
Love,
Mariah and the Foreplay Play crew

story:
Our Story

Our musical Lightning Man began at the Tisch Graduate Musical Theatre Writing Program. Our first draft started as a collection of songs with Jeff writing the music and Shoshana, Katya and Janet writing lyrics. The songs were loosely inspired by Roy Sullivan, a man who in real life survived 7 lightning strikes! The character of Lightning came to life in the shape of 3 seductive and dangerous women. A few months ago, Maggie-Kate joined our team as the bookwriter. We now have two fantastic opportunities to continue the development of our show.  Lightning Man was selected to be part of the 2011 ANT Fest at Ars Nova this October, and we’re also planning a reading of our newly revised show at Primary Stages this winter.  We’re thrilled with both of these opportunities, and we need your help!


Who We Are

Jeffrey Dennis Smith (Composer)

Shoshana Greenberg (Lyricist)

Maggie-Kate Coleman (Bookwriter)

Sam Pinkleton (Director)

Performed by Joshua Isaacs, Ally Bonino, Alyse Alan Louis, and Grace McLean
Directed by Sam Pinkleton
Music Direction by Cian McCarthy
Alden Terry on bass
Joe Choroszewski on drums


What We Need

We’re extremely grateful for Ars Nova for providing a space within ANT Fest. We also extend much appreciation to Primary Stages for providing a space for our reading in the winter. The part that we’re responsible for – and for which we need your help – is in providing payment for the wonderful artists who will breathe life into our show. We’ll require the help of 5 actors, a director, a music director, a drummer and a bass player. We’ll need the help of these people for both events!  And without these people our show simply won’t exist, and every member of our cast and crew is shockingly talented!


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Tell everyone you know about the show and the campaign. 

Come see our show at Ars Nova on Monday, October 24, 8pm!
Click here for more info and to buy tickets.

story:
OUR STORY

We are The Country Dance World Champions The Chili Chicks dance team, we are a community orientated team made up of professional women of all ages and backgrounds. From college students to professional dance instructors, we range in age from eighteen to forty plus and come to the team with everything from no dance experience to pro level resumes. The Chili Chicks provide great family friendly performances that are crowd pleasing and interactive. We are literally “the girls next door”, and we take great pride in providing entertainment for the entire family.

We need an entry level tour bus so we can travel more cost effectively across the country and reach more friends and fans from coast to coast, spreading the love and entertainment of country dance. 

WHY YOU SHOULD CARE

If we are able to purchase a tour bus, we will be able to continue to grow as a team and reach a much wider audience, therefore impacting more people across the country. We have outgrown our current resources that allow us to travel to various events, and it is time to take the next step in order to grow to the next level. While many large events ask us to perform and provide transportation costs, we foot the cost to take our show to schools and small community type events and with travel costs so high we have to turn down many of the smaller ones including many that we would donate our time to but can't get to because of the costs involved.This bus will allow us to avoid renting one and getting motel rooms each trip thus allowing us to accept more invitations from schools and community events and to reach out and introduce more youth and people of all ages to the love and art of country dance. We can’t reach them all, but we can reach out to those we can get to.

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We only need $15,000 more to get an entry level tour bus. There are many costs associated with Team travel and having our own bus will help us to do away with having to get motel rooms and renting a bus/R.V for every trip. This will also allow us to do more events that don't have the budget to cover our current travel expenses but who would really like us to perform for them. If you are able to help us reach this goal in any way, we would really appreciate it and along with our appreciation we'd like to give you some great thank you gifts as well! We have a lot of exciting events in the upcoming months and years that we hope to attend and would love for you to be a part of it! Thank you!

HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

 

If you can’t help even just a little bit or you can but you’d like to do more, then pass this news on to others and send them this link so they can get involved in this opportunity and help us reach our goal. Thanks for your support and hopefully someday soon we’ll be rolling into your town on the bus you helped make possible.
story_txt:
OUR STORY
We are The Country Dance World Champions The Chili Chicks dance team, we are a community orientated team made up of professional women of all ages and backgrounds. From college students to professional dance instructors, we range in age from eighteen to forty plus and come to the team with everything from no dance experience to pro level resumes. The Chili Chicks provide great family friendly performances that are crowd pleasing and interactive. We are literally “the girls next door”, and we take great pride in providing entertainment for the entire family.
We need an entry level tour bus so we can travel more cost effectively across the country and reach more friends and fans from coast to coast, spreading the love and entertainment of country dance. 
WHY YOU SHOULD CARE

If we are able to purchase a tour bus, we will be able to continue to grow as a team and reach a much wider audience, therefore impacting more people across the country. We have outgrown our current resources that allow us to travel to various events, and it is time to take the next step in order to grow to the next level. story:
Our Story

Jessica Miller Tomlinson is a professional dancer and choreographer who is actively working in the Chicago dance community. As a young choreographer I have made it a personal goal to challenge myself to create a body of work that is recognizable as my own but also varies in style, range of perspective and that shows versatility as an artist. My hope is to innovate without self-consciousness and to be new and new again, to have the ability to lead an audience effortlessly from beginning to end no matter how imaginative the journey between. As an active member of the Chicago dance community, I feel a responsibility to help maintain a sense of culture in order to preserve the performing arts. My professional choreographic career was elevated to a new level with the Grand Prize Win at The A.W.A.R.D. Show! 2009:Chicago. Since receiving this grant from The Joyce Theater Foundation, I have been taking on various projects to help further the community in Chicago and other independent artists like myself. For Instance, in June 2010 I self produced a full-length choreographic showcase that presented an eclectic mix of dance professionals from the community. In addition, I have combined forces with other organizations such as: Chicago based musicians District 97, The Fashion Department of the Merchandise Mart, Dance For Life, The Dance Center of Columbia College and am currently working on a joint venture with colleague Jacqueline Stewart entitled "Dance Gallery". In March of 2011 I will be presenting a concert with Chicago artists Winifred Haun and Dancers and Jacqueline Stewart. I am extremely honored to be presenting work at The Joyce SoHo this June as part of The A.W.A.R.D. Show !All-Stars. I am trying to raise money for this trip to NYC so that I can reimburse my in incredible dancers for endless hours of rehearsal, and dedication to my passion.


 

 


The Impact

This trip to NYC to perform at The Joyce SoHo will have such a positive impact on my career as a young, independent choreographer. It is rare that you receive opportunities like this one and I am so grateful and want to use this trip as an opportunity to help spread my name and work to a broader audience base. Not only will this trip benefit myself as a choreographer but it will also help my amazing dancers to further their own careers. Going to NYC is such a great opportunity to network with other dance professionals. I feel I owe it to my dancers to make this trip a success, because of the endless hours in the studio and the dedication to my passion and artistic visions. This is the only source of funding which I have for this project other than my own wallet and that of my incredible husband who as a fellow artist,  whole-heartedly supports my visions. The support for this campaign will help make this trip to NYC a successful venture for myself and my dancers and let us rest assured that we will be able to eat, sleep and dance safely and to the best of our abilities.


What We Need & What You Get

I am hoping to raise $500 for this campaign. The money raised will go directly to my incredible dancers. Mollie, Jackie, Brian and Jeremy have all put in countless hours of blood, sweat and tears to make my choreographic visions a reality and I owe them the world, but as a fellow dancer, understand the importance of a paycheck regardless of the amount. Having this funding will make it easier for all of my dancers and I to have an enjoyable, successful trip to NYC. In return for your support, you not only will receive my undying gratification, but I will personally send you a thank you card signed by myself and my dancers, which includes a series of photos from our trip to NYC to perform at The Joyce SoHo.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word that Jessica Miller Tomlinson is presenting work at The Joyce SoHo for the first time!!

story:
A Dream of Camelot has been invited to The Global Summit 2012 as part of their Arts & Culture program.  We invite you to be part of our Dream Team in whatever way you like, to make the dream of a better world a reality through art and in society!
 
The Global Summit is dedicated to uniting the world's social, economic, and environmental movements to ensure a sustainable future for all. It will be held August 15 - 17 in the London Pleasure Gardens, timed to coincide with the Summer Olympic Games. 
 

A DREAM OF CAMELOT -
The Inspired Musical about Living the Dream
The characteers from Camelot, faced with the destruction of their world, vision their new society and then show up in modern times, faced with a dance of relationships that is grist for the mill in healing their own lives. A Dream of Camelot is about loving communication - inside and out; it's about letting go of what isn't working and finding new ways within ourselves to change our lives and our world.
  
 As the "A Dream of   Camelot" project developed, a realization dawned that many people need to change deeply rooted patterns which are expressed in the Archetype of Camelot in order to live their dream.  Each song in “A Dream of Camelot” is an expression of consciousness in a process of maturing awareness.  Human problems were brought to the Inspiration, and Spirit provided answers through the songs.

A Dream of Camelot has taken six years of writing and development to become the transformational catalyst it now is for casts and audiences alike.

 To bring this musical to The Global Summit is to powerfully express the inner process of awakening love as the foundation of the change The Global Summit is dedicated to. Your help in this endeavor will allow us to provide an inspiration for participants of the Summit to seed a world of Dreams-come-true.


Feel free to make a donation at one of the Perk levels or give whatever feels right for you.  To donate ANY AMOUNT click on "CONTRIBUTE NOW" at bottom or top of page, and then scroll down and select the button "no perk, just a contribution" and then fill in whatever amount you like.

What We Need & What You Receive

We are needing to fund transportation, hotel costs, rehearsal space and payment for cast and crew.  We estimate this will cost about $40,000 US

With your help, we fully expect that we will raise the necessary funds for the production. If the full amount is not raised here, your contributions will still be used for transportation, housing and other expenses to make the performance possible. Thank you!!!

 

Track Record of A Dream of Camelot (A History):

A Dream of Camelot had its first reading in 2009 at the UR Light Center in Black Mountain, NC . The first full production, directed by Jerry Crouch, was presented at the Asheville, NC Masonic Temple, March 11, 12, 13, 2011 and the musical returned to the Masonic Temple, March 29, 30, 31, and April 1st,  2012, directed by Rock Eblen.

More info:

Here is info about the Global Summit 2012 which includes an invitation for sponsors. 
http://theglobalsummit.org/pdf/The_Global_Summit_2012_Program_Overview_Intro_Impact_365.pdf  We plan to raise money here to supplement The Global Summit's fundraising. 
 
Here is the story of how A Dream of Camelot came to be written: http://www.richheartmusic.com/DreamofCamelot.html

Web page about the musical
http://www.richheartmusic.com/ADreamOfCamelotMusical.html


Youtubes:

Here's the opening song "Victory Celebration" from this spring's production.
http://youtu.be/yeol90vibvc

"Now"  from this spring's  production.
http://youtu.be/9B3YtSjOoio
 
"Something About Him" from last year's production.
http://youtu.be/xnda_tun-dU
  
"The Dominator Model" from this Spring's production.
http://youtu.be/mhvRBX5D_VU
  
"No Words Could Ever Tell"  from this spring's  production.
http://youtu.be/xOwIpSlyou4
  
"Who You Are is Beautiful" from last year's production
http://youtu.be/vOwvgEdtIRI

To hear most of the songs: http://www.jukeboxalive.com/audio_play_offsite.php?mid=1676603&skin=1143452

 

We invite everyone to enjoy the music and Youtube videos and spread the word about  A Dream of Camelot!  

Thanks and Blessings, 

The Camelot Dream team.

story:
---¿POR QUÉ?---

Este proyecto surge a raíz de una necesidad, la de expresar la lucha a la que se someten los artistas a la hora de trabajar en cualquiera de sus disciplinas.

¿Por qué Cabaret?

Decidimos hacer este tipo de espectáculo, para poder romper con las reglas y ponernos a prueba  a nosotras mismas. Esta disciplina permite utilizar tanto el baile, como el canto, como la interpretación y es también una herramienta idónea para la crítica social.

¿Por qué Rock?

Utilizamos míticas canciones de rock de los 80´, queríamos rescatarlas , evadirnos de la actualidad tecno-pop y usar estos clásicos tan conocidos,  versionándolos con un estilo que concuerda a la perfección con el espectáculo.

¿Por qué Show?

Porque es para todos los públicos, con música en vivo, en clave de humor y porque en los tiempos que corren hay que tratar de que el espectador desconecte de sus realidades y pasen un rato agradable y divertido en el teatro.

REHAB, Cabaret Rock Show, no es un concierto de música, no es una obra de teatro, no es un espectáculo de danza, es todo eso y mucho más, es un cóctel explosivo que romperá los esquemas de todo aquel que se atreva a adentrarse en un mundo donde no sabrá distinguir la realidad de la ficción.


---SINOPSIS---

Una escuela de rehabilitación, REHAB (Real Escuela de Hábitos Artísticos Básicos)

Carlota, actriz, no ejerce, se inscribe en la REHAB buscando otro MÉTODO para hacerse un hueco en el mundo de la interpretación, el sueño de su vida. 
Elsa y Lucía, afincadas y resignadas alumnas, se encargaran de mostrarle la realidad de esta escuela tan peculiar.

"Aquí se enseñan otro tipo de técnicas y métodos" 
"hay que explotar otras cualidades" 
"investigar en otros campos"

'La Tresena en discordia' nos ofrece un espectáculo en clave de rock .
Un cabaret que incluye danza, teatro y música en directo.
Una crítica hacia el "mundillo" al que se ven obligados los artistas a pertenecer para poder hacer de su sueño una profesión.


---LA COMPAÑÍA---
'La Tresena en discordia' somos una nueva compañía formada por tres jóvenes actrices residentes en Madrid Las tres juntas nos diplomamos en Réplika Teatro cursando teatro, danza y canto. Por fin hemos decidido tirarnos a la piscina escribiendo una pieza que englobe todas estas disciplinas con la ayuda de unos músicos maravillosos. 

---ADAYA SALVÁ---
Procedente de Tudela (Navarra) . Cursó diferentes disciplinas de la danza y el teatro en la escuela de Ángel Martínez. Continua su carrera en Madrid y se diploma en Réplika Teatro en las artes escénicas. Recibe diferentes cursos de cabaret por parte de Eduardo Solís.Hasta la fecha ha formado parte de montajes cómo "Las Bizarrías de Belisa", dirigida por Gabriel Garbisu, "Las brujas de Salem", dirigida por Jaroslaw Bielski y "Nuestra Cocina" dirigida por Jaroslaw Bielski, donde también hace las veces de ayudante de dirección, entre otras. Es actriz y co creadora de la web serie, "Zonas Comunes".
 ---MARÍA ARAÍZ---
Desde su Estella (Navarra) natal, María llegó a Madrid a estudiar periodismo, pero pronto se decantó por el mundo del teatro. Se diplomó en Réplika Teatro. Entre los montajes en los que ha participado destacan "Las Criadas " dirigida por Jaroslaw Bielski, "El loco y la monja", dirigida por Jaroslaw Bielski y "La habitación azul" dirigida por Jaroslaw Bielski. 
---MARINA FÀBREGAS---
Nacida en Tarragona (Cataluña), ha estudiado canto con Remei Tell, Miguel Tubía y Olga Manzano. En Madrid se diplomó en la escuela Réplika Teatro. Ha formado parte de montajes como "Nuestra Cocina", dirigida por Jaroslaw Bielski, "El caso de las petunias pisoteadas" dirigida por Jose Manuel Taracido o "Un tranvía llamado deseo " dirigida por Jaroslaw Bielski. Además es una de las actrices protagonistas del corto "Entre tanto" dirigido por Carla Calparsoro. 

---FICHA ARTÍSTICA Y COLABORADORES---
Sala de ensayo: La Íntegra Teatro.
Fotografía y asesoramiento artístico: Daniel Ghersi.
Dirección musical: Juan con Queso.
Dirección y Coreografías: Adaya Salvá.

---¿QUÉ NECESITAMOS?---
La producción de la obra corre a cargo de la propia compañía, que ya ha hecho una inversión inicial para poder empezar el proyecto. 
 Vuestra ayuda irá destinada a: 
Alquiler de la Sala de ensayo, escenografía, vestuario, material de iluminación y sonido, alquiler de estudio de grabación, publicidad y difusión.

Dirección y Coreografías: Adaya Salvá.

La producción de la obra corre a cargo de la propia compañía, que ya ha hecho una inversión inicial para poder empezar el proyecto. 
 Vuestra ayuda irá destinada a: 

Alquiler de la Sala de ensayo, escenografía, vestuario, material de iluminación y sonido, alquiler de estudio de grabación, publicidad y difusión.

story:
Summary

    This project is a year in the making culminating in an artist residency at the Penasco Theatre in Northern New Mexico in September. Imagine a performance completely comprised of projected images of dancers, except for one lone dancer. Join me on an exploration of expression filled with texture, dynamic sound and light, and innovative movement.

    With your contributions, I will be able to afford fees associated with my residency, purchase supplies to build mobile projection screens and offer my team of artists compensation for their tremendous time and effort.


      What We Need

      • Wood and fabric to build three mobile projection screens.
      • Projectionist, musician and videographer compensation. 

        The Impact

        By participating in a residency in rural Northern New Mexico, I am bringing innovative performance to an area often starved for art. During my residency it is my strongest desire to teach a community "master" class to those wanting to explore dance. Many thanks to the Penasco Theatre for its work in providing experiences like these to its community and surrounding areas.

          Can't contribute, but still want to help?

            Get the word out and make some noise about QUALIA. Share this on Facebook, Twitter and email it to your friends!

story:
My name is Anthony Schaus, head spinner at Illumini Arts, a fire-spinning and performance collective with a special interest in teaching local Sonoma Valley (for now anyway) elementary and middle school kids spinning skills.

In short,

We are seeking financial help to buy poi equipment and other supplies so that our young poi spinners can have what they need to create a performance in the Spring of 2014.

     Learning and performing the very ancient and fascinating art of spinning helps these kids enhance their self-esteem through mastery of a creative art, develop cooperation and social skills, and keep them out of trouble. Because all of the equipment purchased will be retained by Illumini Arts for use in our future programs, your contribution will benefit local kids well beyond this Spring’s training classes and performance.

Illumini Arts—What we do…

     We are a poi and spinning collective based in Sonoma, California. Since 2012, we have been volunteering at local schools and their after school programs, teaching local elementary and middle school children the ancient art of poi. Our classes are focused on a short performance that demonstrates what the kids have learned. This helps to keep them motivated and excited about increasing and enhancing their performance skills. It is truly inspiring and heart-warming to see the pride of the kids, as they learn to master complex moves, as well as working together in a team to create a few moments of magic for their peers, their parents, and interested members of the community. For some of these children, poi may be the only thing they have ever felt true mastery over and received praise and admiration for. We believe their enhanced self-esteem will certainly spill over into their academic and social life, and hopefully keep them from pursuing other less productive or socially unacceptable ways of spending their time. Because we are already working in the schools and with other after school programs, we have seen the demand and interest, and are confident of the positive impact this work is making in the lives of our local children.

Our Campaign—How you can help…

     We are reaching out to our local community and the poi community to take our existing program to a new and higher level. With the money we raise, we will purchase LED poi sets, a small PA system, practice poi, t-shirts for the kids, and storage cases to keep the equipment secure. Although we are currently seeking to use this equipment for a Spring 2014 performance, we intend to keep teaching and training using this equipment to involve more and more children in the future. Your contribution will have a long-lasting affect in our community. A small part of the funds (about $700) will also pay for our website hosting for 2014, to inform the community about the training and learning opportunities, mileage and other minimal reimbursements to our teachers for miscellaneous expenses, and of course the indie gogo fee. If the entire goal is not reached, our first priority will be to use any funds raised to purchase the equipment. We have budgeted for 20 children, but if the funds aren’t there, we can scale back to 15 or 10.


If You Can’t Contribute Money—We welcome your support…

     If you are a member of the spinning community, please help us spread the word. Tell your friends about us. Send them our link (see above). Copy what we are doing in your local schools and community. If you are interested in youth and education in the Sonoma Valley, please tell your friends, family and neighbors about our project. Encourage children you know to join our after school enrichment programs. Invite us to participate at your child’s school. Support the kids by coming to one of our performances. Send us positive thoughts and good wishes. Use the SHARE tools above to tweet about our campaign or let your Facebook friends know about our worthy cause. We humbly thank you!

story:
On Fonts

is a new play by me, Amy Virginia Buchanan

that will be going to Penasco Theatre in New Mexico in June to be featured in their Summer Season

and then will be brought back to Brooklyn to be performed at Cloud City in August!

By contributing, you will be helping us fly members of our company across the country to create On Fonts and then funding the transformation of space through design at Cloud City.

On Fonts is a play about property and permission in relation to our physical selves. In a world a little colder and much stranger than our own, a girl meets a boy and they grow together. Space and property is built up using words first, but then the question arises, “What happens when we run out of words?” Property moves from the linguistic realm to something a little more physical and things get interesting.

I began writing this piece while studying clown at Dell’Arte International School of Physical Theatre. I was drawn to the relationship a clown develops with an audience and the intense vulnerability a clown possesses, which allows him to broach difficult and weighty subjects with ease. I also fell in love with the collaborative process, enjoying taking a text or an idea and then building it with many different voices and bodies contributing. On Fonts is an unfinished script, in that I have written something that will shift and change as we develop the play together. When On Fonts was complete, I met with Claire Moodey  to ask her to direct and together, we have gathered the most amazing team of artists to help build this play. So, how’s about you take a moment to meet them?

 

Claire Moodey (director) is a Brooklyn-based theater artist with a B.A. from Bard College. As a director/writer/designer, she has created Spectral Findings and <the invisible draft> as well as several short pieces which have been shown throughout New York City. Her collaboration with Lotte Marie Allen for video on <the invisible draft> was awarded the Overall Excellence in video design at the New York City Fringe Festival in 2012. As a puppeteer, she has created and performed with Bread and Puppet Theater, Adhesive Theater Project, Alphabet Arts, the OWS Puppetry Guild, as well as for her original works. As an actor and singer, she has performed with EGG and Target Margin Theater’s Russian Futurist Lab, among others. Her recent work on The Service Road was lauded by the NYTimes “brilliantly jagged”. She is currently editing on an episode of Penny Arcade’s Lower East Side Biography Project featuring Richard Foreman.

Joseph Wolfslau (scenic, costume, prop, and sound design) is a set, sound, and costume designer based in New York City.  Recent designs include sound for TAPE (Strasberg Institute), sound for Clown Bar (Pipeline Theater Company), sound for #ReganCross (Theater Row), set, props, and costumes for Moon & Marble (Tugboat Collective), sound for Telemachus, Darling (HITS), set and costumes for The What Dance (Target Margin/Tugboat Collective), sound for 4 Sustenance (The Movement Theater Company), sound for The Rub (Hole in the Sky), costumes for Our Town (The New School), sound for The Good Person of Szechwan (Columbia), costumes for Ghost in the Machine (Dead Copycats), set, sound, and costumes for Harm’s Way (Philaletheus Society), sound for The Seagull (Lake Lucille), and sound for P.S. It’s Poison (Panic).

Serena Wong (lighting design) is a free lance lighting designer based in Brooklyn. She is delighted to be a part of this valiant production team, and to have found a play that mixes her love of typefaces and theatre.

Samantha Wiener (assistant designer)  is a Wig Maker and Off-Broadway Wig Supervisor in NYC.  She builds wigs for Tom Watson and Charles Lapointe for shows like Annie, Motown, Jersey Boys, Wicked, Bring It On the Musical, and Superman. She has been a Wig Supervisor on Hurt Village, February House, Soul Doctor, and All In The Timing; NYC: The Juiliiard School, The Metropolitan Opera, Signature Theatre Company, The Public Theatre, New York Theatre Workshop, Primary Stages; Regional: Wiliamstown, Santa Fe Opera, Alley Theatre

E. James Ford (actor) is a performer, writer, designer, and programmer based in NYC. He is a graduate of NYU’s Experimental Theatre Wing and Circle in the Square Theatre School. For 10 years he was a member of the clowning ensemble Six Characters, which he helped establish. The group toured nationally and received critical acclaim for its anarchic brand of physical comedy. Mr. Ford has performed in regional theatre and abroad, but the bulk of his theatre work has been in NYC where he has worked with some of the best and brightest minds in avant-gardde theatre including SITI Company, Richard Foreman’s Ontological/Hysteric Theatre, Mummenschanz, Title:Point Productions, Synaesthetic Theatre, Fulya Pekar, and Jeff Stark. On the web, Mr. Ford has appeared in the hit Sci-Fi web series Pioneer One, which won the award for Best New Drama at the NY International TV Festival and the Academy of Web Television Awards. In his non-actor life, he has served as the Director of Member Services for Fractured Atlas.

Milo Cramer (actor) is a theater artist living in Brooklyn. Milo is a founding member of theater groups NEW SALOON, with roommates Madeline Wise and Morgan Green, and EGG, with brother Max Cramer. Milo's plays include William Shakespeare's Mom, I'm Miserable but Change Scares Me, andMwah, and his work has been seen in New York at Ars Nova, Galapagos Art Space, and The Brick, and outside of New York at Williamstown Theater Festival and on YouTube. Excerpts of Milo's plays have been published in Bard Colllege's Bard Papers, Bennington College's Plain China, and Brooklyn College's The Brooklyn Review.

Each individual will bring an exciting and unique perspective to this play and by contributing, you will be enabling us to fully realize all that our imaginations can conjure.

And the spaces, oh the spaces, where we will be creating are both so exciting and perfect for our process. Penasco Theatre is situated in a rural part of northern New Mexico and it is a theatre whose focus is physical theatre, circus arts, and the education of children in these areas. Cloud City is the new venue brought to you by those folks that first brought you Dead Herring. With a history of clown, comedy, variety, and music shows, we are extremely pleased to be joining the ranks of amazing performance art that has gone and will be going through this venue. It is a large, raw space in Williamsburg that we will be transforming into our own little world. Like I said, perfect.

The Nitty Gritty       

After meeting with Claire and the designers, it was determined that we need to raise $5,000

This money will be spent on

  • Reimbursing the company for plane tickets to New Mexico and other transportation needs once we arrive
  • The barebones design elements that we will construct in New Mexico
  • Rehearsal space once we arrive back in Brooklyn
  • Scenic/prop elements and necessary tools
  • Lighting equipment
  • Costumes and make up
  • Equipment for sound
  • Advertisement

If we do not reach our entire goal, we will first reimburse plane tickets and then we will reexamine our design elements in order to compensate. BUT! We are so confident that we will be able to reach our goal because of the support from folks just like you.

And to thank you for your generosity, we have created some very enticing benefits for different levels of donation! These include quality time with the collaborative team, personally composed songs, baked goods, poems, and more!

So what’s the big deal about On Fonts?

On Fonts is the first production of Portal Sans Serif, a new production company I am launching. So far, I have produced/created children’s music events, cabaret and variety shows, small plays, literary theatre events, and folk music, all with the same goal but now under the same name. The mission statement for the Portal is simple: Opening doors and bravely crossing through thresholds with the content placed on stage, we aim to provide a clear and precise perspective while creating an earnest and unique experience for both performers and audience members alike.

Theatre and performance should be mutually beneficial to the people on stage and the people watching. It is an experience, an event, to be shared and considered. By fully fleshing out this production, we will have the opportunity to do our best to provide something worth spending time seeing. It will be worth that subway ride to Brooklyn and worth the money you spent on a ticket and a beer, and totally worth the time you spend with us at a bar afterward and, I am confident enough to say, that it will be worth that subway ride all the way back home.

What else is there to give?

If you find yourself asking this question, that is great! There are plenty of other ways to get involved that are not giving to this campaign. Maybe you have a car and you want to help us pick up rented lighting equipment. Maybe you have a really nice aunt in New Mexico that wants to make dinner for a group of vagabond theatre folk. Maybe you have a loud voice and want to help us get the word out about the show. Any help you can offer will be appreciated beyond belief.

When all is said and done, I will think to myself and, most likely, say on all sorts of social media, “We couldn’t have done it without you.” And that is and will be completely the case. We will build this show based on the generosity of the humans around us. So thank you. Thank you for your time and your support.

story:
Hotbuckle Productions ~ 'Pure Brilliance'

Hotbuckle's purpose is to bring excellent theatrical productions to the general public at an affordable price. Five dedicated actors and friends tour the UK and Ireland with adaptations of classic novels ~ next up is our Spring tour of 'David Copperfield.'

“...a tightly choreographed performance by all five of the actors, which worked beautifully, like a Swiss watch” Eastleigh News

“....a clever and novel re-birth of a famous classic that does not fail to grip you through its contemporary approach” Public Reviews

“...Hotbuckle are to be applauded for bringing classics to regional audiences in such an accessible and entertaining way.” Whatsonstage

“The freshly adapted play of Les Mis is pure brilliance." The Yorker

"..a masterful exposition of Hugo’s classic novel” Public Reviews

“Preater's adaptation has the same quality as David Edgar's "Nickleby" script… an outstanding production” remotegoat

What We Need

We are an unfunded theatre company and rely on ticket sales, donations and fundraisers to survive. These are tough times and we need extra help to see us through. We need to keep paying our actors (we do not subscribe to the theory that they should work for free or profit-share), we need to buy a new trailer, we need to pay for petrol, accommodation, printing and all of the other expenses that become increasingly difficult to meet as prices continue to go up.

The Impact

Any help you can give us at all is so appreciated. We have developed a lovely and loyal following from audience members that continue to come to all of our shows around the country and over the sea.  We want to carry on bringing quality theatre to them. We want to reach communities that can't get into London or to large theatres that charge the earth for their tickets. To help us do this, is to help keep the arts alive throughout the UK and Ireland.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that these are tough times for everyone, so if you can't donate, please spread the Hotbuckle word! You can 'like us' on facebook: www.facebook.com/hotbuckleproductions follow us on twitter @hotbuckleprods or come and see our shows! Tour dates can be found at www.hotbuckleproductions.co.uk

story:
My name is Becky Kalinowski and I am one of two student directors of SFSU's University Dance Theatre (UDT). UDT is an audition-based repertory ensemble currently under the direction of faculty members Cathleen McCarthy and Wendy Diamond. Every week we rehearse for six hours. In addition, each member participates in a minimum of eight hours of dance technique classes. Currently we are preparing for our annual showcase, which will feature choreography by Brenda Way (ODC/Dance), as well as works by SFSU faculty, alumnus, and students. 


Before that, UDT will be attending the American College Dance Association Baja Region Conference at CSU Long Beach. The ACDA conference is a unique opportunity for the company members to take classes, perform, and share ideas with dancers from other colleges. There are also scholarship opportunities for summer programs such as CSU Summer Arts and American Dance Festival. 

The 12 amazing dancers attending ACDA 2015:
Madelin Braun
Samantha Chin
Clarissa Dyas
Sarah Escobedo
Kassidy Friend
Rachel Hinde
Becky Kalinowski
Erica Lopez
Nicole Maimon
Adrienne Ulang
Janis Valencia
Nissa Vidal

The school has generously covered our registration fees ($1560) and hotels ($1710), but we need your help covering our transportation costs! The total amount for flights for our 12 company members is $1056. Our goal is to raise that amount over the course of the next two weeks. While we are already committed to going to the conference, it is a stretch financially since many of us are working students. This is a fixed funding campaign, meaning if we do not make our goal we will not receive any funds. On the other hand, if we are able to raise money beyond our goal it will be used to cover meals and local travel expenses. 

Please help us to achieve our goal by making a contribution. Anything helps! 

Thank you, and we hope to see you at our concert April 9-11. For more information, visit this link:
http://lca.sfsu.edu/events/2015-04-09-000000-20...

story:
Hi! My name is Maya Holcomb and I am 16 years old.  I currently dance at Johnson's Dance Studio (http://johnsonsdancestudio.com) with its dance company, Owensboro Dance Theatre (owensborodancetheatre.com), in Owensboro, Kentucky.  I have been dancing at this studio, studying ballet, jazz, tap, and contemporary/modern, for 12 years, but I would like to expand my horizon to bigger, more serious opportunities in ballet. Getting accepted into the Pittsburg Ballet School's Intensive Summer Program (www.pbt.org) has helped me to realize that my dream is a real possibility. But I need your help.


Goals
       I plan to continue my dance studies throughout and after college and hope to get accepted into a prestigious ballet company, but without money, it will be a struggle to achieve these goals. 
       This being the summer before my senior year, it will be my last opportunity to take advantage of experiences that will help me attain college scholarship money. 

       Although I have auditioned and have been accepted into other dance programs, I have not been able to take advantage of those opportunities due to my family's economic situation. However, it was a very big achievement for me to get accepted into Pittsburg Ballet School, and I don't think a lack of money should hold me back. 

       By learning from and performing with some of the most elite dance teachers and professional dancers of Pittsburg Ballet School, I will be taking a major step forward toward my dream.

      This opportunity will open so many doors to my future as a professional dancer and I am very hopeful and optimistic that it will happen.

What I Need 

       The total cost to attend the Pittsburg Ballet School's Summer Intensive Program is $5,700. This includes tuition, boarding & rooming, and travel.

       Although Pittsburg Ballet is my top choice, I have also been accepted into Louisville Ballet's Summer Intensive (www.louisvilleballet.org). Louisville's experience would be less prestigious, but also less expensive (a little more than half of what I need for Pittsburg). Therefore, if I am unable to raise enough money for Pittsburg, the funds will go toward my attendance at Louisville's Summer Intensive.


 Please Share and Contribute!

It's super easy to share my campaign via social media sites with Indigogo's share tools on the side of the page. Please share this with as many of your friends and family as possible, and I will be eternally grateful to any amount of contribution you are able to donate. Spread the word! And I thank you so much for your contribution.

story:
Short Summary

In 2013 we decide we wanted to write about a play about the fast growing epidemic of loneliness that would be relatable to an audience worldwide as well as being entertaining and thrilling.

So after a year of development Death Row Cowboy was born.  After two successful runs in Dublin’s Smock Alley Theatre in 2014, Death Row Cowboy has been invited to run in The Courtyard Theatre London.

What We Need

We are very excited at the prospect of bringing the show to London and reaching a wider audience. With the venue capacity double the size of Dublin we are looking to raise a small amount of money in order to market and promote our show around the city of London.  
We hope the money donated will provide us with flyers and posters and go a long way in promoting our show and getting the maximum exposure we need. 

The Impact

Our aim is to put on the best show possible, giving it every chance possible of a UK tour and raising our profile as important theatre makers.

When we return from London our plan is to tour our show around the country in site specific locations that has never been done before.

Thank You!

We have never received a cent of funding from any government bodies and would not have gotten to London if it were not for the hard work, support and encouragement from the people closest to us. Our Death Row Cowboy family has grown so much in the past year and we would like to thank each and every one of you who has worked with and supported us. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Our overall aim here is to raise the funds needed to print the materials neeeded to promote our show. We understand that not everyone can afford to donate - and that's fine!  There are many other ways which you could support us.

  • Facebook - JOIN and INVITE people to our event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/1566353066984885 
  • Also like Three Peas www.facebook.com/ThreePeasTheatreCompany and SHARE our posts.
  • Twitter - FOLLOW us www.twitter.com/3peastheatre and RETWEET our posts!
  • Share this Indiegogo page!!

Promo Video


Thany you for your continued support!

Andrew and Mark

story:
There once was a boy who loved a girl more than all the world. And the girl loved the boy back just as much. Like so many of us, they didn't know where they were going, but they were going there together. And they were never looking back…

Through a blend of online content, live performance, and film, THE TRIP adapts the myth of Orpheus & Eurydice for today. Our audience is directed in advance to a website where the lovers' relationship unfolds through a series of digital exchanges that they've posted for each other. They fall more and more in love until finally, unable to bear the distance any longer, they agree to meet in the flesh—actually, they agree to get married! Their wedding, and the rest of their story, is then staged in San Diego (December 14-21) as a party performance with live music, refreshments, and a damn fine wedding cake.

THE TRIP is growing in San Diego, and we are here to stay. Orpheus & Eurydice will be our fourth full production in just over a year. Last fall, with support from La Jolla Playhouse, we created an acclaimed, site-specific staging of Our Town for the inaugural Without Walls Festival. Then, forging a partnership with San Diego's NTC Foundation, we created two more site-specific works in a refurbished Navy barracks. We are excited that Orpheus & Eurydice will again push us into new territory, thanks to its interdisciplinary structure. The online parts of the project require that we enhance our internet capabilities. Also, without giving too much away, the live performance in San Diego will include an extended video sequence of several minutes. We will hire a cinematographer and editor, and secure the equipment that is necessary to create this sequence in a professional, beautiful way. Finally, we remain committed to building a consistent ensemble; gathering our artistic family in San Diego creates additional cost, but we believe the benefits to the work more than justify that cost. Once again, this TRIP production will prominently feature alumni of UCSD's Department of Theatre & Dance.

We wish we didn't have to come asking for your support, but we do. We would be grateful for anything you can give, and of course your donation is fully tax-deductible. In return, we promise to create a work of theater that is new, meaningful, and necessary. We'll give you an Orpheus & Eurydice to cheer for.

We cannot thank you enough for considering our campaign. Thank you, and thank you again,

Tom & Josh

(THE TRIP)

story:
Short Summary

Our mission as an organization, is to enrich the lives of the underprivileged and underserved citizens of New Smyrna beach through diverse cultural and educational experiences that leverage the community’s heritage and cultural distinctiveness and strengthen its economic development. 

We are in our second year of the Westside Cultural Arts Summer Dance Camp, a dance intensive for children ages 12-18, focused on African and modern dance techniques. The program is free to the participants. All participants come from underserved communities in the Volusia County area. 

In order to make this program happen, we need your financial support. Last year was an incredible success and children's lives were changed in the process. We expect that this year will be no exception. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are asking for $2,000 which does not cover the entire cost of the program.
  • Donations will go towards the salaries of the dance instructors, cost of transportation of the children to the facility, food expenses, and expenses associated with the culminating event performance (videographer, costumes, etc.).

The Impact

Westside Cultural Arts is a 501 (c) 3 organization and every dollar that you donate will go directly to program costs. Also your donations are tax-deductible. 

By donating, you are impacting the lives of teens by providing them with unique experiences that they would ordinarily not have access to. The arts has a way of changing lives, and you will be a part of helping to make this happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this link with friends.
  • Email bradley@westsidecenter.org to signup to volunteer!

story:
Renata Hinrichs is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Renata Hinrichs for RANDOM ACTS are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.


Hello,

My name is Renata Hinrichs, and I am excited to tell you that my new solo show, RANDOM ACTS, is on a roll!  After a successful night at the Emerging Artists Theater Festival last fall, I am thrilled to report that I have two new opportunities to perform the piece in 2014.  First, the Barrow Group has graciously invited me to use their beautiful studio theater for four workshop performances in June. After that, my show will be part of the internationally renowned United Solo Festival on Theater Row in October.  I have gathered a wonderful artistic team for this next phase of my journey, and I would be honored if you would join me.

RANDOM ACTS is about growing up on the South Side of Chicago in the late 1960’s as the daughter of a young Lutheran minister on the front lines of the civil rights movement.  The story is told from my perspective as a young child as I try to make sense of a chaotic and violent time.  One day, on my way to school, what appears to be a simple act of kindness allows me to see the world from a different perspective.  RANDOM ACTS is a tribute to that brave act of kindness. Though it is a deeply personal story, it has universal resonance.  

In order to take this show to the next level, I need your help. The budget for both productions is $8800. Here’s how it breaks down:

  • Rehearsal Space Rental/Festival Fees    $2,585

  • Creative Team    $3,800

  • Marketing & Publicity    $1,215  

  • Technical Costs    $1,200  

 TOTAL  $8,800


You'll receive cool perks for donating and RANDOM ACTS is sponsored by The Field, a non-profit arts organization, so your donations are 100% tax-deductible. (Please send me a message through Indiegogo if you would like for your donation to be tax-deductible). I would deeply appreciate any contribution you can make to support the next phase of this journey for RANDOM ACTS.

Writing and performing my own work has been the most challenging and rewarding experience I have had as an artist.  There is a message in this piece that is bigger than me.  As a writer/performer, I love exploring the complexities of the human condition and shining a light on some of the darker sides of our human behavior. If we can understand each other and feel what it’s like to stand in someone else’s shoes, we can find compassion for ourselves and others.  

I am so grateful for your support and encouragement, and I thank you from the bottom of my heart for any contribution you can make. Your support of this project is invaluable. I hope to see you in the theater.  


With love,

 Renata 


How else can I help?

Please help me spread the word to friends and family about this -- send emails and connect with me on Facebook andfollow me on Twitter. Please use the IndieGoGo Share Tools (see below) and let's get the word out to as many people as we can!

Thanks for your help!




http://thefield.org/sa/578795  the link to my online contribution page


Renata Hinrichs is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Renata Hinrichs are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Chicken Palace is a fresh, funny and fast paced one-act thriller , written by Lynette Linton, which explores perceptions, post-traumatic stress and stereotypes. The show has already undergone an exciting two-week Arts Council funded research and development process and small industry sharing at Theatre Royal Stratford East in July 2014.

We have taken on board all the feedback, refined the script and want to take it to the next level by creating a site specific performance making the show as much an experience from the outset as it is a performance. We want to use an existing restaurant and transform it into a chicken shop. Audience will be sat at tables and chairs around the action creating an inclusive and claustrophobic atmosphere. The audience will be offered chicken and chips, showed to their tables and when characters get locked in the shop, the audience will get locked in with them, sharing their experiences as they try and work out what is going on and how to escape the shop and each other.

Theatre Royal Stratford East has agreed to support the show, and is offering performance and rehearsal space - with a week’s run - marketing and box office support. We have a shop lined up. We have applied to Arts Council for funding and are waiting on their response. However, we need to raise just the final few thousand pounds in order to give the show and the audience the performance and final polish it deserves. "That's where you come in!" Please donate as little or as much as you like to help us to achieve our vision and be a part of Chicken Palace.

Feedback from our sharing: 

‘Congratulations on ‘Chicken Shop’ – as I said afterwards, I was impressed and think the blend of comedy and thriller tension with such recognisable London characters would appeal to a wide audience, including audiences that might usually not engage with a lot of theatre.’ James Hadley, Arts Council

‘I thought the show was great, very entertaining and very funny in parts. I thought it cleverly explored and challenged people’s prejudices and miss-held beliefs […]You need to take this further Lynette as it is a brilliant idea and deserves to be seen by many more people.’ Nick Shatford, Stoll Charity.

‘I had a fantastic time, the script you developed is in a very good stage, a great concept, strong themes, it is also funny, the dialogue is very convincing and with a little more polishing you will have a fantastic end product: a thought-provoking social satire meets comic thriller.’ Franko Figueiredo, Stonecrabs

We have over twenty feedback forms from members of the audience, which we have looked at with detail. The following shows the information we collated from the forms:

How did the show make you feel? (Feel free to tick more than one)

My view of the world had been changed

Moved – I wanted to cry 11%

Amazed  21%

Like laughing out loud 56%

Scared  4%

Thrilled 13%

Other: (Please specify)  4%

The storyline of the play 

Good 35%

Very good 65%

The relevance of the play to you

Neither good nor poor  9%

Good 52%

Very good  39%

The writing

Good  26%

Very good 74%

Words used to describe the show:

Powerful, funny, socially aware, tense, fast, relevant, thought provoking, tautly- plotted, witty, shocking, character driven, fresh, accessible, dark.

Quotes from feedback forms:

‘Relevant to East Londoners in particular- I’d love to see it on in an East London home, with locals appreciating the local references.’

 ‘Just build upon the existing brilliance.’ 


Find us on twitter @chicken_palace
story_txt:
Chicken Palace is a fresh, funny and fast paced one-act thriller , written by Lynette Linton, which explores perceptions, post-traumatic stress and stereotypes. The show has already undergone an exciting two-week Arts Council funded research and development process and small industry sharing at Theatre Royal Stratford East in July 2014. We have taken on board all the feedback, refined the script and want to take it to the next level by creating a site specific performance making the show as much an experience from the outset as it is a performance. We want to use an existing restaurant and transform it into a chicken shop. Audience will be sat at tables and chairs around the action creating an inclusive and claustrophobic atmosphere. The audience will be offered chicken and chips, showed to their tables and when characters get locked in the shop, the audience will get locked in with them, sharing their experiences as they try and work out what is going on and how to escape the shop and each other.Theatre Royal Stratford East has agreed to support the show, and is offering performance and rehearsal space - with a week’s run - marketing and box office support. We have a shop lined up. We have applied to Arts Council for funding and are waiting on their response. However, we need to raise just the final few thousand pounds in order to give the show and the audience the performance and final polish it deserves. "That's where you come in!" Please donate as little or as much as you like to help us to achieve our vision and be a part of Chicken Palace.Feedback from our sharing: 
‘Congratulations on ‘Chicken Shop’ – as I said
afterwards, I was impressed and think the blend of comedy and thriller tension
with such recognisable London characters would appeal to a wide audience,
including audiences that might usually not engage with a lot of theatre.’ James Hadley, Arts Council
‘I thought the show was great, very entertaining
and very funny in parts. I thought it cleverly explored and challenged people’s
prejudices and miss-held beliefs […]You need to take this further Lynette as it
is a brilliant idea and deserves to be seen by many more people.’ Nick
Shatford, Stoll Charity. 
‘I had a fantastic time, the script you
developed is in a very good stage, a great concept, strong themes, it is also
funny, the dialogue is very convincing and with a little more polishing you
will have a fantastic end product: a thought-provoking social satire meets
comic thriller.’ Franko Figueiredo, Stonecrabs

story:
The Show

We are very excited to be performing an evening-length show this December 18-20th at JACK in Brooklyn.  It is a big deal for us: professionally, creatively, financially and intestinally.  

Here is the description you will find on www.jackny.org

"The Vulgar Early Works is an evening-length concert by the dynamic Philly-based dance/performance duo Magda & Chelsea. The work presented at JACK is recombination and composting of everything the ladies have been up to since they met, and it is meant to lead to a conclusive transitional mind-blow of epic proportions. The material the artists are drawing from contains – as their pieces always do – self-love, subversive humor, feminist spit, and a sexual, angst-ridden cry against society. The genre? Oh, somewhere between TED Talk, modern dance, therapeutic seminar, stand-up comedy, and abstract theater." 

What We Need Help With

Anything you donate will go directly towards paying our sound designer: Mike Kiley.  He is going to give us an aural makeover, including:

1  making an original sonic score to uplift some of the awkwardly silent moments

2  training our voices to express our deepest things

3  improving some of the songs that some people have called "bad."  

Sounds ambitious, but Mike has a lot of experience so we think it will be fine.  See here: http://www.michaelkiley.com/

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute, but are interested in helping us we would love you to:

    • Invite your friends who live in Brooklyn: we want to fill that intimate house!
    • sign up for our email list and come see our shows: www.everybodygetinthecar.com

story:
Short Summary

Help support new, live theater by donating to the premiere production of Escape from Circle 8, a new play by award-winning playwright Sarah Lawrence. Production is scheduled at the historic Soho Playhouse in New York City. The storied Soho was one of the original venues for what is now known as Off-Broadway, and has served as the launching pad for such playwrights as Edward Albee, Sam Shepard, and Lanford Wilson.  The production Dream Team includes the electric Laura Siner in the lead role and Todd Conner as director. Conner's vision for the production includes commissioning original live music and dance. The ultimate goal for this Showcase Production is to serve as a launching pad to introduce this important work to audiences around the world. If the four-week run is successful, it will be moved to a bigger venue in New York with long-range plans for a U.S. tour.

Play Synopsis

Escape from Circle 8: Join us for cold cervezas, hot music, and even hotter clientele
For just four short weeks, the Huron Club @the Soho Playhouse will be transformed into El Nuevo Manhattan, the hottest cantina in Tijuana. As you descend the stairs, host Pedro greets you with cold cervezas and live music. Join us for a whirlwind tour of Tijuana’s nightlife along with drug dealers, prostitutes and other denizens of the dark. The Woman, your lovely guide, begins with a salacious tale of her own spectacular fall from grace. You see, all souls trapped in Circle 8 started with such a fall--unfortunate choices that guarantee them a ringside seat in The Inferno. The Woman has figured out an ingenious escape but needs your help to execute her plan.

What We Need & What You Get

Estimated revenue from ticket prices covers only about 25% of production costs. Our campaign hopes to cover rent and equipment needed for production ($7,000), a professional publicity campaign to fill the seats ($3,000), plus set design and props ($2,000). Ticket revenue should cover the cost of the actors, a composer, director, stage manager, and technical crew. Have you ever wanted to be an Executive Producer (EP) in New York? Our top donors get EP credit in the playbill along with tickets to opening weekend and a private reception with the cast and crew. All donors receive recognition in the playbill and on-line on the Facebook Fan Page. Special incentives for key donations include an autographed copy of the working script, souvenir I Love New York salt & pepper shakers as used in production, and tickets to the performance. Donations are tax deductible to the extent allowed by the IRS. See the perks list for details.

The Creative Team

Todd Conner, Director began his theatrical career at the Flat Rock Playhouse, State Theatre of North Carolina in a thorough and wide-ranging apprenticeship and later received his seminal training as a stage director at The Directors Company in New York under Brian Murray, Nagle Jackson, Stephen Porter, and Michael Parva.  His is a recipient of the Hendrix-Murphy Playwriting Award for his play The Grendelmas, which he first produced and directed in a concert reading in the main sanctuary of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and subsequently directed at Hendrix College.  His environmental adaptation and direction of The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe set box office records at the Dallas Theatre Center. Also in Dallas, he served as the Artistic Director of The Playwrights Project, proctoring the developing work of dozens of North Texas playwrights. His signature work, a solo translation, adaptation and performance (with his own harp compositions) of Ovid’s Metamorphoses, has pleased audiences from California to Minnesota to New York since he premiered it in Beverly Hills in 2000.  As an actor, he has performed in about 80 stage productions, and worked under the direction of such historical figures as Maria Ley-Piscator and Charles Marowitz. He acted in and scripted Miguel Rueda’s short film One Two Three…, which was an official selection at the Hollywood Film Festival and Showtime’s Latino Short Filmmakers Showcase.  He has made several short films, including Écorché, which features the acting of Laura Siner. He has completed an original feature length screenplay set in Sri Lanka, called Amnasia, and is currently seeking backing.  He is also a recipient of an LA Weekly Award, a member of SAG-AFTRA, the Independent Filmmakers Project, United States Masters Swimming, USA Swimming (coach member), and a proud graduate of Hendrix College.


Laura Siner (The Woman) most recently performed the role of Jessie in ‘night, Mother with the White Horse Theater Company.  Also appeared in White Horse’s production of Tennessee Williams’ In the Bar of a Tokyo Hotel.  As a longstanding member of the Oberon Theatre Ensemble, Laura has performed in American Rapture, MacBeth, The Merry Wives of Windsor, The Years, King Lear, The Three Sisters, The Taming of the Shrew, and Phaedre, among many others. Other favorite NYC credits include Hadrian’s Wall (NYC International Fringe Festival) and Days of Wine and Roses (Boomerang Theatre). Film work includes Écorché with Mayasphilms, directed by Todd Conner.  Member: AEA, SAG-AFTRA.  Graduate: Yale University. www.laurasiner.com

Sarah Lawrence, Playwright--Lawrence's first play Liberty won the Southern Playwright's Award and was produced in Jacksonville, AL as well as the Kennedy Center in Washington, DC. The King & Me, a satire about Elvis cult worship, won a national search for new comedies and was presented by the Pegasus Theatre. Her current play Escape from Circle 8  was originally workshopped in Dallas through the Playwrights Project at the Addison Theatre Centre and directed by Jonathan Moscone. She is also the author of five business books and numerous magazine articles that have been featured on Good Morning America, NBC News, the Washington Post, NPR, among many others. She currently attends the MFA program in Writing for Stage and Screen at the New Hampshire Institute of Arts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word! Use the Indiegogo share tools to let your friends know about this exciting opportunity to have a direct impact on producing live theater. Do you have friends that live in the New York City area? Let them know about the upcoming production. We'll post ticketing information closer to opening night.

And that's all there is to it.
