Other favorite NYC credits include Hadrian’s Wall (NYC International Fringe Festival) and Days of Wine and Roses (Boomerang Theatre). Film work includes Écorché with Mayasphilms, directed by Todd Conner.  Member: AEA, SAG-AFTRA.  Graduate: Yale University. www.laurasiner.com






Sarah Lawrence, Playwright--Lawrence's first play Liberty won the Southern Playwright's Award and was produced in Jacksonville, AL as well as the Kennedy Center in Washington, DC. The King & Me, a satire about Elvis cult worship, won a national search for new comedies and was presented by the Pegasus Theatre. Her current play Escape from Circle 8  was originally workshopped in Dallas through the Playwrights Project at the Addison Theatre Centre and directed by Jonathan Moscone. She is also the author of five business books and numerous magazine articles that have been featured on Good Morning America, NBC News, the Washington Post, NPR, among many others. She currently attends the MFA program in Writing for Stage and Screen at the New Hampshire Institute of Arts.

Other Ways You Can Help
Please help spread the word! Use the Indiegogo share tools to let your friends know about this exciting opportunity to have a direct impact on producing live theater. Do you have friends that live in the New York City area? Let them know about the upcoming production. We'll post ticketing information closer to opening night.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

We are Azusa Renaissance Theater--- a nonprofit that strives to bring theater programs to the community at little to no cost. Through months of story circling in Azusa, we've created a play that we hope will resonate not only with Azusans but with communities throughout. This is a play about students and the struggles they face as they navigate the complicated world of high school. They will be forced to look back on their 9th Grade Self and confront how the choices they made then will effect their future. We hope this story will spur dialogue between students, school officials, and parents and be the first step in bringing change to our schools.

Your help will make it possible to put on the best performance we can give. The funds we raise will be put towards space rental, costumes, and set design.

What We Need & What You Get

We hope to raise at least $1,000 to be used in setting up the play.

The funds will be used in the following ways:

  • $500 for renting a stage
  • $500 for technical costs (lighting, sound, set design, costumes etc.)

If you contribute, you will have the unique opportunity to experience the show in a more intimate way, including exclusive invites to special events, meet & greets, and dress rehearsals. This will ensure that you, as a contributor, have a first-hand look into the process of creating community theater.

The Impact

Not everyone gets to experience theater and that's why nonprofits like Azusa Renaissance Theater are so important. Your contributions will ensure that the citizens of Azusa have a link into the arts and the engaging world of theater. Story-telling, in all its forms, is the catalyst for dialogue and change. We hope that this play and the story we are telling will be the spark that lights the fire in our community--- and you are the kindling!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute funds? There is still a lot that goes into making a production happen. There are several ways you can get involved.

  • Audition - Ever wanted to be in a show? Come give it a go! We are looking for local talent and for new and veteran actors.
  • Marketing - Help us spread the word. Share our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.
  •  Production - We will be looking for people to help build sets, set up tech, usher our audience members, and more!
  • Come see the finished product in June! Follow us on Facebook to stay in the loop.

story:
This is our last day of our Indiegogo campaign.  If you can, please donate.  Every dollar helps bring our Love + Death experience to the Mountain View Mausoleum.  

BUY YOUR TICKETS NOW!
@ WWW.PLAYS411.COM/UNTETHERED


UNTETHERED

a new play by Julia Edwards

Directed by Jen Bloom

featuring 

Kevin McCorkle, Joy Osmanski, Gabrielle Rhodeen
Adam J. Smith & Eli Weinberg

Original Music by Steven Van Betten
Choreography by Stephanie Zaletel
Set Design by Murray Burn
Costume Design by Maddie Keller
Lighting Design by Brian Barraza
Stage Management by Kent Jenkins

a wacky love story
not the Hallmark variety
the messy, screwing up, begging for mercy kind


May 8 – June 7, 2015
@ The Mountain View Cemetery in Altadena


UNTETHERED is a project of the Pasadena Arts Council’s EMERGE Program. Donations to UNTETHERED  are tax deductible under Federal ID 95-2540759. 
The Pasadena Arts Council is a 501(c)(3) charitable organization.



WHY SHOULD YOU CARE ABOUT THIS PLAY?

Have you ever been in love?  Have you ever had a fight?  Have you ever thought: I’m done with this?  Or: I don’t know how we can get through this?  Committing to someone is the easy part.  It’s the “til death” part that gets messy. 
Untethered sparks a vital discussion about everyone’s issue—
how do we make love last? 


WHY AM I ASKING YOU FOR MONEY?

We are reaching out to family and friends to raise money to support:

·  live site-specific theatre in interesting off-beat venues
·  dedicated professional actors who love working on the stage
even though they make peanuts doing it
·  and relevant new plays by women playwrights. 
Did you know that on average fewer than 20%
of professionally produced plays are by women?


WHAT WILL WE DO WITH YOUR MONEY?

Julia Edwards' last playFamily Planning that was performed in residential homes around Los Angeles went on to win the LA Ovation Award for Best Production in a small theatre.  She's back for another site-specific experience.  The answer to "what will we do with your money?" is simple:

We will mount the world-premiere of UNTETHERED
in a stunning and unusual venue—
the mausoleum at Mountain View Cemetery in Altadena, CA. 


THIS PLAY NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT!

Now for some...theatre mathematics. 

The production budget is $25,000.  Miniscule compared to a film. 
But we’d need 500 friends giving $50 to get there. 
Uh.  That’s…a lot of friends. 
Or 250 friends giving $100 would work. 
Or 100 friends giving $250. 
A couple of $500 and $1000 friends sure would help. 
You get the picture.


HOW CAN YOU HELP TURN THE PAGES OF THIS PLAY INTO
A LOVE + DEATH EXPERIENCE AT THE MOUNTAIN VIEW CEMETERY?

1. Donate to the play.  
Every dollar helps!

2. Share our Indiegogo campaign with a friend.

3. Like our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/untetheredtheplay

4.  Learn more about the show on our website: www.untetheredtheplay.com

5. Come see the play in May!  Get your tickets NOW:  www.plays411.com/untethered


FROM THE PLAYWRIGHT

This play has been MANY years in the making.

I started writing this play when I was pregnant with my now-seven-year-old.  But the story started long before that.

This play was born in 2002 when I said I would marry my husband. 
I had nightmares.  Bad ones.  He died in lots of them.  Suddenly I had something to lose.  And from that moment I understood the delicate relationship between love and death.  They are tethered together, each giving forcing meaning on the other. 

This play was born in 1964 when my grandmother suddenly died
at the age of 54, leaving my grandfather alone to wander the world, writing haiku.  He wrote about how much he missed her.  And about regret.  About things he should have said to her when she was alive.  And worse, things he shouldn’t have said and could now never take back.  My grandfather’s haiku wove themselves into this play because it is also about time and inheritance.  About appreciating a moment and repeating our mistakes—and perhaps those that have come before us.

This play was born in 1959 when my parents were married. 
On their fiftieth wedding anniversary, I interviewed them.  How do you make a marriage last?, I asked.  My father, the mathematician, said: time and space.  Perhaps that’s why I wrote the fourth dimension into the play?  Because when we speak of love, concrete meaning eludes us.  Yet every time I write, I write about love.  I write about fear.  And I write about our messy attempts to find a home. As Ellie says in the play:

I refuse to let time mend my wounds
I refuse to move on
Don’t they understand?
Love is an emotion
It’s a place
You are my home
And I’m not leaving

Please help us turn these words into an experience.  
Into something that sparks a discussion:
What is love?   
And how do you make it last?

For more information about the show, the artists, and how to experience the play, visit UNTETHERED online:  www.untetheredtheplay.com

venues·  dedicated
professional actors who love working
on the stage even though they make peanuts doing it·  and relevant new plays by women playwrights.  Did you
know that on average fewer than 20% of
professionally produced plays are by women?

WHAT WILL WE DO WITH YOUR MONEY?
Julia Edwards' last playFamily Planning that was performed in residential homes around Los Angeles went on to win the LA Ovation Award for Best Production in a small theatre.  She's back for another site-specific experience.  The answer to "what will we do with your money?" is simple:
We will mount the world-premiere of UNTETHEREDin a stunning and unusual venue—the mausoleum at Mountain View Cemetery in Altadena, CA. 

THIS PLAY NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT!
Now for some...theatre mathematics.  
The production budget is $25,000. 
Miniscule compared to a film.  But
we’d need 500 friends giving $50 to get there. 
Uh.  That’s…a lot of friends.  Or 250 friends giving $100 would work.  Or 100 friends giving $250.  A couple of $500 and $1000 friends sure would
help.  You get the picture.

HOW CAN YOU HELP TURN THE PAGES OF THIS PLAY INTO A LOVE + DEATH EXPERIENCE AT THE MOUNTAIN VIEW CEMETERY?
1. Donate to the play.  Every dollar helps!
2. Share our Indiegogo campaign with a friend.
3. Like our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/untetheredtheplay
4.  Learn more about the show on our website: www.untetheredtheplay.com
5. Come see the play in May!  Get your tickets NOW:  www.plays411.com/untethered



FROM THE PLAYWRIGHT


This play has been MANY years in the making.
I started writing this play when I was pregnant with my
now-seven-year-old.  But the story started long before that.
This play was born in 2002 when I said I would marry my
husband.  I had nightmares.  Bad ones. 
He died in lots of them.  Suddenly
I had something to lose.  And from that
moment I understood the delicate relationship between love and death.  They are tethered together, each giving
forcing meaning on the other.  
This play was born in 1964 when my grandmother suddenly died
at the age of 54, leaving my grandfather alone to wander the world, writing
haiku.  He wrote about how much he missed
her.  And about regret.  About things he should have said to her when
she was alive.  And worse, things he
shouldn’t have said and could now never take back.  My grandfather’s haiku wove themselves
into this play because it is also about time and inheritance.  About appreciating a moment and repeating our
mistakes—and perhaps those that have come before us.
This play was born in 1959 when my parents were
married.  On their fiftieth wedding
anniversary, I interviewed them.  How do
you make a marriage last?, I asked.  My father, the mathematician,
said: time and space.  Perhaps that’s why
I wrote the fourth dimension into the play? 
Because when we speak of love, concrete meaning eludes us.  Yet every time I write, I write about love.  I write about fear.  And I write about our messy attempts to find
a home. As Ellie says in the play:
I refuse to let time
mend my woundsI refuse to move onDon’t they
understand?Love is an emotionIt’s a placeYou are my homeAnd I’m not leaving
Please help us turn these words
into an experience.  Into something that sparks a discussion:What is love?   And how do you
make it last?

For more information about the show, the artists, and how to experience the play, visit UNTETHERED online:  www.untetheredtheplay.com

story:
So here's the deal...

Clay von Carlowitz and I (Asta Paredes) are two classically trained NYC based actors who met and fell in love with not only each other but working together as actors while making a horror-scifi-comedy feature film back in the summer of 2012 ("Return to Nuke 'em High Vol.1 & 2"). Since then, we have steadily built a network of filmmaking friends in the horror and independent film community, and on the strength of our work, we have been offered a variety of projects which either fell apart or we simply turned down due to creative differences/time constraints. Though we have been fortunate enough to work on a variety of projects including short films, web series, and pre-produciton on upcoming features, something is missing. Over time, both of us began to feel an overwhelming need to go back to our roots in acting. After much soul searching and some hard living, we came to the realization that in order to be offered more compelling work, we needed a showcase of sorts for the people who could help bring our career to the next level (agents, fellow actors, and filmmakers). 

We decided that showcase would be "Danny & the Deep Blue Sea" by John Patrick Shanley. We chose this story in particular because we, as two fiercely independent New Yorkers who once thought we were alone, somehow found in each other a soulmate. In the emotionally raw scenario cultivated by Shanley, this is also the story of Danny & Roberta.

For two nights this summer, we would like to bring this story to life. We will do this as a means of catharsis for us as a couple, as an exercise to re-engage our acting muscles, and as a platform to showcase our talent. Our hope is to signify to the artistic community of New York that we seek - and are capable of - the most challenging, provocative work out there.

Having attained permission from the playwright, we are currently hard at work on rehearsals and we are shopping for theater spaces. With your help, we can make this show happen and take the next big step in our lives and our career! 

 

THE SHOW...

(logo design by Lauren Hom)


The Cast

Clay von Carlowitz as DANNY

The second oldest of nine children, Clay von Carlowitz was born in Euclid, OH, on January 4th, 1987. Raised in a conservative Midwestern environment east of Cleveland, the daydreaming von Carlowitz decided early on to trade conformity for mimicry, the consequence of which was the development of his skills as an actor, writer and director. Following his studies at Kenyon College and the University of Exeter, the classically-trained actor wrote, directed and starred in his first feature film, supernatural thriller "The House in the Woods." He then spent a year doing odd jobs, background work and acting classes in LA before ultimately settling in New York City, where he initially pursued theatre. After a series of false starts, von Carlowitz eventually fell in with the indie film scene through his acclaimed comedic performance as the sexually-frustrated social outcast Eugene in Troma Entertainment's subversive scifi-comedy "Return to Nuke 'Em High Vol. 1 & 2." He is ecstatic to be returning to the stage in what will be his first dramatic leading role since starring in David Mamet's "Oleanna" his senior year at Kenyon.

Asta Paredes as ROBERTA

Asta Paredes was born in Beaumont, Texas.  Due to her father's work she was also raised in Holland and Spain before settling back in Texas; the frequently-displaced Paredes had to learn early on how to adapt quickly. Toughened by the Southwest and cultured by Europe, she channeled her aggression into the theatre and found grace through ballet, piano & even some martial arts-- ultimately she landed a scholarship at the University of Minnesota's prestigious BFA Actor Training Program at the Guthrie Theater. Four years later she was doing plays in New York City, but after some study with improv comedy at UCB, she found herself starring in the fun Funny or Die video, 'Battleship Pitch Meeting' made by her friend, Dave Herman. Emboldened by the positive reception to her on-camera presence and skills as a comedic actress, the ever-impulsive Paredes auditioned for Troma's subversive scifi-horror-comedy event film 'Return to Nuke 'Em High: Volume 1 & 2.' After a month-long call back process, the tough-as-nails actress won the lead role of Chrissy. Universally acclaimed for her performance as the disenchanted, sexually-confused high school senior, Paredes has become a cult icon overnight. Already attached to several independent feature films, Asta Paredes continues to carve a path through the industry and is excited to be going back to her roots in theatre with this show. (Coincidentally "Danny & the Deep Blue Sea" was her first scene study in college so it has a sentimental meaning to her to go back.)


Our Director:

 Meg Grujon

Meg Grujon was born in Portland, Oregon and raised by two South African parents who knew next to nothing about theatre, yet found herself drawn to the arts anyway. By seven years old, she was convinced she would become a pop singer after singing “My Heart Will Go On” at her third grade talent show and spent the next ten years studying with several voice teachers who introduced her to musical theatre. Finding that her love for performing came from storytelling, she would pursue a (slightly) more realistic career as an actor and obtain her B.A. in Theatre Performance at Marymount Manhattan College. It was in college she found an additional love for directing, and has continued to direct in the city since graduating in May 2012. After working on several one-act plays, she directed her first full-length play, FIVE WOMEN WEARING THE SAME DRESS with TRG Productions last Spring. In pursuit of finding an artistic home to further develop her craft in acting and directing, she joined the Seeing Place Theater company in the Fall and assistant-directed their last production of TWO ROOMS by Lee Blessing which opened in March with excellent reviews. She will be working as a dramaturg on their next show, THE LARAMIE PROJECT, opening this June. Later in the summer, she will be directing a new post-apocalyptic zombie play titled RAISE ME UP written by Charlie Biscotto for a three-week run in September. She is so thrilled to be involved in this production of DANNY AND THE DEEP BLUE SEA and to be working with such dedicated and passionate actors.

 

The Story

"The setting is a rundown bar in the Bronx, where two of society's rejects, Danny and Roberta, strike up a halting conversation over their beer. He is a brooding, self-loathing young man who resorts more to violence than reason; she is a divorced, guilt-ridden young woman whose troubled teenage son is now being cared for by her parents. Danny, whose fellow truck drivers call him "the animal," seems incapable of tender emotion, while Roberta, who is still haunted by the memory of an ugly sexual incident involving her father, is distrustful of men in general. And yet, as their initial reserve begins to melt, and they decide to spend the night together, the possibility of a genuine and meaningful relationship begins to emerge—the first for both of them. In the end there are no facile, easy answers, but thanks to the playwright's skill and compassion, both characters are able to probe within themselves to find an exorcism and forgiveness that, while painfully achieved, offers the hope of a future touched, at last, with more than the bitterness and loneliness that had been their lot before their fateful meeting"

--Dramatists Play Services Inc.


The Playwright

JOHN PATRICK SHANLEY


John Patrick Shanley was born on October 3rd, 1950, in the Bronx, New York City. His mother was a telephone operator and his father was a meat-packer. Growing up in what was considered a "rough neighborhood," Shanley had trouble adhering to the restrictions of Catholic curriculum, and was kicked out of both kindergarten and high school. After an unsuccessful freshman year at NYU, he was placed on academic probation and subsequently enlisted in the United States Marine Corps, serving a stateside post during the Vietnam War. Upon completion of military service, the newly-disciplined, somewhat self-destructive Shanley channeled his ideas into a novel and burned it before returning to NYU. A few years later, he was valedictorian. Shanley went on to become a playwright, gaining major notice from the 1984 Off-Broadway production of 'Danny and the Deep Blue Sea,' which starred a young John Turturro as Danny. Though critical and commercial success of the similarly-themed 'Moonstruck' led to a more lucrative career as a screenwriter, Shanley continued penning plays, winning the Pulitzer Prize (among many other accolades) for 'Doubt' in 2005, and much more acclaim and notoriety from his 2008 film adaptation with Meryl Streep and Phillip Seymour Hoffman. Known as the 'Bard of the Bronx,' Shanley resides in New York City and continues to write for film and theatre.



'Danny & the Deep Blue Sea' dedication:

"This play is dedicated to everyone in the Bronx who punched me or kissed me, and to everyone whom I punched or kissed."


What's different in THIS production?


The APACHE DANCE!

(Photo by Brooke DiDonato Photography)

John Patrick Shanley defines an ‘Apache Dance’ as:

A violent dance for two people, originated by the Parisian Apaches. Parisian Apaches are gangsters or ruffians.

For THIS production, because of trust and insanity, we are going to use this dance style as a prologue and a means of transition for Danny & Roberta.


 


…as you can see practice will be important!




Here’s the money breakdown…    

    $240 Rights to perform up to 3 nights

    $800/ 2 nights space rental (dress rehearsal included)

    $200/ costume & props (donation optional-- list below)

    $500 Consult Helpers (Director, Dance Instructors, Dialect Coaches)

    $350 Prints/advertising/mailings (programs/postcards/headshots)

    $200 incentives (to make even and send you the goods!)

    $100 research (travel, dance class, books, movies, etc)

    $200 rehearsal costs (space, food, scripts, etc)

    $400/ talent (working hard to make some art!)

     

    TOTAL rounds out to $3,000 for an ideal show.

     

    Cool Perks!

    From this t-shirt design ( at $50 and up) to a night out on the town with us & so much more…check out our incentives on the right---->

     

    What happens if we don’t reach our goal?

    If we don't reach our goal we will take what we have and have to either start another campaign down the line and/or postpone the show. Otherwise see if we can at the very least afford ONE Night and make it count

story:
All the money received will help pay for part of the production of DEPLOYED at the New York Musical Theatre Festival: 13 actors, 5 musicians, rehearsal space rental, costumes, set, etc. 

What is DEPLOYED about?

Needing to prove she’s a worthy soldier and at war with her inner demons, Emily sabotages her relationship with Lieutenant Anthony Wilkes before she’s deployed to Iraq. Assigned to train Iraqi women, she feuds with her interpreter Laila. Just when the lovers finally reunite and Laila and Emily’s quarrel has evolved into a deep friendship, a secret from the past comes back to wreak its revenge. They cannot forget...but can they forgive?

DEPLOYED is about the struggle we all face at some point in our lives -- learning to forgive and to let go of our past in order to move on. Through the relationship between Emily and Anthony, and the friendship between EMILY and LAILA, we also discover that beyond the horrors of war, we are all the same.  No matter where we come from, we are all only human.

Why should you help?

Deployed The Musical presents a message of forgiveness and tolerance. We are all the same! 

The New York Musical Theatre Festival offers a unique opportunity to present Deployed's message to the public in the highest possible professional setting. Deployed was given this chance! 

The objective of $10 000 represents a small part of the production cost which is $70 000. If we can raise $30 000, even better!

- $10 pays to print the script and music for one actor

- $25 pays for an hour of rehearsal 

- $500 pays to print our program 

- $1000 pays for our set

- $1000 pays for our costumes

- $5000 pays for the theatre rental

- (…)

Our cast will rehearse for weeks to make you laugh and maybe cry, and for all their hard work, they deserve a packed house! If you can't make it to New York to see Deployed, please help by giving a dollar in exchange for a song from the show. And  please, share this link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter...

Pour nos amis du Québec qui ne pourront se déplacer pour voir ''Deployed'' à New York, vous pouvez aider à la production en donnant $1 ou $5  et, en invitant vos amis sur Facebook et Twitter à faire de même.    

LULLABY from Deployed The Musical

SHE LOVED from Deployed The Musical

story:
Who am I?

"The Greatest Expression of Rebellion is Joy."

I'm 'Madame' Onça O'Leary, a professional bellydancer and career entertainer, visual artist, author, event producer, and mom working out of the Southeastern US. If you are reading this, you probably know that as a performer, my reputation is built on bringing theatricality, comedy, and emotional depth to the dance. I’ve taught thousands of dancers in the US and Europe, and produced hundreds of dance events, including fifteen weekend-long festivals for both the burlesque and bellydance communities. In these capacities, I am an economic engine for other artists and small businesses, and an activist for my students’ positive self-worth.

What am I doing, and why now?

I am finally codifying aspects of my work into two, Onça-style, instructional DVDs; one on fundamentals of bellydance, and the other on one of my signature props, the fan. 

Why now? Quite frankly, It’s time! I LOVE teaching deep decadent dance technique AND cultivating positive a radical sense of self-image in my students. There’s a demand for instructional materials that allow the home practitioner to cultivate both dance fundamentals and props at their own pace. I’ve been asked many times to create DVDs for my students and fans, sharing my own philosophy of empowerment, self-acceptance and humor, allowing us to continue to work together when that glorious workshop weekend is over. And, most importantly, our filming support team is nearly perfect: We just need you.

Now is the time to film these DVDs, no matter what, but it can happen much sooner with YOUR support. Bellydance offers so many people a path to strength, healing, levity, and a deep sensitivity to world culture… and our society desperately needs all that. Please consider becoming a supporter, get cool stuff, and help us fill the world with rebellious joy!

If you want to hear and see more of what we have in mind, watch the video link!

How can you help, what do we need, and what do you get?

Donate to this campaign! And if you want to support this project yet can't donate, please spread the word about our campaign via email, on Facebook, anywhere you can. Every bit helps!

A project this ambitious means renting space, creating product, and paying a fair rate to the film and support team. With the $3500 we seek to raise, we can see that the crew gets their due, and get this project done in time for the totally delicious DVD release party in Richmond, VA, on April 13, 2014!

For you, we've dished up a series of perks unique to our team: Kissy Kissy photos, signed dvds, VIP event passes, and more. Supporting our efforts gets you involved in an active, joyful community, does concrete good in the world, and gets you a bunch of cool stuff too. On behalf of everybody involved with this project, thank you!


(And special thanks to both Carmine Guida, whose music appears in this video, and to Hatton Cross Steampunk, whose amazing steampunk tank also appears in this video.)
story_txt: Who am I?"The Greatest Expression of Rebellion is Joy."I'm 'Madame' Onça O'Leary, a professional bellydancer and career entertainer, visual artist, author, event producer, and mom working out of the Southeastern US. If you are reading this, you probably know that as a performer, my reputation is built on bringing theatricality, comedy, and emotional depth to the dance. I’ve taught thousands of dancers in the US and Europe, and produced hundreds of dance events, including fifteen weekend-long festivals for both the burlesque and bellydance communities. In these capacities, I am an economic engine for other artists and small businesses, and an activist for my students’ positive self-worth.What am I doing, and why now?I am finally codifying aspects of my work into two, Onça-style, instructional DVDs; one on fundamentals of bellydance, and the other on one of my signature props, the fan. Why now? Quite frankly, It’s time! I LOVE teaching deep decadent dance technique AND cultivating positive a radical sense of self-image in my students. There’s a demand for instructional materials that allow the home practitioner to cultivate both dance fundamentals and props at their own pace. I’ve been asked many times to create DVDs for my students and fans, sharing my own philosophy of empowerment, self-acceptance and humor, allowing us to continue to work together when that glorious workshop weekend is over. And, most importantly, our filming support team is nearly perfect: We just need you.Now is the time to film these DVDs, no matter what, but it can happen much sooner with YOUR support. Bellydance offers so many people a path to strength, healing, levity, and a deep sensitivity to world culture… and our society desperately needs all that. Please consider becoming a supporter, get cool stuff, and help us fill the world with rebellious joy!If you want to hear and see more of what we have in mind, watch the video link!How can you help, what do we need, and what do you get?Donate to this campaign! And if you want to support this project yet can't donate, please spread the word about our campaign via email, on Facebook, anywhere you can. Every bit helps!A project this ambitious means renting space, creating product, and paying a fair rate to the film and support team. With the $3500 we seek to raise, we can see that the crew gets their due, and get this project done in time for the totally delicious DVD release party in Richmond, VA, on April 13, 2014!For you, we've dished up a series of perks unique to our team: Kissy Kissy photos, signed dvds, VIP event passes, and more. Supporting our efforts gets you involved in an active, joyful community, does concrete good in the world, and gets you a bunch of cool stuff too. On behalf of everybody involved with this project, thank you!(And special thanks to both Carmine Guida, whose music appears in this video, and to Hatton Cross Steampunk, whose amazing steampunk tank also appears in this video.)

story:
Who? What? Why?


  • The All Stories Theater Company is a group of theater artists from the Boston area who are dedicated to sharing a diverse array of exciting and compelling stories with our audiences.
  • Our play, "The Van Meder Trust," a multi-generational, multi-racial family drama, has been accepted to FringeNYC 2014! Woohoo! We're looking for help defraying the costs.
  • NYCFringe offers a fantastic opportunity! The festival gets 75,000 visitors a year, including theater professionals, other artists and theater fans from around the world. We can't wait to mix and mingle with them and share "The Van Meder Trust" with as many of them as possible. This play means a lot to us; we've been working on it off and on for over a year. We believe in its themes of hope, forgiveness and perseverance and always have a good time bringing it to life.  In NYC, we know we will hear some great stories, too, and learn a lot. This is a big step forward for our group and our play, and we are excited to see who will sponsor us and come along on the journey!

What We Need....

FringeNYC allows low-budget, independent theater groups like ours to perform in The Big Apple on the cheap. But inexpensive for New York is not necessarily inexpensive in the general sense. Donations made from this campaign will go to:

  • Fringe Festival mandatory fees: $700 registration, $100 venue director gratuity, a little over a hundred dollars for insurance
  • Transportation costs to get our Massachusetts cast and crew to NYC and around the city when we get there; food and other living expenses for the approx. one week the 10-12 of us will be in the city.
  • Funding for props, printing, publicity/marketing, and other production-related expenses.

The Impact

We formed The All Stories Theater Company in 2013 because we believe, as artists, we are responsible for getting our stories to audiences. And that often means taking initiative and self-producing. We cite as our role models The Serpent Players, a multi-racial theater company which performed in 1960s apartheid South Africa - at great personal risk, facing death threats and imprisonment.  They told their stories no matter what. So, what excuse do we have to not do our jobs, too?  Certainly not money. Though, often, we operate on a small budget and rely, as you can see on donations from generous sponsors who put some of their disposable income into our projects.

If you can be one of those generous donors, we thank you in advance. And please know, no amount is too small! If can't donate funds, please do share this link with your network. And most of all, we hope you will come see us in the city this August! (Stay tuned for specific dates!)

story:
ASYLUM Theatre needs costumes, make up and a graphic designer!

Holiday in my Head is a collection of eight whimsical short plays by award-winning playwright & director Dean Lundquist.  It will be ASYLUM Theatre's inaugural production.  It features plays that have to do with or at least mention "Christmas."  It features an all-star ensemble cast of amazing actors including, Chio Su-Ping, Tim Garner, Paul Lucas, Andrew Mowatt, Seong Hui Xuan and Zee Wong.  

The show features the following plays:

  • I Can Tell Your Handbag is Fake - Three women board a train and discover they all have the same designer handbag.
  • Coulrophobia (The Fear of Clowns) - Two criminals hide from the law by disguising themselves as circus clowns.  
  • Finger Food - A fork and spoon fear for their lives in a world dominated by finger food.
  • Holiday with Mr. K - A bankrupt real estate broker meets a strange man claiming to be a legendary Christmas character.
  • Faith in the Super Bowl - Faith wants her husband to go to church on Sunday, but he finds spiritual enlightenment in NFL football and a bowl of cereal.
  • The Naughty List - Barry the Christmas elf has an ethical dilemma that will force him to compromise his principles or leave the North Pole forever.
  • Holy Toast - When Mary Catherine sees a religious icon in her grilled cheese sandwich, she calls Father Christmas, her somewhat wayward priest, for spiritual advice.
  • The Joy of Solitude - Charlie Sumac inadvertently locks himself in his apartment and makes an absurd effort to escape.


    • ASYLUM Theatre is a non-profit organization in Singapore made up of an international group of theatre artists who are passionate about bringing high quality theatre to the masses.  We relish the opportunity to create new works for the stage as well as revivals of contemporary classics and re-imaginings of classical masterpieces.  

    We rely on ticket sales, grants, sponsorship and generous donations from people just like you who are excited about great theatre.

    We are attempting to raise enough funds to cover the cost of purchasing costumes, theatrical make up, a graphic designer and the shipping costs to Singapore.  

    This is our first campaign with Indiegogo, but with your help we are hoping it and our production of "Holiday in my Head" will be a great success!

    What We Need & What You Get

    • Costumes: $2000 (so we aren't nekkid)
    • Make up: $500 (beards, wigs, etc.)
    • Graphic Designer: $500 (to design posters and advertising)
    • Shipping and Handling: $500 (to send it to us)
    Rewards for your contribution range from social media shout outs, acknowledgement in our programs, posters autographed by the cast, and even incorporating your name into the performance!
    If we don't reach our goal, we will have to perform completely naked.  This will likely mean that the whole theatre company will end up in jail and receive numerous lashings of the cane for indecent exposure.   Oh, and our graphic designer will likely become homeless and end up on the street carrying a (well designed) cardboard sign reading "will photoshop for food."

    The Impact

    With your contribution, we are hoping to put on the best collection of short plays the island nation of Singapore has ever seen. This production will not only lay the groundwork for our 2015 season, we may even come to a town near you. 

    • This is an incredibly fun and entertaining show that will make you laugh, make you cry and make you long for Christmas no matter what time of year.
    • It's a family-friendly show with something for everyone.
    • It will be performed by an incredible group of award-winning theatre artists hungry to perform. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't send money, please help spread the word:

      • Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/asylumtheatresingapore
      • Twitter: https://twitter.com/AsylumTheatreSG
      • Homepage: http://www.asylum-theatre.com

story:
The Project:

Hold Me Tight is inspired by the true-crime story Christine and Lea Papin, sisters, maids and supposedly lovers.  On the evening of February 2nd, 1933, the two massacred their employer, Madame Lancelin, and her daughter, Genevieve, gouging out their eyes, smashing their skulls, and beating the two women to an unrecognizable pulp.

Hold Me Tight focuses on the intense intimacy between the sisters, and how that intimacy led to such extreme violence. 

This original devised theatre-dance production is the thesis project of Naomi Bennett, MFA candidate in Television, Film and Theatre at California State University, Los Angeles. 

As an ensemble, we have worked for the past nine months using dance, spoken word, soundscaping, and integrated media to explore the supposed incestuous relationship of the sisters, their ostracization, isolation, and how we as performers can relate to their Delire a Deux.  Our explorations have unearthed issues of class, gender, sexuality, and the basic human need for physical touch.

What We Need

There are many expense that go into mounting a theatrical production, but the main goal of this fundraiser is to make sure the cast and crew get paid!

The first $2,000 will go to paying the cast and crew for their amazingly hard work!

What You Get

Besides the wonderful feeling of knowing you helped an artist get paid for doing art, we have a couple small tokens of our appreciation for you:
  • FREE Tickets to our show!!! (October 20-22, 2014 at CSULA)
  • Signed Photo from the Ensemble
  • DVD of our Final Performance
  • A Night Out Drinking with Us!  And we'll buy the first round!
All funds raised up to $2,000 will go directly to the Cast and Crew.  Any amount over that will help to defray expenses such as publicity, set design, props, and media equipment rental.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Every dollar counts!  

    If you just can't donate right now, please consider sharing this campaign, you can help spread the word on your:

    • Facebook
    • Twitter
    • Personal Blog
    • Anywhere else you can think of!

    Thank you!

    Naomi Bennett, MFA candidate, Television, Film and Theatre, California State University, Los Angeles

story:
My story

I've been involved in theater since the ripe age of 10, and if I'm completely honest with you, it's all I ever wanted to do. I was a shy kid (those in my family might laugh at this, but it's true) and acting has always been a way for me to express myself. As I've grown up my passion has only grown. My need to entertain, to share a story, to give back to the world that's given me so much.

After graduating from the University of Oregon in 2012 I moved to the Bay Area. Some of you may have seen me in readings at the famed Exit Theatre  in San Francisco, at the Actor's Ensemble of Berkeley, or in my recent 3-woman performance of The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged) at the Contra Costa Civic Theatre. 

My time here has been amazing, but it's become clear to me that I still have a lot to learn in order to reach my full potential. In May I was blessed to be accepted to the Portland Actors Conservatory as a member of their professional actor training program.

As a student at PAC I will learn from some of the best in the northwest, expand my collaborative skills, and learn new practices and techniques, as well as honing my current skill set. I'll be able to work with local professionals as well as my peers in my journey to become a more well rounded and experienced actor - and person.

Attending PAC is going to be the opportunity of a lifetime, and I would love for you to be part of that.


Now for the hard part

FAFSA will only cover part of my tuition. Additionally, the program is 9-5 Monday-Friday,  September - May, so it's unlikely I'll be able to work during my time at school. My goal is to raise enough funds to cover the rest of my tuition and help with housing costs (so I don't have to live in the theater basement like the Phantom of the Opera), plus cover the fees from indiegogo. Every dollar helps!


But how can I ever repay you?

I know times are hard. We all have a million causes we'd love to support and help out. Please know your support means so much to me. The encouragement I have received over the past years from friends, family, coworkers (heck, even customers at work!) has meant the world to me. If you are somehow able to contribute in any way, I will be eternally grateful! Any donation will receive a personalized thank you, and any other goodies I can send your way.


Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions about the program or my fundraising goals. And of course feel free to share my project with your friends!

story:
Hello there, my name is Jessica Gilmore and I am a professionally trained dancer from Miami, Fl. I have my BFA in modern dance performance from the University of South Florida. I am a full time teacher. I teach pole dancing and also contemporary/modern dance. 

Contemporary Vertical Dance/ contempole is an intermingling of the art and beauty of modern/contemporary dance and the art and beauty of pole dancing. Right now pole dancing is intriguing to people, it is becoming mainstream and I would like to give people another aspect of the art. With this new style of dance my goal is to use our movements to inspire our story/dance we create and using our story to create new movements. I would like for people to notice the difficulty of the tricks less and more leaving more interested in the intricacy of the movements on and off the pole. 

 I am very passionate about my craft and when I began learning pole I knew I wanted to incorporate it with my foundation of dance. I want people to see the grace and beauty that comes with pole while incorporating modern techniques and ideas. Using the pole as a prop and less as a sexual innuendo. I want to take away the stigma of the pole and make into something respectable, meaningful and beautiful. 

I would like to raise money so that I can get things started. I currently work/ run a pole dancing studio in Oakland,Ca and don't have the money to bring dancers on in the capacity in which I want. I need funding for that. I want to be able to start off paying my dancers for rehearsals and also would like to start investing in a full night production at a local theatre.

story:
Who Was Aphra Behn?

Playwright, spy, swordswoman (probably?), Aphra Behn's life is an enigma.  She was a 17th century British playwright and the first woman to make her living as a writer, we know that; she was a spy in Flanders, we know that, too.  "Aphra" probably wasn't her first name, "Behn" might not have been her last name, we don't know what it really was at all.

This play is about her life, composed partly of truths but mostly of lies, and about what it means to create your own identity, to build a story for yourself as a person in general but as a woman in particular, and as a woman in a time when the stories available out of which to build your life were vastly limited.  It's a play written for six women, to start cracking open the theater in America, and start making all kinds of roles available where they once weren't -- the swordsmen and the rakes and the horrible dirty bastards.

Empress of the Moon premiered here in Philadelphia, and even made a little history when it was the first Philadelphia world premier that was also livecast on the internet (generously hosted at io9.com).  With the help of Cara Blouin and Forearmed Productions, we're going to bring it to the Capital Fringe Festival in Washington, DC this July.

What We Need

Our primary need is travel expenses.  We've got a great group of dedicated actresses who've generously offered to work for nothing more than a share of the box, but we need to bring them back and forth from Philadelphia to DC over the course of three weeks, so we're trying to raise $2500 to cover the costs of putting everyone up.  If we hit $2500, we'll receive about $2300; we're estimating that we'll keep about $100-$150 in reserve to cover the costs of the perks that we're offering.  

Anything we get in excess of $2500 will be used to recoup the administrative expenses for the show (about $1100); after that, everything remaining will be divided evenly between the cast and crew, to be added to their box office share.

Why You Should Help

It's not easy putting up a show in this world, and it's especially not easy putting up one that gives so many opportunities to actresses, and it's even more especially not easy putting up one of those that also helps to raise the profile of one of the most important women in the history of literature -- your donation will help all THREE of those things, bringing the story of Britain's most important woman playwright who was also a spy to an ever-increasing audience.

We can do this; we're putting together a top-notch, low-budget production, we've got great actors and a fantastic director.  We've got almost everything we need, except for that one little push that you can give us.  

    If You Can't Donate

    Then tell your friends!  Share Aphra's story; even if THEY can't donate, maybe one day Empress of the Moon will play in their town or city or village or local agrarian commune, and they'll buy a ticket!
story_txt: Who Was Aphra Behn?Playwright, spy, swordswoman (probably?), Aphra Behn's life is an enigma.  She was a 17th century British playwright and the first woman to make her living as a writer, we know that; she was a spy in Flanders, we know that, too.  "Aphra" probably wasn't her first name, "Behn" might not have been her last name, we don't know what it really was at all.This play is about her life, composed partly of truths but mostly of lies, and about what it means to create your own identity, to build a story for yourself as a person in general but as a woman in particular, and as a woman in a time when the stories available out of which to build your life were vastly limited.  It's a play written for six women, to start cracking open the theater in America, and start making all kinds of roles available where they once weren't -- the swordsmen and the rakes and the horrible dirty bastards.Empress of the Moon premiered here in Philadelphia, and even made a little history when it was the first Philadelphia world premier that was also livecast on the internet (generously hosted at io9.com).  With the help of Cara Blouin and Forearmed Productions, we're going to bring it to the Capital Fringe Festival in Washington, DC this July.   What We NeedOur primary need is travel expenses.  We've got a great group of dedicated actresses who've generously offered to work for nothing more than a share of the box, but we need to bring them back and forth from Philadelphia to DC over the course of three weeks, so we're trying to raise $2500 to cover the costs of putting everyone up.  If we hit $2500, we'll receive about $2300; we're estimating that we'll keep about $100-$150 in reserve to cover the costs of the perks that we're offering.  Anything we get in excess of $2500 will be used to recoup the administrative expenses for the show (about $1100); after that, everything remaining will be divided evenly between the cast and crew, to be added to their box office share.Why You Should HelpIt's not easy putting up a show in this world, and it's especially not easy putting up one that gives so many opportunities to actresses, and it's even more especially not easy putting up one of those that also helps to raise the profile of one of the most important women in the history of literature -- your donation will help all THREE of those things, bringing the story of Britain's most important woman playwright who was also a spy to an ever-increasing audience.We can do this; we're putting together a top-notch, low-budget production, we've got great actors and a fantastic director.  We've got almost everything we need, except for that one little push that you can give us.    If You Can't DonateThen tell your friends!  Share Aphra's story; even if THEY can't donate, maybe one day Empress of the Moon will play in their town or city or village or local agrarian commune, and they'll buy a ticket!

story:
THE MAN BURNS is a mystical, joyous theatrical observation on Burning Man and a glimpse into the lives of people who make this epic trek once a year. This interactive play breaks down the walls and gives you a night at Burning Man

********************************

LISTEN TO SCENES FROM THE PLAY

https://soundcloud.com/themanburns/the-man-burns-opening

https://soundcloud.com/themanburns/the-man-burns-sc-3

*******************************

MY VISION

This is not a play that will be performed at Burning Man-this will be performed off-playa, in your city, in a theater.

You walk up to the theater to see a performance of a new play, "The Man Burns."  Out front is an art car playing music and getting the evening going. When you enter the theater the first thing you notice is a group of people gathered around a costume exchange picking out free colorful clothing accessories like a faux fur mantle or a set of glowing devil horns to wear inside the theater. If you brought an extra costume piece you can leave it behind for someone else.



(photo by Layne Kennedy)

Next, you'll come across an old tiki bar called MAKIMAKI, the kind of bar you might accidentally happen on the esplanade at Burning Man. MAKIMAKI is decorated with well-traveled thrift shop tiki items. The house cocktail is of course, the MAKIMAKI, but there are other playa-themed cocktails as well. And a jar of pickled eggs on the counter. 

 When you go inside you'll notice that the theater is decorated like the inside of a Mongolian yurt with beautiful tapestries lining the walls. The play begins. If you've never been to Burning Man you will be transported to this far-off, mysterious place. If you've been to the playa before you will find yourself back home, in the middle of a conversation about connectivity, overwhelming art, accidental sharts, (or accidental art and overwhelming sharts),  late night poutine and Burning Man urban myths. 

During intermission and after the play there might be a marching band or or someone playing jazz songs on their ukelele or grilled cheese sandwiches being handed out. The party will change from city to city because YOU  are the party. 

WHY WON'T MY FRIENDS AND FAMILY COME TO BURNING MAN?

It's too hot. It's overrun by naked hippies. It's too far away. There are no real showers. It used to be better ten years ago. 

Those are some of the reasons I've heard from friends and relatives about why they'll never come to Burning Man. But they love hearing stories about the playa and seeing at all the photographs.  By making "THE MAN BURNS" an interactive night with elements of Burning Man, I could give all of my friends a Burning Man night. And you can too. Everyone has at least 5 friends or relatives who say they'll never go. Bring them to see "THE MAN BURNS" and share the experience with them. 

(author of "The Man Burns", David Vernon)

WHO I AM 

My name is David Vernon and I grew up in a show biz family. My dad was a comedian and the voice of Frosty the Snowman. I spent my childhood backstage at The Ed Sullivan Show, The Tonight Show and wondering why my father was never the "Secret Square" on The Hollywood Squares. I also grew up with a love of story. Eventually, I took my love of story to the Tisch School of the Arts at NYU where I studied Film and TV. 

 I have been a professional writer for the past twenty years.  I've written short fiction (which has been widely anthologized), screenplays (a film I wrote, "The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green" premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival and  was released by Regent films.)  I was recently commissioned to write three short scripts for an upcoming feature film anthology about the city of Berlin by the producers of "New York, I Love You."  I've written essays on Salon (http://www.salon.com/2000/12/20/frosty/  I was chosen to participate in the IFP Screenwriter's Lab. I also sold a TV sitcom pilot to the Fox Network called "American Has-Beens." 

Before dedicating myself full time to writing, I worked as Head of Development for a film and TV producer at Warner Brothers. At another point I worked for a theater producer and was in charge of attending theater festivals, such as the incredible Humana Festival in Louisville, KY, to find plays that might work for Broadway and off-Broadway. 

I didn't know it at the time but all of these projects and jobs were training grounds for my most challenging and exciting project to date.



THE STORY

A whiteout is announced at Burning Man over the radio.  People are warned to take shelter. Within moments several strangers run into a Mongolian yurt to get away from the wind storm. 

(photo by Ian Norman)

The strangers include: ANDY and BUNNY EARS, a gay couple that own the Mongolian Yurt and were preparing for a hot sexual encounter with someone they met on the playa. FIREFLY, a virgin burner who just dropped her first ever hit of MDMA and was on her way to a dance club, PERSEPHONE, an Australian sci-fi actress looking for a ride share to Venice Beach after having another disappointing day on the playa, MOWGLI, a bouncy, energetic young guy dressed entirely in blinky lights who communicates only through motion, MARY ANIMALS, a 60 year old woman who comes to Burning Man on her own and sets up a coffee stand (with the worst coffee on the playa), that is destroyed in the white out, and an ex-marine with an unfortunate sense of direction, known as McRIB, who is dressed in a sketchy Ronald McDonald outfit who was on his way to fight at Thunderdome but got lost. 

The result is playa chaos as these characters, and a few others, spend the evening connecting, disconnecting, dancing to some great music on the Burning Man radio, arguing, and telling their Burning Man stories; some heartbreaking, some extraordinary.

INSPIRATION

I've been going to Burning Man for the past eleven years and have also been active in the Burner community. During that time I've witnessed   many fascinating Burning Man stories unfold in front of me. I've also met  so many fascinating and unique individuals. Their stories inspired me to write "THE MAN BURNS." 

The people who go to Burning Man travel a great distance and experience great joy, and sometimes hardship in search of....what exactly? A unique vacation? An opportunity to meet like-minded people? A chance to become part of something bigger than ourselves...part of an artistic experiment? After years of taking notes,  I became passionate about writing a play that explored these questions. 

For many people, "THE MAN BURNS" might be the closest they come to attending Burning Man. For others it might be their first introduction to this amazing place. For Burners, I hope the play might be a catalyst for them to further discuss their own experiences and stories. 


(photo by Lindsey Sterrett) 

THE PROCESS

I have been developing the story and working on "THE MAN BURNS" for the past three years.There is still more work to be done to get the play up and running. 

PHASE 1: Additional creatives will be brought in, a director will be hired, an art director and a costume designer. The casting process will begin. 

PHASE 2: The play will receive its world premiere performances in San Francisco and Los Angeles. 

PHASE 3: After taking into account what I've learned from the initial performances I will make further adjustments to the play. Then, the hope is to bring "THE MAN BURNS" to other cities in the U.S. and ultimately off-Broadway---and perhaps even to other countries. 

DO YOU WANT TO BRING THE MAN BURNS TO YOUR CITY?

Contact me @ themanburnsplay@gmail.com

WHY CROWD FUNDING?

When I worked as a scout in the theater world I was amazed at how difficult it was for a playright to get even the smallest production of their play mounted. It usually involves sending your play to many different producers and waiting months for them to even take a look at it, if they ever do. The process can take years and I don't like to sit around waiting for someone else make my dreams happen. Instead of having my play sit on the bottom of a stack of plays on a producer's desk, why not turn to the community of burners and fans of innovative theater to help me bring this project into existence? We have the power to make this happen.

HOW WILL WE USE YOUR PLEDGES TO MAKE THIS A GREAT THEATRICAL EXPERIENCE?

I am working on a very tight budget for THE MAN BURNS. $15,000 is not much to mount a production of a new play in two cities. I have already invested much of my own money to the development of this play. Your generous donations will help with the cost of renting a theater in Los Angeles and in San Francisco, casting, rehearsals, and setting up the after party events. 

I will be counting on the passion of tight knit community of artists to help bring this dream alive on a limited budget. 


(photo by Mick Jeffries)

BACKER REWARDS

I want to use Kickstarter not just as  a fundraiser, but as a chance to get people involved in this play. And for your generosity I have have come up with some great rewards. 

  • A VERY limited edition DOG TAG PENDANT FEATURING THE ETERNAL KNOT, A DESIGN THAT IS ON THE MONGOLIAN YURT AND ALSO REPRESENTS AN IMPORTANT THEME IN THE PLAY

  • OUR BEAUTIFUL CUSTOM DESIGNED T-SHIRT BY ARTIST ADAM JUNOD. 

  • YOU CAN BE AMONG THE VERY FIRST TO SEE THE WORLD PREMIERE OF THE MAN BURNS IN LOS ANGELES OR SAN FRANCISCO!
  • VIP INVITATIONS TO PARTY WITH THE PLAY'S CREATIVE TEAM AFTER THE PLAY!
  • A PART IN THE PLAY!
  • YOUR OWN COPY OF OUR THEATER POSTER! 

THANK YOU

“If you want to build a ship, don’t drum up the men to gather wood, divide the work, and give orders. Instead, teach them to yearn for the vast and endless sea.”

― Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, author of The LIttle Prince

I've written the play. I've bombarded you with Facebook posts. I've spent way too much time setting up a crowd funding campaigns. So here we are. You've read this far so that has to mean something. So now it is in your hands. Do you want to join me on this adventure?

Please support this play in any way you can--by backing us, or by championing us to your friends. This is a dream that can't happen without you. 

SPECIAL THANKS

To Crespin Rosas. To Terror Pigeon Dance Revolt for use of their song, Ride Friendship on my Kickstarter video (www.terrorpigeondancerevolt.com). And Sharma Hendel and Absinthia Baum for so much guidance!

BIG THANKS TO: Noe Adame, Paul K. Bisson, Neil Fridd, Daniel Herrera Gomez and Alvaro Gomez, , Nancy Bombard Jackson, Mick Jeffries, Adam Junod, Mike Kelley, Kentucky Fried Camp,  Maki Ogawa, Jason Prelsnik, Max Moore, Guy and Ashley Shocat, Lindsey Sterrett and Joseph Tiu.

story:
CALLING ALL FANS OF THE X FILES! Announcing the World Premiere of Close to HOME: A Musical X File-- the first unauthorized X Files Musical! On the night of October 11th, 1996, an episode of television aired that would revolutionize the face of the modern American TV Drama. Condemned for its gruesome depictions and themes, Season 4, Episode 2 of the X Files was pulled from the air immediately after premiering, making it the only episode of its kind in the show's nine seasons of syndication. And to this day, "Home" lives on in infamy in the hearts and minds of television audiences everywhere. NOW coming to Milwaukee, WI on April 23, 24, and 25, 2015: the musical parody of the very episode that changed television forever! Featuring a full original score, new script, and an immensely talented cast of musicians and performers, this hilarious and groundbreaking show will be performed at the ComedySportz MKE Garage before a live audience. A donation of $20 or more will earn you 1 reserved ticket to the show before general reservations are opened to the public in April. This sure-fire hit will sell out quickly, so guarantee your seat now! Won't be able to make it to the show? Live too far away to see it? Worry not! Help to make this show a reality with a contribution of any size and you will receive an exclusive link to a high-quality video of the performance after the show has premiered! Donate today and bring Close to HOME: A Musical X File to life!

Now there is a musical that is as Close to Home as it can be. Help fund this instant cult classic! 


Funding needed goes to: 

.Costumes ($200)

.Wigs ($150)

.Lights ($300)

.Rent ($700)

.Set ($200)

.Props ($150)

.Payment to Actors 

.Payment to Band

story:
WELCOME  TO OUR VIRTUAL BOX OFFICE AND FUNDRAISER!! To reserve a seat for the Tuesday, July 21st staged reading at The Mercury Theatre (7:30 PM - Rated PG-13/R for language and sexual content), just choose the $15 option. If you want more info and ways to make a greater contribution, please read on!

THE SECRET LIFE OF A LOCAL BAND is a new work by playwright, Lara Filip, with music from three well-loved Chicago songwriters, Diana Lawrence, Alan Schmuckler and Grammy nominated, Liam Davis. The story focuses on a small-town band that unwittingly makes it big and lands in Los Angeles. Leading the band is a woman that society may deem a little "past her prime" to become a pop star. The piece champions strong female characters, who can find their voice at any age, and raises discussion about the state of entertainment today, the role of media, as well as the bonds that pull artists together and keep friendships alive during the strangest and most challenging circumstances.

The reading on July 21st will be free to the public. However, the total projected cost is closer to $4,000. This campaign will help offset some of those costs. Even if you can't join us on the 21st, this is a great way to help contribute to the development of new works!

With the funds raised, we will pay our cast of all-star AEA actors, our incredible director, the stage manager and hire our sound and projection designers. All of these artists are vital to the success of the reading and are all working for well below what they are truly worth, in an effort to support a new piece in which they believe. We will also pay for rehearsal space rental and physical materials such as scripts, binders and all those little things that add up. If we do really well with this campaign, we may even provide snacks for the actors. But let's not get ahead of ourselves... :)

Thank you for supporting live theatre!

story:
Help PlayGround Publications publish this year’s anthology of the season’s best scripts by pre-ordering a copy of The Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles (2016)

THE BACKSTORY

Since 1994, the mission of PlayGround has been to support the development of new voices for the theatre. For over two decades, PlayGround has been a leading playwright incubator, providing unique opportunities for the cultivation and development of early-career local playwrights and partnerships with leading professional directors, actors, theatres and theatre lovers. In 2012, PlayGround expanded to Los Angeles with the launch of PlayGround-LA and its inaugural season in residence at the Zephyr Theatre.

Through the development of original short (and now full-length) plays, PlayGround-LA creates a microcosm of the greater theatre scene, supporting emerging playwrights' experimentation and risk-taking, while helping them hone their style and technique.

PUBLISH OR PERISH

For the past fifteen years, PlayGround Publications has promoted the work of scores of emerging new playwrights and their short plays through the Best of PlayGround series of anthologies.

This month, PlayGround Publications will print two new Best of PlayGround 2016 anthologies. You can help us in this mission by pre-ordering copies of the Los Angeles book through this Indiegogo funding campaign.

The book contains six scripts as performed at this year’s Best of PlayGround Gala new plays showcase (May 9, 2016). These six plays were selected as the best this season from more than 160 submissions and thirty-six works developed through the Monday Night PlayGround staged reading series.

Each script is printed in its entirety, creating an historical record of the development of these plays, with dates of first reading and premiere, original casting information and playwright biographies.

Proceeds of this funding campaign will be used exclusively to print and distribute the Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles anthology.

The Best of PlayGround anthologies:

  • Celebrate the best short plays of the past season;
  • Provide an economical way to bring high-quality audience-tested scripts to the attention of producers and educators;
  • Promote the work of new generations of talented playwrights;
  • Provide students and new dramatists with models of plays that have proven popular with audiences;
  • Creates an historical record of the development of these plays.

This year PlayGround is expanding the role of these books to help move the work of its talented emerging writers from page and into production.

The 2016 Los Angeles anthology contains complete scripts of the following plays:

She Has Seen the Wolf by Allie Costa
A New Happily Ever After by Vincent Terrell Durham
Bright Shining Sea by Julianne Jigour
Antic Resolutions by Arthur Keng
Psycho by Jessica June Rowe
Goodnight Joanne by Nicki Spencer

CUT TO THE CHASE

By contributing to our campaign, you can pre-order copies of this year’s anthology which will be available beginning May 9, 2016. This frees PlayGround-LA to invest its working capital in developing and producing the best new plays by Los Angeles's best new playwrights.

In addition to pre-ordering an anthology, if you are able to contribute more, we’ve lined up some swell perks as our way of saying thank you. If you'd like to pre-order multiple copies, please contact us for special rates.

Even though a great deal of in-kind labor is donated to support this publishing project, there’s no avoiding the need for cold, hard cash.

PlayGround Publications will use proceeds of this campaign to:

  • Print the 2016 Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles anthology;
  • Acquire ISBN numbers (yes, they cost money);
  • Market the anthologies to producers, educators, drama students, and fans of the theatre;
  • Create and distribute electronic versions of the anthologies.

Please support our campaign and help us jump-start the careers of some exciting new voices in the theatre community. Thank you!

PlayGround Publications is a fiscally-sponsored project of PlayGround (Federal ID 94-3336399). All gifts to this campaign are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
DEBRIEF 

“Obra Anaïs performance ensemble is a group of nine multidisciplinary artists who create contemporary performances with an evolving and engaged intersectional feminist and eco-socialist lens, recently debuting their inaugural production, CONFITEOR [vol i].

Since 2015 Obra Anais has also performed in collaboration and support of other artists locally and internationally, as well as solely highlighting their own ensemble work in a variety of venues such as Psychic City, Salle le Tremplin (Sherbrooke, QC), Casa del Popolo — collaborating with fellow Montreal composers (Xavier León, BUFFLO, malky), visual artists, and performance ensembles (Live Art Society/Discorituaali (Finland)).


PAST PRODUCTION 

C O N F I T E O R [vol i]

In early March (c. 2016) Obra Anaïs led the audience through the basement of Montreal's historic Rialto Theatre for an intimate affair with mixed media performances, clandestine meetings and the confessions of hidden secrets.  
C O N F I T E O R [vol i] was a piece that extrapolated on nine individuals’ reflections on seduction: the performance of presenting one’s supposed best self through learned behaviours. Centred around discovery, divulgence and persuasion 
C O N F I T E O R [vol i] aimed to open up a space for reflection as it unraveled the problematic, the absurd and the erotic in these dances of seduction.


Re:Stage Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WRbJb6O5Y5U&feature=youtu.be


CURRENT PRODUCTION 

C O N F I T E O R [vol iI] scheduled for: 

May 20 - 22 @ 2PM/5PM/8PM

May 25 - 28 @ 2PM/5PM/8PM


C O N F I T E O R [vol ii] is a live performance installation where performers explore notions of their "best revolutionary selves" and invite audiences to do the same by engaging with the dystopian, high-stakes world created, set in the year 2032. 

This show provides a uniquely intimate experience that calls for the critical examination of oppressive systems, such as surveillance and capitalism, that make radical movements of social justice necessary. 

In confessing the ways in which we cower from of our most revolutionary impulses and our desires for change, C O N F I T E O R [vol ii] poses an even greater challenge: to be more revolutionary in your daily life. 


* * * obra anaïs wants this challenge to be financially accessible to all, so no individual will be turned away at the door due to lack of funds. * * *


"If action is not taken immediately and this mission cannot be completed, the future of the world is at risk. Relevant content will be transmitted that is crucial to humanity's survival. Help the revolution live on". 


PURCHASING TICKETS 

Your tickets can be purchased online ONLY and will not be sold at the door.

Purchase here: 
https://thepointofsale.com/tickets/?q=Confiteor%3A%3A+vol+ii&p=1

It is imperative that you reserve and book your tickets online as spaces are very limited! 


* * * If you are experiencing financial limitations and still want to be a part of this experience, please do not hesitate to write directly to obra at obra.anais@gmail.com * * *


HOW YOUR $$$ WILL HELP CONFITEOR [vol ii] EXIST!

Your donations will fund the:

  • audiovisual technology (projectors, speakers, transducers … )

  • set pieces

  • costumes/disguises

  • lights

  • rental of rehearsal + performance space

These items will radicalize and optimize our enclave for each mission’s efficiency and full immersion of the participants! 

Furthermore, your aid will offer a financial stability that will facilitate the production of [vol iii] and [vol iv], currently scheduled to occur over the course of the next year.


ALTERNATIVE WAYS TO SUPPORT obra anaïs 

& C O N F I T E O R [vol ii] . . . 

As a radical collective we need as many allies as possible. You can become an ally by: 

  • telling your most trusted friends about the operation dates (May 22 - 28)

  • visiting and sharing the facebook page https://www.facebook.com/obra.anais/?fref=ts

  • reading about the latest missions on the website http://www.obraanais.com

  • looking out for updates and secret codes @obraanais (Twitter)

  • sending us private messages at obra.anais@gmail.com


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
About Me

Hi there! My name is Cassie M. Seinuk, and I’m a Cuban Jewish playwright, stage manager, and visual artist, turned theatrical producer! Although I’m an originally from North Woodmere, Long Island, I have spent the past 10 years in Boston, MA, working as a professional stage manager and writing plays. In 2013, I received my MFA at Lesley University’s Writing for Stage and Screen program, where I wrote the play, Eyes Shut. Door Open. (ESDO)

The First Production of ESDO

In Summer 2015, ESDO was produced by Boston theatre company, Wax Wings Productions. While the production was successful, we were limited by a short run and small budget. Many people have said the play was short lived and could have been greater realized with more a sophisticated production. I'm so grateful to have had ESDO produced even this one time, and for what I've been able to accomplish in playwriting so far. Now, I would like to take my play Eyes Shut. Door Open. to the next level, to bring it back to the stage with a larger budget and to a wider audience. To do all that, I need your help!

Bringing ESDO Back to the Stage

This campaign is raising funds to bring my play Eyes Shut. Door Open. back to the stage, in May 2016 at the stunning Warehouse XI in Somerville, MA, as a co-production between myself and Wax Wings Productions. This new production of ESDO will feature our same original team of talented actors, Victor Shopov, Michael James Underhill, and Melissa deJesus, and returning director, Christopher Randolph. Remounting ESDO with the help of this campaign will allow us to accomplish the following:

1. Bring ESDO to a wider audience given its larger scale, longer run, and more centrally located venue, and create more opportunities for people to see the play that missed its first, shorter run.

2. Fully realize ESDO on a more flexible budget. This means more developed lighting, set and sound design, and a more accessible venue in a vibrant neighborhood. 

3. Stimulate the local artist economy by paying actors, designers, crew and a venue for their time and work.

The success of this campaign would be a career changing moment for me. I know in my heart that I will always be a writer, but this opportunity will give me the resources I need to pursue a long term career as a playwright. As an independent artist, having a production of this caliber is a huge door opener, and is the key to making these dreams a reality.  

The Costs

We were able to fund the first production of ESDO mostly by ourselves, with the help of a few generous supporters, to whom we are greatly thankful. The costs of bringing ESDO back to the stage properly are going to add up quickly. Your donation will go towards the following:

    • Venue: $3,000

    • Design costs: set, lights, sound, costumes, blood: $3,000

    • Salaries for 3 actors, 1 director, 2 stage managers, and a team of 5 designers, and a production crew: $5,200

    • Programs, Marketing, Promotion, Concessions: $800

For You

In exchange for your generosity, we’ve put together some great exclusive gifts for you, all of which are available to the right of this campaign. See some examples of our fantastic gifts below! 

              

Thanks for checking out my campaign and I hope to see you in May!


More About the Play

Eyes Shut. Door Open is a modern Cain and Abel story set in the SoHo art scene of New York City. Turner Street's bold paintings are the hottest thing to hit the scene - they've even captured the attention of the elusive Johanna, who has more than just art on her mind. But when his one-eyed, pill-popping, younger brother appears, Turner must face the disturbing truth of his success, and the haunting family secrets shut behind doors.

ESDO Team

CAST:
Victor Shopov as Turner
Michael James Underhill as Palmer
Melissa deJesus as Johanna

CREATIVE TEAM:
Christopher Randolph, Director
Patrick Greene, Sound Composition and Design
Chris Bocchiaro, Lighting Design
Kyle Blanchette, Scenic Design
Lauren Annese, Properties
Stephanie Brownell, Costumes
Sam Layco, Stage Manager
Walker Allison, Asst. Director and Asst. Stage Manager
Wax Wings Productions, Co-Producer
Music in the video is an original composition for ESDO by Patrick Greene

story:
Dance Caribbean COLLECTIVE (DCC) is an organization dedicated to bringing and facilitating Caribbean Dance works, performances and culture to the Caribbean Diaspora in the US and more specifically Brooklyn, NY. We are raising $3500 towards the New Traditions Festival 2016, our acclaimed dance production held during Caribbean Heritage Month.

Through the New Traditions Festival, DCC is committed to presenting concert dance works rooted in Caribbean cultural traditions and experiences, that can connect to the Caribbean-American community through workshops, classes and education programs. This year we have chosen five local choreographers and two featured choreographers to develop and present work for New Traditions 2016, who align with this mission.

The featured  choreographers are Chris Walker and Kevin Ormsby in ‘Facing Home: Love and Redemption’, a contemporary dance concert that investigates the global impact of Bob Marley’s music—its expression of humanity’s struggle and inspiration toward love, redemption and hope—and the active, deep-rooted homophobia in Jamaican/West Indian Culture, and our 5 local artists are
Candace Thompson, Jessica St. Vil, Maxine Montilus, Safi Harriott and Shola Roberts. 

These artists are also serving as leaders in their communities, teaching workshops at schools and community organisations to inspire our youth. We need your support to give the New Traditions Artists the opportunity to present their work at the highest level. We invite you to join us in bringing this festival to life by contributing to this groundbreaking campaign!

#DanceYourCaribbean by ensuring that our culture stays alive through these artists. 

Are you #downwithDCC? 

DONATE today and join the DCC Team! 

$5 - $25 - Shout out on social media - #DownwithDCC
$25+ Shout out on social media - DCC Famalay (Family)
$50+ Shout out on social media/Name printed in program - DCC Junkanoo Jammers
$75+ All of the above/Autographed DCC Photo - DCC Bal (Haiti Dance Party) Ballers
$100+ All of the above/Personal thank you card - DCC Lime Lovers
$150+ All of the above/A free Soca Dance class - DCC Carnival Crew
$250+ All of the above/A free personal training session - DCC Caribbean All Stars

Onward! and Upward! Thank you for your support!


(Dance Caribbean COLLECTIVE is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Dance Caribbean COLLECTIVE must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.)
