story:
Shakespeare for Everyone!

Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park uplifts and enriches the lives of local residents and visitors through a classical theater experience. We believe the arts are an important part of the fabric of a community and we want to do our part to ensure a thriving arts environment and help foster the value of the arts as a public good. 

Residents of all ages and economic backgrounds are invited to come together for free outdoor theater in Vallejo, Martinez and Oakland. We are passionate about creating, producing and presenting live theater, and introducing non-theater goers to the visceral, cathartic experience of watching a live performance in the company of other audience members. Because this is a free event, all funds to pay company members and operations must be raised through grants and other fund raising sources such as asking generous community members like you to contribute to this campaign. 

Your contribution will go directly to paying our excellent and 

well-deserving actors, stage manager and director. 

Matinee performances, using natural light and sound, means we do not use or need lighting and sound equipment or techs, keeping our production costs low and our performance values high! Still, we need $2200 to cover our actors' pay for our upcoming free performances. 

Then, why, you ask, are we asking for $2200? Fees. Up to 10%. Indiegogo (4%), plus paypal and credit card fees (3%). In order for us to receive the full $2000 we need to help pay our hardworking actors, we must add the additional cost for the fees.

A free community event

Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park is preparing for our seventh season! Our director this year will be local actor and director Lindsay Stoltz-Karimian. Performances will be held at the Hanns Park Amphitheater in Vallejo July 30 and 31, at the Martinez Waterfront Amphitheater in Martinez, August 6 and 7, and the Peralta Hacienda Historical Park in Oakland on August 13 and 14, 2016. All performances at 3 pm.

Our 2016 show will be another “bare-bones” production, concentrating on the actors performances, with minimal set and modern dress. As is our tradition we will be announcing which show in April on Shakespeare's possible birthday. Drop us a line at vallejoshakespeare@gmail.com to be put on our email list and receive the announcement. 

Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park is proud to bring professional live theater to the residents of Vallejo, Martinez and Oakland. Our aim is to provide an inspiring and educational experience for our audience through intensive preparation and high quality performance.  

Find us on Facebook at Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park, or go to our NEW website, www.VallejoShakespeare.Wix.com/VShakes.  

Performance opportunities for the Bay Area theater community!

One of our goals is to provide professional performance opportunities through non-traditional casting to Bay Area actors of color and varying backgrounds. Our casts are made up of multi-ethnic and diverse actors from around the Bay Area. Characters in the plays are often switched from male to female, as well as casting females to play male roles, providing more acting opportunities for women. Smaller roles are also given to novice actors to give opportunities to a wide range of actors at every level. We want our productions to reflect our diverse community where we perform and help our audience connect to classical theater with exciting contemporary staging.

We pay our wonderful actors a small stipend for their hard work and time, but we need help to do this. Please help. Thank you.


Photos are from our 2015 production of MACBETH. Photo #1 by JJ McCoy at the Mare Island Naval Cemetery, #2-4 by Joe Pudlak at Hanns Park, Vallejo, and #5 by Clinton Vidal at Martinez Waterfront Amphitheater.
story_txt:
Shakespeare for Everyone!Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park uplifts and enriches the lives of local residents and visitors through a classical theater experience. We believe the arts are an important part of the fabric of a community and we want to do our part to ensure a thriving arts environment and help foster the value of the arts as a public good. Residents of all ages and economic backgrounds are invited to come together for free outdoor theater in Vallejo, Martinez and Oakland. We are passionate about creating, producing and presenting live theater, and introducing non-theater goers to the visceral, cathartic experience of watching a live performance in the company of other audience members. Because this is a free event, all funds to pay company members and operations must be raised through grants and other fund raising sources such as asking generous community members like you to contribute to this campaign. 
Your contribution will go directly to paying our excellent and 
well-deserving actors, stage manager and director. 
Matinee performances, using natural light and sound, means we do not use or need lighting and sound equipment or techs, keeping our production costs low and our performance values high! Still, we need $2200 to cover our actors' pay for our upcoming free performances. 
Then, why, you ask, are we asking for $2200? Fees. Up to 10%. Indiegogo (4%), plus paypal and credit card fees (3%). In order for us to receive the full $2000 we need to help pay our hardworking actors, we must add the additional cost for the fees.A free community eventVallejo Shakespeare in the Park is preparing for our seventh season! Our director this year will be local actor and director Lindsay Stoltz-Karimian. Performances will be held at the Hanns Park Amphitheater in Vallejo July 30 and 31, at the Martinez Waterfront Amphitheater in Martinez, August 6 and 7, and the Peralta Hacienda Historical Park in Oakland on August 13 and 14, 2016. All performances at 3 pm.Our 2016 show will be another “bare-bones” production, concentrating on the actors performances, with minimal set and modern dress. As is our tradition we will be announcing which show in April on Shakespeare's possible birthday. Drop us a line at vallejoshakespeare@gmail.com to be put on our email list and receive the announcement. Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park is proud to bring professional live theater to the residents of Vallejo, Martinez and Oakland. Our aim is to provide an inspiring and educational experience for our audience through intensive preparation and high quality performance.  Find us on Facebook at Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park, or go to our NEW website, www.VallejoShakespeare.Wix.com/VShakes.  Performance opportunities for the Bay Area theater community!One of our goals is to provide professional performance opportunities through non-traditional casting to Bay Area actors of color and varying backgrounds. Please help. Thank you.
Photos are from our 2015 production of MACBETH. Photo #1 by JJ McCoy at the Mare Island Naval Cemetery, #2-4 by Joe Pudlak at Hanns Park, Vallejo, and #5 by Clinton Vidal at Martinez Waterfront Amphitheater.

story:
1. CHI SIAMO/WHO WE ARE

 La compagnia I Nuovi Scalzi nasce nel 2007 a Roma, come gruppo informale, durante il corso di alta formazione in tecniche e forme della commedia dell’arte con Claudio De Maglio, ad opera del Centro Teatro Ateneo presso l’ università La Sapienza di Roma.

Nel 2012 si formalizza in associazione culturale e di promozione sociale, in Puglia con sede a Barletta. L’associazione si orienta  verso i linguaggi di un teatro popolare e di strada, elaborando proposte di spettacolo che , attraverso un linguaggio immediato, possa avvicinare il teatro e le arti performative e la danza ad un pubblico popolare e poco abituato a vivere gli spazi del Teatro. 

In abito teatrale  affina le competenze e lo studio della commedia dell’arte, indagando tematiche contemporanee, mediante la tradizionale scrittura di canovacci. In ultimo la compagnia scrive e mette in scena  “La ridiculosa commedia della terra contesa” tratto dall'antefatto storico: La Disfida Di Barletta. Lo spettacolo è incentrato sull’importanza di tutelare la Terra dall’abusivismo edile e da gli interessi privati, al fine di tutelare l’ambiente e di alimentare nel pubblico l’interesse al Bene Comune, alla protezione del verde pubblico e a tecniche agricole non invasive.  E' questo lo spettacolo scelto per rappresentare l'ITALIA al Festival in CANADA


FB:https://www.facebook.com/?locale=it_IT

FB/pagina: https://www.facebook.com/pages/I-NUOVI-Scalzi/1602955196654629?fref=ts&locale=it_IT

    2. PERCHE' SOSTENERCI/WHY SUPPORT 

L'Associazione è composta da giovani attori professionisti di età compresa tra i 20 e i 30 anni, tutti con grande dedizione per questo MESTIERE.

Partecipando al bando di selezione del Festival canadese, concorrevamo con più di 100 spettacoli su tutto il territorio nazionale; è stata scelta proprio la Commedia dell'Arte, una delle più antiche tradizioni teatrali ITALIANE a rappresentare il nostro paese. Era da tre anni che l'ITALIA non veniva selezionata a partecipare al FESTIVAL; è per noi un onore ed una grande occasione, sia come italiani che come giovani artisti, poter essere i rappresentanti delle cultura del nostro paese all'estero.

Grazie al vostro sostegno, che andrà a coprire le spese di viaggio (aereo+vitto e Alloggio), stiamo organizzando una tournèe dello spettacolo nei paesi della regione del Quebec.

   3. I NOSTRI PARTNER/OUR PARTNERS

In occasione della selezione al festival la compagnia ha ricevuto il Patrocinio del Comune di Barletta, città pugliese dove ha sede l'associazione e fonte d'ispirazione per la realizzazione della commedia. Da più di due anni collaboriamo con la Civica Accademia Nico Pepe di Udine diretta dal Regista e nostro maestro Claudio de Maglio. Inoltre siamo in attesa di ricevere il Patrocinio del Ministero dei Beni Culturali italiano, che ha accettato la nostra richiesta (senza contributi economici) come sostegno istituzionale per il viaggio canadese. Abbiamo anche contattato i gruppi italiani residenti in Canada, così da poter creare una rete di comunicazione ed un anche un possibile sostegno alla campagna di crowdfunding. 

    

FIRE SHOW perk 
Ecco alcune foto del fire show . Una delle ricompense speciali per i  nostri sostenitori. Una performance di giochi e colate di fuoco, suggestive coreografie su musica, in atmosfere oniriche, che sorprenderanno il pubblico con la forza e la passione del fuoco.

story:
About I KADA Dance Company..

I KADA contemporary dance company was formed in Sept, 2011 in NYC. The company name KADA stands for Korean American Dance Association. We are a contemporary dance company focusing on cultural exchange through the arts. While our focus is dance, we also fuse visual arts, music, painting and photography into our shows and festivals. We have held three annual shows and one festival since our beginning. All shows and festivals have a specific theme attached to the works. This is where the cultural exchange between artists,choreographers and dancers are united. Having had artist from Asia, Europe, North America and South America the exchange of culture and styles has been a sight to see. As we continue to grow we will keep creating dance works of extraordinary artistry that deliver positive messages and life enriching experiences for all

What we need and what you get..

We aim to raise $2,500 for our 4th annual international dance festival; KoDaFe in NYC 2016. The funds raised will be utilized for theater hire, rehearsal spaces, dancers, costume, multi media and promotion. We want to make this year bigger and better than the last, and create a platform for a wider community for dancers and audience to share!!! In return for all contribution, big and small, KoDaFe will show appreciation by thanking donors with unique rewards!!!


About the Festival..

 KoDaFe in NYC 2016 will be held at The Ailey Citigroup Theater on June 21st at 7:30pm.

The theme of the festival this year is "Chum Janchi", meaning "Dance Party" in Korean! It's a time to celebrate through dance!!!


Check out the Gallery!!!

story:
LIT PRODUCTIONS is and all encompassing playground for ideas and experiments. Join Us.

Our first production will be “In the Heights”.  The show will be running March 9-13 in the Student Center at Purchase College.

“IN THE HEIGHTS tells the universal story of a vibrant community in New York’s Washington Heights neighborhood – a place where the coffee from the corner bodega is light and sweet, the windows are always open and the breeze carries the rhythm of three generations of music. It’s a community on the brink of change, full of hopes, dreams and pressures, where the biggest struggles can be deciding which traditions you take with you, and which ones you leave behind. IN THE HEIGHTS is the winner of the 2008 Tony Awards for Best Musical, Best Score, Best Choreography and Best Orchestrations.” — Rodgers and Hammerstein

Music and Lyrics by Lin-Manuel Miranda | Book by Quiara Alegria Hudes | Conceived By Lin-Manuel Miranda


Cast:

Usnavi: Justin Laguna

Nina: Rosemarie Albanes

Kevin Rosario: Alejandro Beccera

Camila Rosario: Lucy De Urquiza

Benny: Tyrone Hodges

Vanessa: Faith Gallivan

Sonny: Micah Rabang

Abuela Claudia: Caitlin Sosa

Daniela: Marina Espinet

Carla: Emma Myers

Graffiti Pete: Frandy Ciserno

Piragua Guy: Antonio Muniz

Ensemble: Michael Jorge, Riley Kiggins


Production Team:

Director and Producer: Caitlin Byrne

Musical Director: Ethan Brown-Jones

Choreographer: Sanina Leilani

Lighting Designer: Nyle Farmer

Assistant Director: Madison Hartke-Weber

Stage Manager: Nic Uvino

Assistant Music Director: Dan Russo


What We Need 

$500: Rights for the play are already paid for so we are raising money for the set and props for the show.

story:
What

It is Christmas morning and the Franks are gathered around the family Christmas tree, exchanging gifts in the name of Jesus Christ. When an unexpected package arrives from Santa and his Reindeer, little Jimmy Frank must channel the killing powers of his new computer game, The Little Devils, to kill the evil that has taken over the living room. Will the Franks survive? Will they keep the "Christ" in Christmas once and for all? Will they save Jesus from the cross? This short play is about holiday consumerism, religious fanaticism, and the awkwardness of family on Christmas.

_____________________________________________________________________________

Who

My name is Emilia White ('Emilia Javanica') and I'm a performing artist, playwright and director. In December 2015 I hosted a staged reading of my short play The Little Devils at the ongoing experimental performance series that I co-curate in Detroit, The Performance Laboratory. The performance received an incredible amount of laughter and positive feedback, and influenced my decision to keep the play as a reading, and work with the performers to translate it into a dramatic radio play. This has opened up an exciting new genre for me, one rich with sound effects and vocal exploration. The Little Devils will be my first attempt to tell a story through audio alone, without relying on the visual. 

I'm asking for your help to pay a stellar female cast, and a talented group of audio engineers.

The performers include:
Bridget Michael
Laura Pazucowski
Eleni Zaharopoulos
Dorothy Melander-Dayton
Torri Lynn Ashford
Carrie Morris
Emilia Javanica

The recording will take place at the Tempermill in Detroit during the first week of March 2016. Following the recording I will work with the audio engineers to mix everything together and incorporate additional sound effects and background music. 

The Need

I need $1,750 to make my radio play a reality. The funds will be used to pay for the following: 

$1,225 to pay 7 performers ($25 per hour for 7 hours of rehearsal & recording)
$250 for rehearsal space
$260 for four hours in The Tempermill Recording Studio (recording & mixing)
$15 for sound effects

Why

Each year in October as soon as Thanksgiving ends, Christmas shows up on the shelves at CVS Pharmacy and Walmart. Americans are bombarded with holiday music and Christmas cheer. Many families who celebrate decorate their houses with Christmas lights and put up a Christmas tree in the living room. Deal-hungry crowds converge en masse at Black Friday and Cyber Monday. Kids get their picture taken with Santa Claus. Occasionally someone puts up a reminder on their lawn of what Christmas is really about, like this one from my neighborhood: 

My play attempts to capture the removal from reality that one family experiences on Christmas morning as they rip open present after present of religious meaninglessness, only to discover that there are some things they can't control. 

How else to help

Every penny counts! I'm hoping to raise the full amount I have requested, but am prepared to work with what I receive for this production.

If you don't have money to donate, you can also help in the following ways:

Tell your friends!

Share on Twitter and Facebook!

Email it to your mailing list!

Put up signs with the link in local coffee shops!

Stand up on the bus and announce it to strangers!

Call your Mom on the phone and tell her about it!

Sing about it, out loud, in public!

Tell Santa Claus! Maybe he'll bring presents early this year!

Thank you so much for your support!!!

story:
Help us build a dance festival in Boston!

New Movement Collaborative + Green Street Studios  presents the 1st Annual Lion's Jaw performance + dance festival
Lion’s Jaw is a completely new kind of event for Boston! A performance + dance festival that brings together a group of nationally recognized choreographers, performers, educators and students to study, perform and create dance together for five days. 
Featuring all-day intensives with award winning choreographers Sara Shelton Mann + The Body Cartography Project as well as daily classes with Olivier Besson, Leslie Castellano, Alice Gosti, Miguel Gutierrez, K.J. Holmes, Annie Kloppenberg, Paul Matteson, Alli Ross + Taja Will, this festival bring artists who have never before shown in Boston together with some of the cities most sought after teachers and performers. 
Days will include classes | mini-workshops | critiques | dance-labs.                       Nights will include public performances | discussion | live music improvisation jams.
visit lionsjaw.com for more information

Studio 1 Green Street Studios

Studio 2 Green Street Studios




What we need: we can't do this without your help!

We have an ambitious sum of money to raise in the next two months but we feel so confident in our community and our city and are looking forward to working together to make this happen. Please know that whether you donate* $5 or $5,000 every penny counts and it really does make a difference!
 All your donations are also tax deductible thanks to Fractured Atlas, New Movement Collaborative's fiscal sponsor*

your donations will go to:

  • paying our artists competitive salaries for the dozens of hours of teaching required over the 5 days
  • travel + transportation costs for teachers
  • housing costs for teachers
  • 5 days of rentals for studios + theatre spaces
  • tech [sound|lighting|stage management] for the performances
  • promotion + marketing
  • liability insurance
what if we exceed our goal?
If we are so lucky to exceed our goal we will be able to pay our festival staff a small stipend for all the volunteer hours required for this event, invest in a more extensive scholarship program and raise funds for next year's 2nd annual festival!

*New Movement Collaborative is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of New Movement Collaborative must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law


What impact on Boston? 

Despite growing momentum around the arts in Boston, it remains a city without a professional dance-festival, the goal of New Movement Collaborative generally + Lion's Jaw specifically is to help make this a city where artists come to live, work and gain national attention.

  • By bringing artists from other cities to ours to interchange with local artists we hope to catalyze energy and change
  • We are committed to creating an affordable festival where actual working dance-artists can attend.
  • We will be building a diversity scholarship fund to help people from diverse backgrounds who for financial reasons, might not otherwise be able to attend the event
  • As local Boston curators, New Movement Collaborative are new, energized and experienced producers with a history of working collaboratively with local institutions
  • Please feel free to reach out, ask around, look over our webpages and find out more about us! We are committed to putting on quality events and to helping artists feel met + supported


Risks + challenges

As we have said before, this is an ambitious project and there are always risks. Some potential events that could impact the event could be: an unsuccessful crowd-sourcing campaign, teacher cancellations or issues with the space.

  • We may be young but we are seasoned producers. Over the past 3 years, the founders of New Movement Collaborative have collectively run over 2 dozen weekend workshops, facilitated over 50 classes and developed and organized everything from performances, panel talks, residencies to mentorship programming throughout the Boston area.
  • If we do encounter funding issues you can count on us to find creative solutions! We are committed to making Lion's Jaw happen and even if we come up a bit short fiscally, we are confident this fall will be amazing!
  • We are lucky to live in a world filled with amazing dance-artists and in the event of a cancellation, we have a long list of other wonderful options
  • We are working hard to secure a back-up space in the unlikely event that Green Street Studios is unable to house the festival.


Can't donate but still want to help?

Even though no donation is too small, we understand that times are tough and if for some reason you are unable to give fiscally to the campaign there are a few ways you can still help:

  • share the campaign, our facebook and web pages and help us get the word out!
  • reach out to us as we get closer to find out if there are organizational ways in which you can be involved with the festival
  • find a fiscal sponsor or support large-scale donors to help us grow our scholarship capabilities.


Video credits:

videography: tamar melen editing: jared williams video footage: used with permission by sara shelton mann, olive beiringa, taja will, k.j. holmes, doppelgänger dance collective, alice gosti + sarah young 
music: mike wall

Jaw is a completely new kind of event for Boston! A performance + dance
festival that brings together a group of nationally recognized choreographers,
performers, educators and students to study, perform and create dance together
for five days. Featuring all-day intensives with award winning choreographers Sara Shelton Mann + The Body Cartography Project as well as daily classes with Olivier Besson, Leslie Castellano, Alice Gosti, Miguel Gutierrez, K.J. Holmes, Annie Kloppenberg, Paul Matteson, Alli Ross + Taja Will, this festival bring artists who have never before shown in Boston together with some of the cities most sought after teachers and performers. 
Days will include classes | mini-workshops | critiques | dance-labs.                       Nights will include public performances | discussion | live music improvisation jams.
visit lionsjaw.com for more informationStudio 1 Green Street Studios


Studio 2 Green Street Studios

   
What we need: we can't do this without your help!
We have an ambitious sum of money to raise in the next two months but we feel so confident in our community and our city and are looking forward to working together to make this happen. Please know that whether you donate* $5 or $5,000 every penny counts and it really does make a difference!
 All your donations are also tax deductible thanks to Fractured Atlas, New Movement Collaborative's fiscal sponsor*
 your donations will go to: 
paying our artists competitive salaries for the dozens of hours of teaching required over the 5 days
travel + transportation costs for teachers
housing costs for teachers
5 days of rentals for studios + theatre spaces
tech [sound|lighting|stage management] for the performances
promotion + marketing
liability insurance

what if we exceed our goal?
If we are so lucky to exceed our goal we will be able to pay our festival staff a small stipend for all the volunteer hours required for this event, invest in a more extensive scholarship program and raise funds for next year's 2nd annual festival!
*New Movement Collaborative is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of New Movement Collaborative must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law

What impact on Boston?  Despite growing momentum around the arts in Boston, it remains a city without a professional dance-festival, the goal of New Movement Collaborative generally + Lion's Jaw specifically is to help make this a city where artists come to live, work and gain national attention.  By bringing artists from other cities to ours to interchange with local artists we hope to catalyze energy and change
We are committed to creating an affordable festival where actual working dance-artists can attend.
We will be building a diversity scholarship fund to help people from diverse backgrounds who for financial reasons, might not otherwise be able to attend the event As local Boston curators, New Movement Collaborative are new, energized and experienced producers with a history of working collaboratively with local institutions Please feel free to reach out, ask around, look over our webpages and find out more about us! We are committed to putting on quality events and to helping artists feel met + supported    
Risks + challenges  As we have said before, this is an ambitious project and there are always risks. Some potential events that could impact the event could be: an unsuccessful crowd-sourcing campaign, teacher cancellations or issues with the space.  We may be young but we are seasoned producers. Over the past 3 years, the founders of New Movement Collaborative have collectively run over 2 dozen weekend workshops, facilitated over 50 classes and developed and organized everything from performances, panel talks, residencies to mentorship programming throughout the Boston area. If we do encounter funding issues you can count on us to find creative solutions! We are committed to making Lion's Jaw happen and even if we come up a bit short fiscally, we are confident this fall will be amazing!
We are lucky to live in a world filled with amazing dance-artists and in the event of a cancellation, we have a long list of other wonderful options
We are working hard to secure a back-up space in the unlikely event that Green Street Studios is unable to house the festival.    
Can't donate but still want to help? Even though no donation is too small, we understand that times are tough and if for some reason you are unable to give fiscally to the campaign there are a few ways you can still help:  share the campaign, our facebook and web pages and help us get the word out! reach out to us as we get closer to find out if there are organizational ways in which you can be involved with the festival
find a fiscal sponsor or support large-scale donors to help us grow our scholarship capabilities.



Video credits:
videography: tamar melen editing: jared williams video footage: used with permission by sara shelton mann, olive beiringa, taja will, k.j. holmes, doppelgänger dance collective, alice gosti + sarah young music: mike wall

story:
Our most ambitious project to date...

As we enter our second year, we're ready to face the challenge of our largest cast, and largest venue yet. THESE SHINING LIVES is a beautiful period piece, based on the real life struggles of the "Radium Girls", as they came to be known:


"If one woman were to tell the truth about her life, the world would split open." - Muriel Rukyser

Journey with us back to Chicago in the roaring 20s. It's a world of banana splits, days at Lake Michigan, and hidden flasks filled with gin. A world of jazz music, Al Capone, and Rudolph Valentino. 

In 1922, The Radium Dial Company moved to Ottowa, Illinois. They hired local young women to paint watch faces with luminous radium powder. The work was easy and the wages were high. But there was a hidden cost.

THESE SHINING LIVES explores the journey of real life Radium Dial painters Catherine Donohue, Frances O’Connell, Pearl Payne, and Charlotte Purcell as they enlist attorney Leonard Grossman to help them battle a corrupt system that considered them expendable.

It's a fight that still resonates today, in a world where profit, rather than human life, is often the priority.

Directed by: Mallory Metoxen
Featuring: Libby Amato, Randall Anderson, Anna Figlesthaler, Linnea Koeppel, Tom Marks, Philip Sletteland, and Jade Taylor.


We Think You're the Bees Knees!

So we've put together some fun perks to say thank you for helping us bring this inspirational story to the stage!

Spread the word!

We hope to see you all at the show next month. Theatre is storytelling...and we've got an amazing story to share with you. And tell your friends! This one has something for everyone: it's a love story, a friendship story, a courtroom drama, a tragedy, and a tale of triumph over a corrupt system.

And once again...thanks. We couldn't do it without you!

story:
Our continuing MISSION

Now well into our third season, we still wholeheartedly believe and full-throatedly proclaim our belief that:

In an age where the notion of “neighborhood” is fast evolving into a series of intangible on-line social media webpages, A Public Fit aims to reinvigorate the tangible community by working with emerging Las Vegas artists to create exciting, innovative and provocative professional theater. APF believes strongly in the communal power of great stories, dramatic ideas and the sincere engagement that audiences find in challenging theatrical events. A Public Fit genuinely hopes to unite professional artists and audiences through the most effective form of human connection, treating each production as the beginning of an unending conversation.

“To see what exquisite acting and directing are all about, buy your ticket now before they’re gone.  This is theatre at its best.”

-Mary LaFance, Talkin’ Broadway

www.talkinbroadway.com/page/regional/lasvegas/l...

As before, the staff of APF will be working merely to cover their expenses in order to make absolutely certain that the performers and behind-the-scenes artists get paid first.  Our everlasting cry:  A Public Fit respects artists too much to ask them to work for free.

“It’s rare to see theater that unabashedly aims to create a serious work of art that’s challenging, cerebral and emotionally impacting.”

-Jacob Coakley, Las Vegas Weekly

www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/stage/2016/nov/09/a-p...

 

Our recent PAST

A Public Fit’s on-going series of free monthly staged readings captured the imagination of an ever-growing audience of theatre aficionados who braved SRO crowds.  Our first fully-realized production, Dawn King’s “Foxfinder”, was met with critical and commercial success, selling out its November 2014 run and garnering 11 Las Vegas Valley Theatre Award nominations - including wins for Best Play, Best Director and Best Lighting Design - nominations in every category for which it was eligible.  The following season, APF challenged the very role of the audience itself with its world-premiere production of “A Summons from the Tinker to Assemble the Membership in Secret at the Usual Place”, an original piece that once again dominated the Valley Awards, winning Best Ensemble Cast as well as the coveted Audience Choice Award.  APF’s second show that year, Gina Gionfriddo’s modern comedy “Becky Shaw”, saw multiple acting nominations as well.  And the first mainstage production of our 2016-2017 season, Andrew Bovell’s “When the Rain Stops Falling” left audiences gasping.  This is the kind of flat-out, take-no-prisoners theatre that A Public Fit continues to thrive on.  And it’s why APF was named Best Theatre Company in Las Vegas by the Las Vegas Weekly immediately following our inaugural season.

“‘When the Rain Stops Falling’ is a triumph!  … The scenic design was stunning.”

-Michael M. Humel, editor-in-chief, Culture of the Senses

http://cultureofthesenses.com/when-the-rain-sto...

 

Our spectacular FUTURE

Two mainstage productions and three staged readings remain in our 2016-2017 season.  In February, A Public Fit will produce Martin McDonagh’s “The Beauty Queen of Leenane.”  Set in a small country village in Connemara, county Galway, Ireland, this blackest of black comedies depicts the decades-old struggle for power and independence between a 40-year-old spinster and her wry, devious, 70-year-old mother.  It is suspenseful, compelling and unexpectedly funny as it builds with unrelenting tension towards an unforgettable and inevitable climax.  “The Realistic Joneses”, our final mainstage production of 2017, opens in May.  This funny, moving and wonderfully weird play by Will Eno is a tantalizing conversation about the perplexing business of being alive.  The Joneses share so much more than identical homes and common last names as idyllic fantasy and harsh reality clash.

“In the ‘entertainment capital of the world,’ it’s rare to see theater that works in this register.  It’s satisfying in ways that go beyond just a good show…”

-Jacob Coakley, Las Vegas Weekly

www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/stage/2016/nov/09/a-p...

 

Our Vegas CULTURE

Las Vegas is evolving still.  As the valley’s neon glow continues to be a beacon for cultural emigrants from across the nation, A Public Fit has actively sought out to embrace those looking for an innovative, professional, theatrical oasis in the literal desert.  Our aesthetic is unique, our vision unparalleled, our commitment unrivaled, our energy unmatched.   And while Las Vegas still draws the most talented people on the planet to perform in its spectacular strip extravaganzas, the need for cultural expression of a more connective nature still burns fiercely in the breasts of these creative super-stars.  A Public Fit exists to give voice to these yearnings, to harness the prolific desires of those artistic visionaries that land here in the valley.

“The artistic team driving APF to the forefront believes and embraces the notion that theatre is for everyone, it will always be relevant and it is a vital part of our community's culture.”

-Melanie Jupp, Assistant Program Manager, Education and Outreach, The Smith Center

 

Our PLEA

Please help us continue what we’ve started - an even larger, continuing season with 3 fully-realized productions and 4 free-to-the-public staged readings; our continued commitment to explore the challenges of ‘found space’ production; the drive to maintain our standing as Las Vegas’ only professional theatre company.   Add your voice to the growing chorus of those who demand more from the Las Vegas cultural landscape.  Sing proudly with us our anthems of optimism and audacity.  We’ve proven that nothing that happens in Vegas stays in Vegas; in fact, what happens in Vegas should shake the artistic pillars of the nation!  And, of course, as a nationally registered and verified non-profit organization, all donations to A Public Fit are tax-deductible to the full extent of applicable tax law!

story:
T.EENAGERS AUX MONDIAUX DE DANSE HIP HOP À LAS VEGAS

LA TROUPE DE TENDANSE REPRÉSENTERA LE CANADA EN AOÛT PROCHAIN AU WORLD HIP HOP DANCE CHAMPIONSHIP #TEAMCANADA2016

La troupe T.EENAGERS du Studio Tendanse de Granby ira représenter le pays cet été à la plus importante compétition de danse hip hop au monde. Hip Hop International accueillera à Las Vegas du 8 au 13 août prochain les meilleures équipes de plus de 50 pays.

Pour se rendre au bout de leur rêve, l'équipe doit ramasser beaucoup de sous qui serviront à couvrir les frais reliés au transport, à l'hébergement, aux repas, à l'entraînement, aux costumes, aux frais d'inscriptions, etc.

Les 5 jeunes danseuses qui forment la troupe T.EENAGERS sont âgées de 12 et 13 ans et se sont entraînées à défaut de 6 heures par semaine tout au long de l'année et devront sacrifier leur été pour se perfectionner davantage. Tout au long de l’annéee, l’équipe s’est hissée aux premiers rangs des compétitions où elle a performé, en plus de recevoir de nombreux prix spéciaux pour performance, interprétation, précision, meilleure chorégraphie, etc.

La compétition de danse World Hip Hop Dance Championship représente les olympiques dans le monde de la danse. Chaque pièce chorégraphique doit respecter des critères très précis pour être admissible. Il faut savoir que le Canada, aux côtés du Japon, de la Nouvelle Zélande et des Philippines, figure toujours parmi les meilleurs pays à se démarquer lors de cet évènement prisé.

Fières représentantes du pays et de TEAM CANADA pour l’édition de 2016, Alexia, Alison, Coralie, Isanne et Kiliane vous remercient infiniment pour vos dons, votre collaboration et vos encouragements!

Pour rester informé des activités de financement qu'organisera T.EENAGERS durant l'été et pour suivre leur aventure, suivez la page Facebook T.eenagers – Tendanse .

story:
Who are the Christ Church Players ...


The Christ Church Players are a reemergence of youth theatre at Christ Episcopal Church in Exeter, New Hampshire. In the past, the youth theatre program created a safe space for children and teens to discover new truths about themselves, each other, and the world around them, and to share those truths with the community through the art of theatre.

Founded by Suzanne Jalbert Jones, Director of Music at Christ Church, and her longtime collaborator Lexi Meunier, the newly-dubbed Christ Church Players serves as an important outreach ministry for young performers in the Exeter area, though many of its cast and audience are not members of the church. It is the belief of CCP that exposure to the performing arts helps to build the foundation of well-rounded and well-adjusted individuals for the betterment of our community.



... and who are Suzi & Lexi?


Suzanne Jalbert Jones has served as the music director and choral conductor for numerous theatre companies and churches throughout New Hampshire and Massachusetts. She currently directs the Christ Church Choir and Junior Choir, is on the faculty of the Performing Arts Connection in Sudbury, MA, and offers private lessons through her voice and piano studio. She is passionate about 19th and 20th century choral music and musical theatre, and was nominated for Best Musical Direction at the 2013 and 2014 EMACT DASH Awards. Suzanne holds a BM in Classical Voice Performance from the New England Conservatory of Music, as well as a Masters in Choral Conducting from the University of New Hampshire.

Lexi Meunier began her theatrical career fifteen years ago in her hometown of Derry, New Hampshire, performing with programs much like CCP! A graduate of the Portland Actors Conservatory in Portland, Oregon, Lexi is on the faculty of the Performing Arts Connection in Sudbury, MA, and she serves as the Director of Theatre Education for the Haverhill branch of the North Shore YMCA Theatre Company. Lexi is currently studying English with a Theatre Arts concentration and Education minor at the University of Massachusetts: Lowell.

Suzi and Lexi share the belief that exposure to the performing arts is extremely beneficial to youth, as it fosters emotional intelligence and communicative abilities, encourages a strong awareness of self and others, and increases both self-discipline and self-confidence. Best friends for over a decade, Suzi and Lexi have worked together both onstage and behind the scenes of numerous productions, and they are so very thrilled with the opportunity to share their love and knowledge of theatre with up-and-coming performers!



"Impossible Things Are Happening Every Day!"


Last fall, CCP mounted its debut production of Rodgers & Hammerstein's Cinderella, a show that was chosen in hopes that the story's popularity would help garner interest in this unknown theatre company. Maybe a dozen performers would be enough for a worthwhile production? Would we be lucky enough to have a full ensemble with twenty?

Much to our surprise and elation, over fifty young performers auditioned for Cinderella, and we were blown away by not only the quantity of performers, but also by the quality; from the moment auditions began, we were met with so much enthusiasm, energy, and raw talent that we were left feeling giddily overwhelmed. We ultimately decided to accept every performer who was brave enough to audition, splitting the performers into two casts based on age. This allowed our older performers to be challenged, and our younger performers to take a turn in the spotlight. Both spirited casts absolutely blew away their audiences. Parents, performers, and patrons raved - and continue to rave! - about Cinderella, and it is with their support and encouragement that we embark on a full theatrical season.

"My husband and I have been so impressed by all your effort and care that you put into this show from the very beginning. Your communication with us and care of our children was truly outstanding! ... You created a lovely community there, and it showed both onstage and off. I have told many people just how impressed I've been with your professionalism as well as creating an environment for our children to feel nurtured, encouraged, and creative."

"The girls absolutely LOVED being a part of Cinderella and still sing the songs all the time. (One even constructed "her own little corner" in her room, and I find her singing there quite often!) For both of them, the show provided a real window to discovery of interests and talents that they didn't know they had. What a gift! ... Beyond the performance, the whole experience of team-building was so positive - what a great group of kids and what a wonderful culture of support."

"I just wanted to let you know how impressed my husband and I were with the entire production of Cinderella. ... I had no idea that this play would be such a positive and, in all honestly, life-changing experience for her! She loved every minute of it. She couldn't wait for play practice ... and just took on all responsibilities without needing us to nag her. She has officially been bitten by the acting bug and can't wait to be part of another production! ... Thank you so much for providing such a wonderful experience for our daughter and all of the kids that took part in the plays. There is nothing better than watching your child do what they love!"



The Importance of Theatre in Our Community


What excites us most about working with young performers is that children are natural masters at playing make-believe and utilizing their imaginations, which makes them inherently talented performers. Unfortunately, as children mature, the spaces in which they are allowed to touch base with that creativity become limited. We believe that the rehearsal room is a place in which it should be safe for everyone, regardless of age, to revisit that unique sense of play. We gladly recognize any performer who is willing to explore new things, and encourage shyer individuals to trust their instincts. It is our goal that each cast member leaves our process knowing that there is something special inside of them, and we consider it our job as theatre educators to foster the confidence that will allow them to share that with others. In this way, theatre fulfills one of the core values of Christ Church: LIVING joyfully in faith.

Whether or not a child intends to pursue a career in the arts, exposure to theatre shapes important fundamentals, one of which is learning to function within a group. In our ensemble-based rehearsal process, it is extremely important that our performers not only learn to shine in the spotlight, but also to be great teammates - and occasionally audience members - along the way. In collaborating with each other, and also by exploring and interacting with unfamiliar settings and characters, performers will learn to see others' points of view, and to discuss the resulting emotions in healthy and constructive ways. This upholds another value of Christ Church: CONNECTING with God and one another.

It is our wish to never turn away an aspiring performer due to their inability to pay a program fee. To date, we have offered almost $2,000 in scholarships and waived fees to our participants. As you will read below, this is one of the reasons we hope to raise funds for our 2016-2017 season. No child should ever be told that they cannot afford to express themselves artistically, and as a society, we cannot afford to go without creative, well-rounded, and emotionally-intelligent youth. Combined with providing quality family entertainment for our audience members, we fulfill the third value of Christ Church: SERVING the local and global community.



Your Donation Will Go Towards ...

SCHOLARSHIPS
The first $2,000 raised by this campaign will be set aside solely for scholarships. No performer is ever turned away from CCP due to an inability to pay a performance fee. In exchange for a letter discussing why theatre is important to them, all performers are eligible for waived fees or full scholarships.

LICENSING RIGHTS
We must pay a fee for each show we produce; the more performances we offer, the higher the fee. It is important to us to offer multiple performances during each show, not only to reach as many audience members as possible (Cinderella sold out almost every night!), but also to give our casts as many special memories as possible. More often than not, we pay over $1,000 just for the right to mount a show. We hope to produce five shows this season, including our three summer workshops, and much of this campaign will assist in paying licensing rights.
COSTUMES
As we did with Cinderella, we hope to work with as many performers as possible this season. Unfortunately, when we accept so many performers, our costume budget absolutely explodes! Our generous and skilled Wardrobe Volunteers are able to work wonders, but we still require funds for sewing materials and thrift-shop finds! Please help us to ensure that every performer feels like a star.

LIGHTS & MICROPHONES
Christ Church, while stunning, is not equipped for full theatrical productions, and we are required to rent lights and microphones for each show. These vital elements certainly add up quickly. 


The Christ Church Players 2016 - 2017 Season

SUMMER of 2016
Theatre 1-2-3 is the educational summer component of CCP, an opportunity for young performers to build upon the skills and confidence necessary for success. Theatre 1-2-3 utilizes a leveled curriculum to provide its participants with training appropriate to their age and ability. Workshops are held from 9:00 am – 3:00 pm, Monday through Friday, during which participants will rehearse a musical to be performed for friends and family at the culmination of their session; when not rehearsing, participants will take classes taught by experienced theatre performers and educators, intended to expand their theatrical toolbox. In addition to spending time in a fun, safe, and creative environment, participants will leave Theatre 1-2-3 with improved skills in acting, singing, and dancing, a better understanding of the rehearsal process, and the kind of confidence that comes from socializing with like-minded friends, working together to create something to be proud of!

FALL of 2016
On the heels of our highly-successful production of Cinderella, we will produce another large-scale, mainstage musical this coming fall. It is our hope to once again have the means to accept every performer who auditions, and mount another colorful, whimsical, energetic production! 

SPRING of 2017
In the spring, we hope to offer a smaller musical tailored to performers who are considering exploring theatre seriously in the future. We have quite a few CCP members who would like to grow their skills with a more serious, challenging show. Due to the smaller cast, which translates to less production fees and often smaller audiences, the challenge will once again be for us to offset the costs involved!

Please Help to Spread the Word!
Whether or not you are able to contribute financially, we would be incredibly grateful if you helped to spread the word about CCP and our current fundraising campaign! We are always looking for new performers and volunteers, so please let any creative spirits in your life know about us. Use social media, email, or even word of mouth - and, as always, we certainly hope to see you at a show!
story_txt:
Who are the Christ Church Players ...

The Christ Church Players are a reemergence of youth theatre at Christ Episcopal Church in Exeter, New Hampshire. In the past, the youth theatre program created a safe space for children and teens to discover new truths about themselves, each other, and the world around them, and to share those truths with the community through the art of theatre.Founded by Suzanne Jalbert Jones, Director of Music at Christ Church, and her longtime collaborator Lexi Meunier, the newly-dubbed Christ Church Players serves as an important outreach ministry for young performers in the Exeter area, though many of its cast and audience are not members of the church. It is the belief of CCP that exposure to the performing arts helps to build the foundation of well-rounded and well-adjusted individuals for the betterment of our community.




... and who are Suzi & Lexi?

Suzanne Jalbert Jones has served as the music director and choral conductor for numerous theatre companies and churches throughout New Hampshire and Massachusetts. She currently directs the Christ Church Choir and Junior Choir, is on the faculty of the Performing Arts Connection in Sudbury, MA, and offers private lessons through her voice and piano studio. She is passionate about 19th and 20th century choral music and musical theatre, and was nominated for Best Musical Direction at the 2013 and 2014 EMACT DASH Awards. Suzanne holds a BM in Classical Voice Performance from the New England Conservatory of Music, as well as a Masters in Choral Conducting from the University of New Hampshire.Lexi Meunier began her theatrical career fifteen years ago in her hometown of Derry, New Hampshire, performing with programs much like CCP! A graduate of the Portland Actors Conservatory in Portland, Oregon, Lexi is on the faculty of the Performing Arts Connection in Sudbury, MA, and she serves as the Director of Theatre Education for the Haverhill branch of the North Shore YMCA Theatre Company. Lexi is currently studying English with a Theatre Arts concentration and Education minor at the University of Massachusetts: Lowell.Suzi and Lexi share the belief that exposure to the performing arts is extremely beneficial to youth, as it fosters emotional intelligence and communicative abilities, encourages a strong awareness of self and others, and increases both self-discipline and self-confidence. Best friends for over a decade, Suzi and Lexi have worked together both onstage and behind the scenes of numerous productions, and they are so very thrilled with the opportunity to share their love and knowledge of theatre with up-and-coming performers!




"Impossible Things Are Happening Every Day!"

Last fall, CCP mounted its debut production of Rodgers & Hammerstein's Cinderella, a show that was chosen in hopes that the story's popularity would help garner interest in this unknown theatre company. Maybe a dozen performers would be enough for a worthwhile production? Would we be lucky enough to have a full ensemble with twenty?Much to our surprise and elation, over fifty young performers auditioned for Cinderella, and we were blown away by not only the quantity of performers, but also by the quality; from the moment auditions began, we were met with so much enthusiasm, energy, and raw talent that we were left feeling giddily overwhelmed. We ultimately decided to accept every performer who was brave enough to audition, splitting the performers into two casts based on age. This allowed our older performers to be challenged, and our younger performers to take a turn in the spotlight. Both spirited casts absolutely blew away their audiences. Parents, performers, and patrons raved - and continue to rave! - about Cinderella, and it is with their support and encouragement that we embark on a full theatrical season."My husband and I have been so impressed by all your effort and care that you put into this show from the very beginning. Your communication with us and care of our children was truly outstanding! ... You created a lovely community there, and it showed both onstage and off. I have told many people just how impressed I've been with your professionalism as well as creating an environment for our children to feel nurtured, encouraged, and creative.""The girls absolutely LOVED being a part of Cinderella and still sing the songs all the time. (One even constructed "her own little corner" in her room, and I find her singing there quite often!) For both of them, the show provided a real window to discovery of interests and talents that they didn't know they had. What a gift! ... Beyond the performance, the whole experience of team-building was so positive - what a great group of kids and what a wonderful culture of support.""I just wanted to let you know how impressed my husband and I were with the entire production of Cinderella. ... I had no idea that this play would be such a positive and, in all honestly, life-changing experience for her! She loved every minute of it. She couldn't wait for play practice ... and just took on all responsibilities without needing us to nag her. She has officially been bitten by the acting bug and can't wait to be part of another production! ... Thank you so much for providing such a wonderful experience for our daughter and all of the kids that took part in the plays. There is nothing better than watching your child do what they love!"


The Importance of Theatre in Our Community
What excites us most about working with young performers is that children are natural masters at playing make-believe and utilizing their imaginations, which makes them inherently talented performers. Unfortunately, as children mature, the spaces in which they are allowed to touch base with that creativity become limited. We believe that the rehearsal room is a place in which it should be safe for everyone, regardless of age, to revisit that unique sense of play. We gladly recognize any performer who is willing to explore new things, and encourage shyer individuals to trust their instincts. It is our goal that each cast member leaves our process knowing that there is something special inside of them, and we consider it our job as theatre educators to foster the confidence that will allow them to share that with others. In this way, theatre fulfills one of the core values of Christ Church: LIVING joyfully in faith.Whether or not a child intends to pursue a career in the arts, exposure to theatre shapes important fundamentals, one of which is learning to function within a group. In our ensemble-based rehearsal process, it is extremely important that our performers not only learn to shine in the spotlight, but also to be great teammates - and occasionally audience members - along the way. In collaborating with each other, and also by exploring and interacting with unfamiliar settings and characters, performers will learn to see others' points of view, and to discuss the resulting emotions in healthy and constructive ways. This upholds another value of Christ Church: CONNECTING with God and one another.It is our wish to never turn away an aspiring performer due to their inability to pay a program fee. To date, we have offered almost $2,000 in scholarships and waived fees to our participants. As you will read below, this is one of the reasons we hope to raise funds for our 2016-2017 season. No child should ever be told that they cannot afford to express themselves artistically, and as a society, we cannot afford to go without creative, well-rounded, and emotionally-intelligent youth. Combined with providing quality family entertainment for our audience members, we fulfill the third value of Christ Church: SERVING the local and global community.


Your Donation Will Go Towards ...SCHOLARSHIPSThe first $2,000 raised by this campaign will be set aside solely for scholarships. No performer is ever turned away from CCP due to an inability to pay a performance fee. In exchange for a letter discussing why theatre is important to them, all performers are eligible for waived fees or full scholarships.LICENSING RIGHTS
We must pay a fee for each show we produce; the more performances we offer, the higher the fee. It is important to us to offer multiple performances during each show, not only to reach as many audience members as possible (Cinderella sold out almost every night!), but also to give our casts as many special memories as possible. More often than not, we pay over $1,000 just for the right to mount a show. We hope to produce five shows this season, including our three summer workshops, and much of this campaign will assist in paying licensing rights.
COSTUMES
As we did with Cinderella, we hope to work with as many performers as possible this season. Unfortunately, when we accept so many performers, our costume budget absolutely explodes! Our generous and skilled Wardrobe Volunteers are able to work wonders, but we still require funds for sewing materials and thrift-shop finds! Please help us to ensure that every performer feels like a star.
LIGHTS & MICROPHONESChrist Church, while stunning, is not equipped for full theatrical productions, and we are required to rent lights and microphones for each show. These vital elements certainly add up quickly. 







The Christ Church Players 2016 - 2017 SeasonSUMMER of 2016

Theatre 1-2-3 is the educational summer component of CCP, an opportunity for young performers to build upon the skills and confidence necessary for success. Theatre 1-2-3 utilizes a leveled curriculum to provide its participants with training
appropriate to their age and ability. Workshops are held from 9:00 am – 3:00
pm, Monday through Friday, during which participants will rehearse a musical to
be performed for friends and family at the culmination of their session; when
not rehearsing, participants will take classes taught by experienced theatre
performers and educators, intended to expand their theatrical toolbox. In
addition to spending time in a fun, safe, and creative environment,
participants will leave Theatre 1-2-3 with improved skills in acting, singing,
and dancing, a better understanding of the rehearsal process, and the kind of
confidence that comes from socializing with like-minded friends, working
together to create something to be proud of!









FALL of 2016
On the heels of our highly-successful production of Cinderella, we will produce another large-scale, mainstage musical this coming fall. It is our hope to once again have the means to accept every performer who auditions, and mount another colorful, whimsical, energetic production! 
SPRING of 2017
In the spring, we hope to offer a smaller musical tailored to performers who are considering exploring theatre seriously in the future. We have quite a few CCP members who would like to grow their skills with a more serious, challenging show. Due to the smaller cast, which translates to less production fees and often smaller audiences, the challenge will once again be for us to offset the costs involved!
Please Help to Spread the Word!Whether or not you are able to contribute financially, we would be incredibly grateful if you helped to spread the word about CCP and our current fundraising campaign! We are always looking for new performers and volunteers, so please let any creative spirits in your life know about us. Use social media, email, or even word of mouth - and, as always, we certainly hope to see you at a show!

story:
ABOUT ME:

Gunnar Montana is a Philadelphia-based choreographer and performance artist who's work has appeared in festivals across the region, including the Philadelphia FringeArts Festival and ThinkFest, as well as in several venues across the City.
Infusing movement and visual arts, Gunnar's work refuses to be defined. His artistry as a whole is an array of visual art installations, prop-based choreography, set design, costume design, transformation of atmosphere, and innovative movement, concepts, and ideas.  Gunnar attended The University of the Arts, graduating in 2011 with a BFA in Modern Dance Performance and a profound interest in choreography and creative movement. 

_________________________________________


MERCHANDISE:

The Official Gunnar Montana Sticker Set:

Get the Gunnar Montana Sticker Set!

Includes 6 circular stickers, size 3"x3". 

International shipping included.

_________________________________________________________

Gunnar Montana Show Prints:

Get the Gunnar Montana Show Prints!

Includes 5 signed prints, size 5" x 7" 

Chronicle the evolution of Gunnar Montana's work over the course of three years. These prints were specially designed and created by Gunnar to represent and capture the essence of his past five productions.

International shipping included.

________________________________________________________

Gunnar Montana Commemorative Show Posters:

Get the Gunnar Montana Commemorative Show Posters!

Includes 6 mini posters, size 9.5" x 7.5" 

Chronicle the evolution of Gunnar Montana's work over the course of four years with these mini show posters! 

International shipping included.


RECENT WORK:

Check out some of the cool things we've been working on:

For more recent works visit my WEBSITE or INSTAGRAM profile. 

How Will I Make Arrangements For My Perks?
Shortly after making your contribution to Gunnar Montana's Wroughtland campaign, a member of Gunnar's team will contact you to make arrangements to have your merchandise and benefits shipped, and/or your backstage tour scheduled.  

How Soon Will The Perks Be Shipped?

The team at Gunnar Montana Productions is committed to getting swag in your hands within 30 days of your contribution.  We want you to enjoy your perks as soon as possible! 

Where Do I Go With More Questions?

If you have any question or concern, please send us an email at mrgunnarmontana@gmail.com and we will answer as soon as possible!

If you like our project but you can't contribute, please consider 
sharing it using the share buttons under the video with your friends and family. 

This will help us to spread the word! Thank you!

story:
The Grumpiest Boy in the World

Northwestern University's Purple Crayon Players Presents:
The Grumpiest Boy in the World
(or: Zachary Briddling, Who Was Awfully Middling)
A play for 5-9 year olds

Written by: Finegan Kruckemeyer
Songs by: Darren Clark
Directed by: Julianne Lang
Produced by: Josh Krivan

Northwestern University, Shanley Pavilion

November 17, 7:30pm

November 18, 7:30pm

November 19, 11am, 2pm, 7:30pm

About Purple Crayon Players

Northwestern University's the Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theater company devoted to creating, performing and spreading high-quality theater for young audiences.

About The Grumpiest Boy In the World

The Grumpiest Boy in the World is Purple Crayon Player's Fall Quarter Production and the North American Premiere of Kruckemeyer's play. The story of Zachary Briddling, a seven-year-old boy, who, upon finding himself to be absolutely not unique in any way, decides to set upon a fantastic journey to find some place where he will be the strangest, the weirdest and the most bizarre creature the people have ever seen.

Why We Need Your Help

When you donate to The Grumpiest Boy in the World, you'll be helping us to create an unbelievable production, including:

An creative and beautiful set designed by our wonderful Space Designer, Alex Dayton

Gorgeously colorful costumes designed by our unbelievable Costume Designer, Hannah Perez

Hair and Makeup for the incredibly talented Hair and Makeup Designer, Megan Culligan

Lights for our fantastic Lighting Designer, Sara Torres, to illuminate our actors' shining faces

Sound equipment for our awesome Sound Designer, Jonathan Mathias, to create cool effects and make sure the actors can be heard!

Workshops before and after the show at local grade schools for kids to interact with the Grumpiest Boy team!

What You Get Out Of It

Perks:

  • Personalized Thank Yous!
  • Merch!!
  • Ad Space!
  • Autographed & Framed Photos!
  • Our eternal love and gratitude!

Who's Who on the Team

Meet the Cast:

Zachary: Michelle Kim

Dad/Others: Mat Benson

Mom/Others: Makaa Copeland

Scientist 1/Others: Stefan Schallack

Scientist 2/Others: Marissa Ferrara

Meet the Production Team:

Producer: Josh Krivan

Director: Julianne Lang

Assistant Director: Hannah Merens

Stage Manager: Abbey Kutlas

Assistant Stage Manager: Shane Eichstaedt

Space Designer: Alex Dayton

Space Assistant: Connor Scott

Space Assistant: Clare Mclaughlin

Lighting Designer: Sara Torres

Assistant Lighting Designer: Ying Dai

Costume Designer: Hannah Perez

Costumes Assistant/Mentor: Emily Blim

Sound Designer: Jonathan Mathias

Hair and Makeup Designer: Megan Culligan

Music Director: Rose Packer

Technical Director: Becca Schwartz

Graphic Designer: Alex Schneidman

Outreach Director: Kelsey Robins

Publicity Director: Dawn Rafal

Fundraising Director: Arthur Mergner

How Can I Help?

  • Donate
  • Come see our show!
  • Share The Link and Tell People About Our Show
  • Contact Arthur Mergner with any questions, inquiries or requests at ArthurMergner2020@u.northwestern.edu

We are incredibly grateful for any way you can help us to create this fantastic production and look forward to seeing you in Shanley Pavilion on November 17th-19th!

Love,

The Cast, Crew and Production Team of The Grumpiest Boy in the World

story:
Let's Keep Live Theatre Alive!

Hello, dear friends!

My name is Dan Kostelec, and I’m the guy who plays your friendly, neighbourhood Shakespeare at Renaissance Faires, schools and more all over the country in my one-man, audience-interactive, improvisational Shakespeare show, “Shakespeare Approves!” I take some of the Bard’s plays and turn them into half-hour, live-action, interactive cartoons where the audience members are the actors, props, and scenery.

The COVID-19 crisis has shut down everything, renaissance faires and theaters included - and some of the most vulnerable people in our increasingly-gig-based economy are your favorite performers in theatre and renaissance festivals.

Piggy-backing on the success of the first three shows (12th Night & the 3 Bears!, Romeo & Juliet: The Flying Implement of Doom Edition!, Julius Caesar: Beware the Ides March of the Penguins!, and A Midsummer Night's Dream: A Gaye Olde Tyme!) performed by our new online theatre company, The Social Distancing Players , we're back with our fifth performance of online, irreverent, quasi-improvisational, audience-interactive family fun with Macbeth: Death by Fluffy Kittens!

Actors from various theatre companies and some of your favorite Ren Faire acts will be performing a live reading adapted from my stage show that is normally produced at festivals as an audience-interactive, improvisational show.

I'm looking to raise at least $1,100.00 for this performance, so that I can guarantee each performer a minimum of $100 (and hopefully more!) for their time in bringing us joy and laughter. And that's where you come in. We need your help to make it happen!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1,100. Okay - that part was pretty straight-forward

What do you get?

A part in the show! And also much more!

If you're familiar with my live, in-person ren faire show, you know that I use the audience members as my cast, the set, even as some of the props. So keeping with that tradition, if you are able to donate to this cause, the first 5 people to donate $50 or more will get to be in the show (all roles are first-come, first served). Yeah, it sounds like pay-to-play, because it is. But if you can afford it, I guarantee that you'll have a marvelous time!

Roles Available

King Duncan     Prince Malcolm     Macduff's Family     The King's Messenger

Prince Donalbain     Lady Macduff     The Army

 

But wait — there’s more!

Let’s say you have some cash but can’t afford to go up to $50. For $10 you can get a "seat at the show"! You'll have the best seat in the house - your house! - but can join the actors "backstage" before and after the show in our private Zoom meeting, and interact with the actors and your fellow audience members in a private chat. Plus, you're seeing the show 45 seconds before the folks on Facebook and YouTube!

Well, for $30 you can get a copy of the performance script signed by the author (that’s me!).

And if you’re feeling particularly generous and want to donate $100 - well, you get some goodies! You get the signed performance script, a part in the show (if you desire, and if they haven’t been snatched up yet — all roles are first-come, first served), AND a personalized sonnet commissioned JUST FOR YOU (a $20 value).

The Impact

You will directly be helping professional entertainers keep "professional" as part of their job title, by helping us to pay our bills, buy our groceries (when we dare to venture outside during this social distancing period), and not sink deeper into poverty or credit card debt.

You're helping to extend hope and build morale for our fellow members of humanity by giving them a much-needed distraction during this crisis, a sense that a return-to-normal is not just possible but inevitable.

You're keeping live theatre alive.
 

Other Ways You Can Help


Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Share this campaign with your friends, family, even enemies!

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you. I love you - you love me - there is mutual, glorious affection!

Well, for $30 you can get a copy of the performance script signed by the author (that’s me!).
And if you’re feeling particularly generous and want to donate $100 - well, you get some goodies! You get the signed performance script, a part in the show (if you desire, and if they haven’t been snatched up yet — all roles are first-come, first served), AND a personalized sonnet commissioned JUST FOR YOU (a $20 value).
The Impact
You will directly be helping professional entertainers keep "professional" as part of their job title, by helping us to pay our bills, buy our groceries (when we dare to venture outside during this social distancing period), and not sink deeper into poverty or credit card debt.
You're helping to extend hope and build morale for our fellow members of humanity by giving them a much-needed distraction during this crisis, a sense that a return-to-normal is not just possible but inevitable.
You're keeping live theatre alive. 
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:Share this campaign with your friends, family, even enemies!
And that's all there is to it.
Thank you. I love you - you love me - there is mutual, glorious affection!

story:
What is this???

Hi! My name is Michael Dreger & I'm a recent graduate from Cornish College's Original Works program. I've used Indiegogo previously to raise funds for 3 different theatre productions, affording each: costumes, set pieces, & stipends for our production team...
And I'm back at it again!!! With a story. That is. Incredible!!
Crafted by Heather L. Earnhardt, The Wandering Goose is a poignant piece on love, set to the tone of a children's fable. It follows relationship of a Bug in her garden & a wandering Goose, as they explore what it means to love & lose.
It comes alive onstage as a theatrical adaptation by Clara Hayes & myself. I am currently working with an awesome team of actors & designers, bringing this story to live as vibrantly as it sits on the page!! But we need help!!
I believe in paying artists for their work & make it my goal every project to make sure my team is compensated. Any donations to this project will serve to pay for costumes, set, & hard working artists!!
They will be met with endless gratitude...and even some perks!

The Perks!!

Like I said, we only need enough for costumes, set & team. 

The set & costumes are budgeted to run a cumulative $250 dollars.

Then comes paying the team. We have a:

Lighting Designer

Sound Designer

Set Designer

Costumer

Photographer

Poster Designer

3 Actors

&  Assistant Director!!

Whatever we can raise will go right to these amazing artists. And of course we wouldn't ask without something to return!!

We have everything from reserved seats, to photos, to signed posters, to talk backs with the actors (and maybe even the author!!!) Help Us Help You!!! :) 

The Impact

This story isn't just a typical "Bug meets Goose" thing. This is real. This is relatable. This is heart wrenching. And absolutely beautiful. I have never felt so impassioned about creating a piece of work; from the moment I read Heather's book, I was hooked. 

This story deserves a large stage and even larger audience. It's message transcends age, religion, weight, race, sexuality, & gender. It's about who we are at our core and how we connect with others.

Risks & Challenges

The only risk of this process is not attaining the funding we need to cover expenses. It would mean we can't get some pieces and our team wouldn't get paid. 

But I'm certain we can raise the money we need . We're ambitious and we can make this happen together!! I've worked on campaigns before and I'm sure this won't be my last!! 

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you cannot donate, don't worry. Just your support and sharing of this page will help us jump the hurdles we need to put up this beautiful show!!

That and if anyone has flowers they don't mind us putting in a staged garden...Let me know! :)

story:
Check out our NEW VIDEOS by clicking on the 'Gallery' tab above!

Here's the Rub

What this project is and what it does:

  • The Last Days of Judas Iscariot explores the conflict between mercy and Free Will, as the fate of history's most notorious sinner is put before a judge. However, in Purgatory, no one is safe from judgement as Mother Teresa, Pontius Pilate, Satan, and more are brought to the stand to testify. The play argues both sides and asks big questions in search of truth. 
  • This campaign will allow Stage of Fools to gain exposure in a market that relies so heavily on results. It is our privilege to select plays that we are passionate about and work with talented artists, however, the continuation of our work requires contributions and support of the audience. Thats YOU!

The Fools behind the curtain.

Stage of Fools is a new Theatre group in Minneapolis, MN as of 2015. The group consists of 4 young Theatre Artists of different origins, from different education and training, but with one common goal. This is essentially our mission: Through our diverse styles, to create a collective vision for every project and to inspire audiences (as a whole) to engage in stories and ask important questions regardless of demographic. YOU are our future!

What We Need 

All of the funds contributed will go to:
  • Performance Space Rental ($1,050): The play will be produced at Art House North in St. Paul, MN. Art House charges a $175 fee for every day we are in the theater, whether that be for finalizing light and sound cues during Technical Rehearsals, or for nightly performances.   
  • Lighting Rental ($500-$700): Art House is an unconventional theater space so it doesn't have standard equipment for theatrical lighting. In order to bring a specific focus to the stage, we will be requiring the rental of minimal Set Lighting. 
  • Copyright Fee ($400): Seasoned Theater Companies usually have annual funds set aside for preliminary costs such as Rights and Scripts. As a brand new company, we don't have that luxury, so we will need to cover the cost of Rights for The Last Days of Judas Iscariot.
  • Artist Compensation (?): It's always a little painful that this comes last. All actors who have agreed to this production never questioned or mentioned money as a factor. They have all voiced their excitement and gratitude for being able to have a platform to exercise their passion and be a part of telling such a powerful story. With that said, any leftover contributions will be distributed evenly in stipends to actors. This may cover their out-of-pocket costs (travel, meal expenses for extended rehearsals, and time away from additional/survival jobs).
  • "It's about the unknown": If we reach or surpass our goal, additional revenue goes toward planning for the future of Stage of Fools. If we don' reach our target goal, we adapt to the situation, scale down some of the production's enhancements, and remain focusing on the project and most importantly, the people. Theatre is so much about the process rather than the result. The result may fall short but we will never give up on the plan.

The Impact

Here is how your contribution helps the bigger picture:

  • As said previously, the Twin Cities Theater Market relies heavily on results. "Profitable" results often are THE deciding factor in how larger companies choose the plays they will put in their season, the creative staff that work on each project, and the actors who are cast in roles. With your support for our vision and project, we can break down some of those unfortunate barriers and harness a specificity for unique perspectives and risk-taking projects that still maintain the highest level of quality, artistry, and professionalism. YOU can help us shake things up!

Other ways you can help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean YOU can't help:

  • SHARE this campaign anywhere and everywhere! Check out Indiegogo's share tools!
  • Support our company on Social Media. We have links to those outlets on THIS campaign. Check 'em out!
  • Have other ways you'd like to support or donate? Let us know!

Verdict

All the details you need:
  • The Last Days Of Judas Iscariot by Stephen Adly Guirgis
  • Producer: Stage Of Fools Theatre Company
  • Director: Alex Goebel
  • Location: Art House North (793 Armstrong Ave W, St Paul, MN 55102)
  • Performance Dates: ONLY FOUR SHOWS - December 4, 5, 11, & 12th at 7:30pm
  • Reserve Tickets Here: http://stageoffools.brownpapertickets.com/
