Reserve Tickets Here: http://stageoffools.brownpapertickets.com/

story:
House Play a new play by Diana Lynn Small will have its world premiere in Austin, TX in June 2019 by Salvage Vanguard Theater. 

Like its preceding show, Mad & a Goat, House Play is being developed with artists across the country--James Hapke / Marie Ponce / Paige Tautz in California, Heather Johnson in Colorado,  Kate Taylor in Texas, and Diana Lynn Small / Tyler Gobble in Indiana. Following February's workshop in Indiana and June's premiere in Texas, the show will be toured to a variety of hometowns & beloved locations, with an emphasis on places without traditional theaters. 

We’re gathering in Elwood, IN in February 2020 to rehearse the play and share it with a preview audience for the first time. We're raising money to help support this final workshop and to launch the play after its premiere. 

House Play is a new play performed around your dinner table. Part meal and part fairy tale, House Play is a dark comedy that follows three young girls who have been left for dead in the woods as they adopt new identities in order to survive: a Woman, an Animal and a Sibyl. It’s like if Lord of the Flies was a dark comedy, used household items as puppets, and featured female characters. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We need your help to fund our Workshop Production in Indiana ($2000) and to fund the first chapter of our House Tour after the Austin, TX premiere ($3000). These expenses help cover travel, artist fees and show supplies:

February Workshop...

  • Airfare for 5 collaborators: $1500
  • Communal meals for all 7 collaborators for 1 week: $150 
  • $50 Stipends for all 7 collaborators: $350

 

House Tour, Chapter 1...

  • Airfare & Travel: $2000
  • Marketing & Outreach: $150
  • Artist Pay: $700
  • Artist meals: $150
  • *Any funds we raise over $5,000 will go towards tour costs, specifically, boosting artist pay.

 

To express our thanks for your generosity and support of new theater, we have handmade gifts from the House Play team: nutrition coaching, unique recipes, clown kits for kids of all ages, original music, drawings and poetry.

 

The Impact

House Play will transform dining room tables into imaginative storytelling spaces, focused on towns that don't have access to new plays and experimental art. The play will be toured, granting the artists and audiences opportunities to meet new folks "in the middle of nowhere" places. We believe that people fall in love over good food and stories. We’d like to be responsible for more of that. 

While the Austin premiere is covered by support from Salvage Vanguard Theater, your support will allow us to tighten up the show before that important run, as well as get us financially ahead for the small-towns tour at the heart of the show; this stability will allow us to confidently take the show to other communities in need of experimental art experiences

 

Risks & Challenges

The great thing about live theater is that it can fail--someone can forget a line, a prop could disintegrate right in your midst / our mitts, an audience member might be confused & begin asking the person sitting next to them in too-loud-a-voice “WHAT THE HECK IS HAPPENING?” This fundraising campaign, your support, & our hard-work leading up (including our YEARS working together) is assurance that we’ll be best prepared & better ready for any challenges that the chosen kitchen table might bring us.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate every dollar we get, as it goes towards the spreading of this production across the country. If you’d like to contribute in other ways, you can add us on Instagram (@houseplay_), spread the word through your social media accounts, & tell interested friends & family about this effort. If you’d like us to come to your town for a House Play run, feel free to donate the $5000 for a personal House Play production, or reach out about other opportunities.

story:
CITY OF LIGHT - SEANCES, SPIRITS, AND LIGHT OPERA?

Hello! My name is Michael McFaden, and I am the author of the book and lyrics for the new light opera, City of Light.  Part fact, part fiction, City of Light explores the continuity of life after death as experienced in the tiny community of Lily Dale, New York, through the lesser-known music of Sir Arthur Sullivan. 

So, what is Lily Dale? Founded in the 1870's as a summer camp, and a favorite locale of Susan B. Anthony to hold suffragette rallies, Lily Dale became a mecca for free-thinkers, as well as the home of the Spiritualist religion.   Harry Houdini actively persecuted the mediums of Lily Dale in order to expose frauds, but Sir Arthur Canon Doyle was an ardent believer.  Even Hollywood legend Mae West consulted one of Lily Dale's most famous mediums on a regular basis.  Today, Lily Dale is a quiet village, a shadow of its former self.  Yet, the curious still visit.  And in 2010, I was one of the curious.

Sparked by my fascination with Lily Dale and combined with a keen interest in the operettas of Gilbert & Sullivan, I conceived the idea of writing a light opera in the style of that famous duo, using Lily Dale as the backdrop.  I started researching Sullivan's music - specifically compositions he wrote apart from Gilbert.  And from the scores of six light operas, one grand opera, two religious oratorios and one part song, City of Light was born, helping to preserve the music of Sir Arthur Sullivan by presenting to the public an entirely new Sullivan score.  Most people only know Sullivan's music through the combined works of Gilbert & Sullivan.  Yet Sullivan was a very prolific composer outside of that famous collaboration.  Most of his music outside of the G&S canon is forgotten today, buried in obsolete works difficult to revive.  But City of Light allows some of these lost jewels to shine once again and, hopefully, will help to create a new appreciation for this Victorian composer. 

Last year City of Light won the first new musical competition sponsored by the Boiler Room Theatre in Franklin, TN.  The prize is to be a full production at the Boiler Room Theatre this September (2013).  However, the theatre is not going to be able to handle all of the production costs.  The Boiler Room is providing the performance space, online advertising, front of house support, and the like.  But all sets, costumes and lighting are limited to what the theatre has on hand. I am responsible for any additional costs such as musical arrangements, rehearsal space rental, specialty set pieces and costumes, and any additional promotion.

Most importantly, if the individual actors and musicians are to be compensated, that money will also have to be raised by me.  City of Light has a cast of about twenty, plus four musicians.  Many of these people have been with this project since its first readings early last year.  And in some cases, actors commute as many as ninety miles for rehearsals.  Up until now, I have been unable to offer any of these individuals any compensation at all for their time and talent.  Your donations will help show my appreciation for their commitment and hard work.  Artists deserve to be compensated.  And that, my friends, is why I need your help.

What we need and what you get

Launching a new musical is a monumental undertaking.  Few theatres are willing to take risks with unknown, untried works; even Broadway seems to be producing only adaptations from the movies.  So to get a local theatre with an established reputation to take a chance on something new is very exciting.  This production will help provide the groundwork needed to take City of Light even further in the future.  But, stated bluntly, producing a show requires finances.

The amount we are shooting for is $6,000.  That really is not a whole lot of money to produce a big musical, but I am trying to keep the goal achievable.  Once the expenses of mounting the show have been achieved, the remainder of the money will go directly to the musicians and the actors.  In essence, look at your contribution as sponsoring an artist.  If the goal is surpassed, then there will be more to share with those who are giving so generously of their time and talents.  I am keeping none of this money for myself.  Please remember that Indiegogo keeps 4% of any monies raised. (And if the goal is not achieved, Indiegogo keeps 9%.)  So every dollar helps.  I encourage you to give what you can.

For you, the donors, I have tried to come up with an interesting array of unique perks - Lily Dale souvenirs, cast recordings of the show, tickets to the performances of City of Light, and telephone readings with a registered Lily Dale medium.  Four donors at the top level will even receive a stay in this lovely cottage on the grounds of Lily Dale! 

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!!  The wonderful thing about technology today is that we can spread the word about this show with just a keystroke or two.  Please share information about Ctiy of Light with your Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr, Google+, and other social media site followers!  "Like" us on Facebook.  Help me raise the capital I need to give City of Light a proper, professional production.  Indiegogo has share tools designed to help in this manner.  Plus, if you have any questions about the show, I invite you to contact me personally at mmcfaden@aol.com

Thank you!

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!!  The wonderful thing about technology today is that we can spread the word about this show with just a keystroke or two.  Please share information about Ctiy of Light with your Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr, Google+, and other social media site followers!  "Like" us on Facebook.  Help me raise the capital I need to give City of Light a proper, professional production.  Indiegogo has share tools designed to help in this manner.  Plus, if you have any questions about the show, I invite you to contact me personally at mmcfaden@aol.com
Thank you!

story:
My Name is Gabriel Gastelo and I am an undergraduate dance major at Arizona State University. I have been working on the production crew for the school of dance for the last school year. I hope with this adventure to ADF I can bring back all the knowledge and experience I gain at ADF back to my ASU community! With this campaign you will be helping my get across the country via car! I will be traveling from Tempe, Arizona to Durham, North Carolina!

I set a goal of $600 for the trip, this would cover the cost of gas to drive across the county and back home again! The trip will take over 32 hours of travel time, and the distance is roughly 2,150 miles of travel. I choose to go via a car in hopes to document my travels, something that I will share with all those who would like to contribute!

In preperation for this trip I applied for a grant from ASU and was awarded $1600 to cover room and board whiile I am there. I will also get a stipend from ADF for working as a production intern which will total $1100, and that money will go to covering my expenses in AZ for the two months that I am away.

When I applied for this internship initially I was contacted and told that the positions have been filed. I was then offered a stage craft apprentiship postition instead (which was not a stipend positon), I was then contacted about a month ago and was told that one of the Production Interns was unable to commit to the summer. So then I was offered that persons spot, and I gladly expected! Things for this venture have fallen nicely in place, and I hope this campaign will be one of those things!

 

If you'd like to follow me on this adventure I will be posting on these social media outlets!

 

instagram: ggastelo

Twitter: @ggastelo86

Tumblr: ggastelo.tumblr.com

story:
Who We Are

Representation matters, but it is twofold. For too long queer stories have lived on the periphery of narratives explored on stage and in film. It is not enough to just tell the stories of queer individuals, it is imperative that we are included in the creation of them.

Here. strives to champion the work of LGBTQ+ artists, by presenting traditional narratives through a queer perspective. We invite audiences to break down the boundaries within their imagination and experience a world in which our narrative is ever present.

Our inaugural production, Paramour, is a multi-generational LGBTQ love story that examines the intricacies and sacrifices of queer love through the use of heightened language.

Piera Van de Wiel (Co-founder and Producer), Jennifer Parkhill (Co-founder and Director), and John Anthony Loffredo (Co-founder and Playwright)

What We Need & What You Get

With your support, we were able to raise $3,605 in our initial campaign. These funds allowed us to secure a beautiful performance venue in downtown Manhattan for our production this July. We were also able to invest in promotional photos as well as put our money towards renting rehearsal spaces and other pre-production costs.

We are proud to have raised 72% of our goal in the first campaign, this time we are hoping to make up the difference. The funds we raise in this campaign will go towards:

  • Rehearsal space
  • Costumes
  • Props and set pieces
  • Insurance and other incidentals

The Impact

All too often queer artists are left out of the telling of our own stories and we are trying to change that. Here. hopes to bring LGBTQ+ art made by LGBTQ+ artists to the forefront of our society. Your support, in the form of a campaign contribution or social media shout out, brings us one step closer to our ultimate goal--changing the way our culture values LGBTQ+ artists. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, please share our campaign! Sharing this campaign on social media, in LGBTQ+ advocacy groups, artist groups, and on your personal pages would be a big help in getting our mission out into the world! 

If you read this campaign and know of artists in your community who may wish to be involved, please pass this along. We hope to expand our network of queer artists of every discipline and would appreciate your help in connecting us.

With heartfelt gratitude and much love,

Here. Artist Collective

story:
The 2018 Doomsday Clock says it is "2 Minutes to Midnight."

Scum says “Game on."

Humble Beginnings

It all began in a Washington Heights Apartment in March 2018, when Sarah Shear gathered her friends together for a reading of a play she had recently finished. This first read only confirmed what we already believed - that this play was not only enjoyable and compelling, but a poignant, humorous, thought-provoking story about four friends doing their best to survive in unimaginable conditions. People needed to see this play, and we needed to make it happen.

With Sarah's initiative, a team was assembled (like the post-apocalyptic theatre Avengers) to get the play up on its feet. We had our first public reading of the play at The Chipped Cup on April 14th, 2018 and the response we received was absolutely overwhelming. People responded to these characters, as if they could easily be their own friends, and found themselves questioning what their own survival instincts would be in the apocalypse. It was an enthusiasm that matched our own, so we knew it was time to give this play the fully-staged production it deserves. And as the characters in the play teach us, there is no time like the present

The Big Hurdle

The only thing standing in our way now is the price tag. We need a performance space, rehearsal space, props, costumes, lights, crew, and actors. We believe in compensating everyone for the time, energy, and talent it takes to put on a quality show. While we will be a non-union production, the Scum Team refuses to ask people to work for free. This has become a crucial component in our need to fundraise.

We've created a budget for the production, as outlined below:

Performance Space: $2,500
Rehearsal Space (55 hours): $1,000
Set, Costumes, Props: $500
Stipends (divided between Actors, Production Team, Designers): $1,200
Marketing: $300

What It Means To Us

"Aside from being passionate about women telling women’s stories, what’s exciting about Scum is the immediacy of the piece. We’ve heard “I know these people” over and over again, wherever Scum goes. Toxicity is addressed through this piece fearlessly and asks the audience, “So what do we do now? How can we make the world a better place?” And somehow it’s funny, too! It’s an incredibly special piece and I’m excited to share our 2023 with 2018." - Sarah Shear, Playwright

"I love the raw energy of Scum - it cooks, pummeling you with its dialogue. By the end, once the dust settles, what you're left with is actually a very tender, earnest warning about the ride we just took. And where it might be heading if continue on it." - Javan Nelson, Director

"Beyond the fact that I love this piece, it is so exciting to be a part of team producing new work written by a female artist who writes such fleshed out, honest characters. You really feel like you know these people, and the journey they go on challenges the audience as much as it challenges them. New work is the backbone of our industry, and it's a joy and an honor to be a part of the process of bringing it to life." - Becca Barrett, Marketing Producer

"This project brings out parts of the friends and acquaintances I have made that I never would have seen otherwise. I can't think of anything more important or essential to the world of theater than a work that can do that." - Ross Lampert, Executive Producer and Dramaturg

Other Ways You Can Help

- You can share this campaign with your friends, family, and country(wo)men on any and all social media! Be sure to tag us @scumtheplay on Facebook and Instagram and use our hashtag, #TheGameBegins

- You can audition! We will be holding auditions following the campaign and we would love to see you there.

- Once we’ve reach our goal, COME SEE THE SHOW! Celebrate new artists telling new stories.

- You can advertise in our program! If you run a business and would like to buy ad space, you can email scumtheplay@gmail.com

story:
WHO ARE WE

Founded in 2018, the Village Conservatory for Music Theatre (or ViC) is the brainchild of Paul De Gurse, Jacqueline Harding and Simon Miron.

Our partner Winnipeg Studio Theatre (or WST) is a non-profit company founded in 2006 devoted to creating, developing and producing Canadian and international contemporary plays and musicals in an intimate setting.

OUR MISSION

The ViC is an arts education organization dedicated to providing high quality post secondary music theatre education in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

WST's goals are educational and developmental, combining a mix of original, traditional and experimental theatre where creativity can emerge and artists of different disciplines can discover and work together.

WHAT WE DO

The ViC is currently focused on producing a series of music theatre workshops in the fall and winter of 2018/19. The goal of these workshops is to train and educate performers who will be participating Winnipeg Studio Theatre’s winter 2019 production of Pippin. These workshops will also be available to the general public.

Through the StudioWorks Academy, WST has been offering training to young people for over 12 years. WST is devoted to developing emerging talent in Winnipeg.

WHY THE CAMPAIGN

The ViC and WST were offered a unique sponsorship from long time arts patron Debbie Gray. Debbie has offered to match every donation towards emerging artist program up to a maximum of $3500. This is a unique opportunity to make a difference to an emerging artist, and all of us at the ViC and WST wanted to get the word out!

Pick a Character Perk and help support local theatre! Click on the Perk for more details. Tax receipts will be issued and your name will appear in the program for Pippin.

​Pick a Perk before Feb. 24th and be entered to win a KEITH LEVIT framed photo.

To learn more about the ViC and WST go to:

https://www.facebook.com/villageconservatory/

https://winnipegstudiotheatre.com/

story:
About the Project

Brave Spirits Theatre, the Washington DC Metropolitan area’s premiere producer of little-known early modern plays, is proud to announce an (almost) entirely re-gendered production of both parts of Shakespeare’s classic coming-of-age saga, Henry the Fourth.

"Washington is blessed to have young, creative, multi-talented emerging companies like Brave Spirits here." -- MD Theatre Guide

In Part One, Queen Henri has a problem -- she faces rebellion from the north, from the Countess of Northumberland and her daughter, Hotspur; and in the west the “wild and irregular” Glendower plots her own insurrection. Civil war is on the horizon, and Henri’s tenuous claim to the throne is threatened -- but that’s nothing compared to her problems at home. Hallie, Henri’s eldest daughter and heir, is less interested in affairs of state than in carousing around the seedy London neighborhood of Eastcheap with her friend, Jill Falstaff. Part One culminates in an epic battle between the Henri’s forces and the rebels.

In Part Two, military drama takes a backseat to the issues of the family. As Henri nears death, she worries about Hallie’s ability to lead the nation she is leaving behind. Falstaff’s comic exploits in the Gloucester countryside lighten the mood, and the play ends on a bittersweet note as the young Hallie comes into her own as Henri V.

Support Female Artists

Besides gender-flipping the characters and performing the two plays with a cast of ten women and two men, Brave Spirits has assembled a production and design team that is 80% comprised of female artists.

In these productions, women get to play iconic Shakespeare roles, make jokes, fight fight for what they believe in, talk about sex, grow up, get angry, get passionate, sing songs, ruminate on getting older, and argue about what's best for a family and what's best for a country.

This is our largest production team and most ambitious project and will cost around $13,000. Ticket sales will only cover a portion of our expenses, especially as we are committed to affordable ticket prices. The campaign amount is focused on helping pay stipends to the actors. The actors will have put in up to 150 hours of rehearsal time each once we open. Please help us support the work they do.

"[Brave Spirits has a] kick-ass mission." -- DCMTA

Employment opportunities for women in the theatre do not meet the percentage of women in the general population. The numbers are even lower for women trying to work in the classical theatre. Your support helps Brave Spirits continue to take on projects of this magnitude and enables a greater number of female artists to perform in and design for the works of Shakespeare.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Like us on Facebook.
  • Follow us on Twitter.
  • Join our mailing list.
  • Share this campaign and our information with others.

Thank you so much for your time and support.

story:
About Adoration

Two former violin students reconnect after the suicide of their mentor. Loosely based on The Seagull by Anton Chekhov, Adoration pieces together the non-linear tales and imperfect lives of two generations of musicians: their compromises, their quiet victories, and their take on what it means to be an artist.

We at Tantalus are independent theatre artists devoted to building community through our works, while creating theatre that challenges convention and that stems from the question of what our responsibilities are as human beings. 
Through this campaign, we aim to build the funds required to make our remount of Adoration as successful as possible, in hopes of providing work that makes our audiences think critically on subjects such as the importance of the teacher-student relationship, while looking at the silent sacrifices that artists make time and time again. 

For a project like this, the support of the community is paramount. Help us tell the story that so many artists can relate to. 

What Your Generosity Gets You. 

For this remount, we are asking the community for 700$. With this money, we can ensure that Adoration runs smoothly.

This 700$ will go towards audio recording sessions, printing costs, promotional material, and any repairs that may be necessary with our set or props. 

Your contributions to our production will not go unrewarded. When it comes to independent theatre, every dollar goes a long way, and we want you to be rewarded for your help. Our perks for this campaign range from social media shoutouts, to personalized videos from our cast and crew, to digital copies of the beautiful music from the show, composed and performed by our very own playwright, Violette Kay. There is even a perk for those of excessive generosity where we dedicate a show to you, or someone of your choosing. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone has the money to donate to a campaign like this, but there are so many ways you can help that don't include spending a dime. Just taking the time to spread the word about our show, our company, or even this Indiegogo campaign will go such a long way in ensuring we can make this show a success.

No matter how you decide to contribute, the cast and crew of Adoration want to say a big THANK YOU for all your help.

story:
An all-female cast, crew and co-production team present this play by April De Angelis, uncovering how women struggle to be and not to be represented on the stage, as well as how they work, endure and thrive behind the scenes. 

2016 has been called “the year of women in theatre” – with movements to advance equity in theatre production, casting, staffing, pay and opportunity. Yet for today’s female artists, making a living can be a constant hustle between freelancing, teaching, day-jobbing, seeking child-care or relying on others for financial stability in the creative pursuit of “this thing one gives one’s life blood for.”

Your fiscal sponsorship of Playhouse Creatures will help ensure the longevity of our female artists as well as contribute to the operating needs of our production.

Join CoHo Productions, along with Brenan Dwyer and McKenna Twedt, in creating this uniquely feminine theatrical experience that celebrates the everlasting tenacity of women artists.

We Need You!

Your contribution to Playhouse Creatures will ensure support for:

  • Artists compensation and Actors Equity salary
  • Design budgets for Scenic, Lighting, Costumes and Properties
  • Rehearsal space
  • Marketing

Additionally, we are focused on small, reasonable donations of $10, $20 or $50 to fund our production.  For every new donor to Playhouse Creatures CoHo Productions will MATCH your contribution!

The Impact

Playhouse Creatures  exposes what it costs to be an actress.  

In 1669, these pioneering women - our characters - give everything to tread the boards, enduring poverty, prostitution, pregnancy and abortion, violence, dismissal, loneliness and social ostracism under constant pressure to produce new and titillating entertainment.  Their successes in the form of leading roles, trysts with the King and eventually shares in the company could - and do - disappear at any time.  The central theme of the show lies in this tenuous balance.

As Mrs. Betterton muses, "sometimes I wonder what would happen to a person if it was taken away. That thing one gives one's life blood for." In Playhouse Creatures, we experience the success... And the taking away.

Raise Your Voice In Support

You can support our production without contributing financially.  We need YOU to:

  • Spread the word on your social media with the Indiegogo share tools!  Like, Share and add CoHo Productions to your social circle
  • Volunteer!  Click to CoHoProductions.org to lend a helping hand
  • Contact your local newspaper, TV station, radio station, community center or local news agencies to share our story of putting female artists in Portland, Oregon to work!

Learn More About Brenan and McKenna

Brenan Dwyer: "I am an actor, writer, director and producer of stage and screen projects. A Portland native, I’ve worked in numerous houses around town; I was an acting company member at Northwest Classical Theatre Company, and have worked at Oregon Children’s Theatre, Artist Repertory Theatre, Imago Theatre, Lakewood Theatre, Action/Adventure Theatre, Willamette Shakespeare, and at CoHo in Enjoy. 

With particular passion for work by and for women, I am a doer who can bring a production from conception to completion. As the creator of my web series Potty Talk, I delivered three seasons of web-based sketch comedy from a grassroots foundation. I completed three crowd funding campaigns, received grant funding from the Regional Arts and Culture Council, organized events, planned premieres, and managed schedules and budgets. I also wrote, directed, and produced a show for Action/Adventure Theatre’s Pilot Season that over-sold every night, and was voted by the audience to return in 2016 for a full run. These projects exemplify that I work tirelessly to achieve success on ventures close to my heart. 

Producing is especially interesting to me as I strive to curate a career full of meaningful projects. Playhouse Creatures is particularly exciting to me as an allegory for my experiences as a young woman in Portland theater. I am excited to be in this play because Mrs. Marshall is an assertive firecracker, like me. I am overjoyed to produce it so that we may hold a mirror up to the culture in Portland."

McKenna Twedt: "I am an actor and costume designer working in Portland and the surrounding areas. A graduate of Western Oregon University with my Bachelor of Fine Arts in Acting and Costume Design I take pleasure in my working and academic passion. Having worked with several local companies such as Theatre Vertigo, PHAME Academy, defunkt, Post5 Theatre, Third Rail Repertory, Tears of Joy, Lakewood Theatre, Willamette Shakespeare Company, CoHo Productions and Northwest Classical Theatre Company I consider myself a person of experience in the community and strive to further add my voice to the local conversation. 

As a former Third Rail Mentee, I am well acquainted with the particulars of producing a play from inception to completion. As part of the Mentee team I delivered costumes conception and co-execution, co-hosted a fundraising soiree, co-designed and acquired props, conceptualized marketing media photographs, designed marketing flyers and designed the poster, as well as consulted in all areas of the production. As a former educator with Tears of Joy Theatre and Tigard High School Theatre Department, I am experienced in interpreting plays and leading immersive discussion exercises that expand students understanding and appreciation of the material. 

I feel that, as an artist, it is my responsibility to support and produce works that speak the transformative language of artistic integrity and ignite the emotional imagination of the viewer. Playhouse Creatures is such a work. The play is a seductive, visceral and charming account of loud, feminine voices I often see suppressed or quieted in historical fiction and popular entertainment. Playhouse Creatures also illuminates the particular practice of being an actress. As an actress myself, I feel the play provides an insight into my world and parallels the experiences of actresses past and present. I am excited and invigorated to produce a play that so honestly captures a true and indiscriminate female experience."

CoHo Season 21

March 17 – April 8, 2017

CoHo Productions with Brenan Dwyer and McKenna Twedt present

Playhouse Creatures

by April De Angelis

Directed by Alana Byington

Featuring: Lorraine Bahr, Brenan Dwyer, Jackyln Maddux, Dainichia Noreault, McKenna Twedt

CoHoProductions.org/PlayhouseCreatures
story_txt:
An all-female cast, crew and co-production team present this play by April De Angelis, uncovering how women struggle to be and not to be represented on the stage, as well as how they work, endure and thrive behind the scenes. 
2016 has been called “the year of women in theatre” – with movements to advance equity in theatre production, casting, staffing, pay and opportunity. Yet for today’s female artists, making a living can be a constant hustle between freelancing, teaching, day-jobbing, seeking child-care or relying on others for financial stability in the creative pursuit of “this thing one gives one’s life blood for.”
Your fiscal sponsorship of Playhouse Creatures will help ensure the longevity of our female artists as well as contribute to the operating needs of our production.
Join CoHo Productions, along with Brenan Dwyer and McKenna Twedt, in creating this uniquely feminine theatrical experience that celebrates the everlasting tenacity of women artists.

We Need You!
Your contribution to Playhouse Creatures will ensure support for:

Artists compensation and Actors Equity salary
Design budgets for Scenic, Lighting, Costumes and Properties
Rehearsal space
Marketing

Additionally, we are focused on small, reasonable donations of $10, $20 or $50 to fund our production.  For every new donor to Playhouse Creatures CoHo Productions will MATCH your contribution!

The Impact
Playhouse Creatures  exposes what it costs to be an actress.  
In 1669, these pioneering women - our characters - give everything to tread the boards, enduring poverty, prostitution, pregnancy and abortion, violence, dismissal, loneliness and social ostracism under constant pressure to produce new and titillating entertainment.  Their successes in the form of leading roles, trysts with the King and eventually shares in the company could - and do - disappear at any time.  The central theme of the show lies in this tenuous balance.
As Mrs. Betterton muses, "sometimes I wonder what would happen to a person if it was taken away. That thing one gives one's life blood for." In Playhouse Creatures, we experience the success... And the taking away.

Raise Your Voice In Support
You can support our production without contributing financially.  We need YOU to:

Spread the word on your social media with the Indiegogo share tools!  Like, Share and add CoHo Productions to your social circle
Volunteer!  Click to CoHoProductions.org to lend a helping hand
Contact your local newspaper, TV station, radio station, community center or local news agencies to share our story of putting female artists in Portland, Oregon to work!

I also wrote, directed, and produced a show for Action/Adventure Theatre’s Pilot Season that over-sold every night, and was voted by the audience to return in 2016 for a full run. These projects exemplify that I work tirelessly to achieve success on ventures close to my heart. 
Producing is especially interesting to me as I strive to curate a career full of meaningful projects. Playhouse Creatures is particularly exciting to me as an allegory for my experiences as a young woman in Portland theater. I am excited to be in this play because Mrs. Marshall is an assertive firecracker, like me. I am overjoyed to produce it so that we may hold a mirror up to the culture in Portland."

story:
CCYT Cabaret opens August 4, 2017

About Curtain Call Youth Theatre

CCYT is an award-winning teen theatre group based in Agoura Hills, CA. We've dedicated over a decade to theatre arts education. CCYT strives to foster well-rounded performers well-versed in theatre etiquette, discipline, teamwork, and camaraderie in addition to the acting, singing and dancing aspects of live theatrical performance. We are challenging our students with chair choreography and for that, we need chairs!

What We Need & What You Get

View the chair on our wishlist here. Our fundraising goal is enough for 10 chairs plus tax/shipping. Our goal is to raise this money with enough time to rehearse with them.

In return, you'll get a unique peek into our rehearsal process and constant gratitude for your support! After the show, these chairs will belong to our home theatre, Playhouse 101, and we will make them available for future Playhouse 101 productions and rental to fellow members of our arts community.

If we don't reach our entire goal, we'll buy as many chairs as we can! If we do not reach enough to buy a chair, it will go into the general props/costumes/makeup production budget for the show.

About the Show

CCYT’s production of the Tony Award-winning musical, based on Christopher Isherwood’s Berlin Stories with music by John Kander, lyrics by Fred Ebb and book by Joe Masteroff, is directed by Jeff Wallach. The show takes audiences to 1929 Berlin, Germany, and tells a fun, rigorous story about human nature during political turmoil.

The show itself features the weaving narratives of a cabaret singer, a writer from America, and the inhabitants of Berlin, led by the enigmatic and dazzling Kit Kat Klub Emcee. CCYT’s production brings immersive theatre to the Agoura Hills arts community by transforming Playhouse 101’s black box theatre into the seedy nightclub where the musical is set. The show will be presented in-the-round and feature tables where audience members get a one-of-a-kind experience of memorable songs such as “Cabaret,” “Don’t Tell Mama” and “Maybe This Time” as part of the nightclub’s crowd.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute at this time, we ask that you share this campaign with your social networks and invite you to see the show in August!

If you are an artist, we are holding a graphic design contest for our promotional materials! Visit Curtain Call Youth Theatre on Facebook for complete details.

story:
A press conference is held. A dinosaur from the past and a robot from the future explain about their involvement with supposedly saving a stupid little girl from a speeding train.

 

 

After a debut at a theatre festival in 2013, playwright and director Brad McEntire is getting a chance to bring his aburdist play DINOSAUR AND ROBOT STOP A TRAIN back to area audiences. This time, as a co-production between Sundown Collaborative Theatre and his own Audacity Theatre Lab.

Though both companies run on shoe-string budgets and the play is not super-duper expensive to produce, this campaign is an effort to both raise awareness and to bring in some funds to subsidize two aspects of the production specifically...

1. Helping pay for the performance venue rentals

2. Helping pay the artists involved (cast and crew)

 

Every little bit helps. We hope you can be a part of this great indie production. At the very least, come out and see the show.


Performance times/dates are:

October 30-November 1 and November 6-8 @ 8pm

Point Bank Black Box Theatre

318 E Hickory St., Denton, TX 76201

 

November 12-15 and 19-22 @ 8pm

Margo Jones Theatre in Fair Park

1st Avenue, Dallas, TX 75210



To reserve tickets, email: boxoffice@sundowntheatre.org

More info at: AudacityTheatreLab.com

story:
Sea Level Rise: A Dystopian Comedy

Welcome to South Florida of the future!
     Have a drink and pull up a beach chair.
          Oh, and never mind that silly little
               two feet of sea level rise …
                    you're in Paradise, after all!

Sea Level Rise: A Dystopian Comedy is an official selection for the 2019 Broadway Bound Theatre Festival and will have 3 performances with summer in NYC.

Broadway Bound is an independent, boutique theatre showcase that annually presents a collection of stimulating original productions. Their long-term vision is to impact Off-Broadway theatre in a substantial way by offering fully curated, finished plays that are truly ready for a larger stage.    https://www.broadwayboundfestival.com/

3 Performances on 42nd Street in New York City!
     In the beautiful Theatre Row complex's Lion Theatre.
     Come see the show on:

  • Wednesday, July 31 at 8pm
  • Friday, August 2 at 5pm
  • Saturday, August 3 at 2pm

About the Play

The festival's critique of the play said: “A crisply written, fun, campy look at a serious issue, that makes its point. The playwright knows how to write dialogue and land a joke...”.

How can a play about climate change be funny?

First you set it in South Florida where the citizens are so deep in denial they'll boil like the proverbal frog before giving up their Maseratis. Mix in something gross like a septic tank pushed out of the ground, an alcoholic climate researcher, absentee Russian condo owners and a homeless wandering gun nut. How can it be anything but funny?

Sea Level Rise is intended to spearhead theater’s entry into the climate change conversation.

About the Playwright

This is Henry Feldman’s second climate change play. His first, "Global Warming: A Comedy," was recently workshopped at the Key City Public Theatre’s 2019 Playfest in Port Townsend, Washington.

As Mr. Feldman grew interested in climate change science and activism, he recognized that “scientists are sucky at communicating.” He believes strongly that the arts, and particularly theatrical comedy, should be instrumental in educating the public and inspiring action. He says, “Funny is what I write, and funny is what I decided it would take to get an audience to pay money to see a climate change play.”

About the Director

Ted Thompson returns as a director for his second season with the Broadway Bound Theatre Festival having directed last season's thriller Nowhere Man by Rob Dames. He has been directing for nearly two decades now a wide range of plays from comedy (The Sunshine Boys) to drama (Death of a Saleman) at venues ranging from the Brooklyn Heights Players to Theater for a New City. He has directed two plays by Lynn Nottage of which she said his direction was "sensitive and nuanced" (N.Y. Times Aug 24, 2018) He is especially pleased at the Broadway Bound Festival to be able to work with playwrights on new and contemporary works.

The Give and Get

Your contributions will go toward the expends of hiring actors, a director, stage manager, and sound designer. There will be props and set pieces including a broken septic tank! There’s the rent for rehearsal space, a fabulous poster, PR, and so on. And even when everyone is getting paid what is a criminally low hourly rate, it adds up.

We have some great merch for you! T-shirts, mugs, and posters – take your pick. (Burdened by too many worldly possessions already? You can contribute without selecting a perk.)

The Broadway Bound Theatre Festival is the first step toward getting "Sea Level Rise: A Dystopian Comedy" in front of audiences! Your support can help it succeed at the festival and go on to a standalone run.

Helping beyond money

Money is good, but the end result is getting people to see the show. So please:

  • Tell people about the show. Point them to the website: https://www.sealevelriseplay.com/
  • Share this donation campaign.
  • If you belong to any groups, please ask them to put a mention of it on their website and/or newsletter. (That includes Facebook.)
  • Together, we can make a difference.

Thanks for reading!

story:
Short Summary

We're seeking backers to support our first full production as a theatre company at VAULT Festival 2019. View From Here Theatre amplifies voices underrepresented in UK theatre and shares untold stories from across the country in response to current issues. We're proud to be partnering with Alice Malseed to bring her brilliant play Jade City from a boxing club in Belfast to one of the biggest arts festivals in London. 

Jade City gives us a snapshot of Sas and Monty, unemployed and in need of an escape. Through an imaginative game they've played since childhood, they search for the words to talk about a violent act from their past.

The play is a powerful piece of new writing, performed with inventive physical movement from David Quinn and a live electronic score from Michael Mormercha. It explores austerity and masculinity, where disenfranchised young men search for identity; by speaking to the economic realities, it will illuminate Northern Ireland for a London audience, many of whom will be wrestling with an understanding of the social and political situation in the context of Brexit. 

Your contribution will help us to bring this production to London and assist us in making theatre more accessible for first-time theatre goers through workshops and discussions. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise £3,000 to make Jade City happen. We are funding a new set and lighting design to prepare the show for VAULT Festival and further UK and Ireland touring. You are also investing in the future of Jade City and without your help we simply won't be able to make the project happen. With a great set and lighting design, we can tour the show and workshops to different spaces, especially to those who have never been to the theatre before.

From a social media shoutout, to a pin badge, to a VIP drinks reception with the cast, writer and director, there's a perk for every budget. We'd love if you can help us in whatever way you can to make this production the best it can be and secure its future. Funding for the arts in Northern Ireland (and across the UK) has become incredibly low and we can no longer rely on these sources to continue to support us.
If you are receiving a social media shoutout, please email your "@" to viewfromherefest [at] gmail [dot] com

The Impact

We think it's important to tell stories about where you're from, and we need to hear different voices. We think it's important to share those stories across the regions of the UK and exchange ideas. 

We want this play to be seen by an audience in London. But we also want that to happen for more than one week. We will invite independent producers, programmers and venues in the hope of forging new creative connections for this play and the company across the UK. Our aim is to take this play from Belfast to London and then onwards around the UK. 

Risks & Challenges

We have made funding applications to Arts Council England, Culture Ireland and other smaller trusts to support the second iteration of this production. It was fantastic that the initial development of Jade City was funded by a Jerwood Performing Arts Microbursary, and the original Belfast production was supported by the Irish government's Department of Foreign Affairs. We want to keep building on these successes. However, the nature of this kind of event and programming in London, and a serious lack of funding in Northern Ireland,  means we haven't had a huge amount of time to turn that around.

We'd love to guarantee the artists involved a few things:

  • Being able to cover the cost of transport and accommodation in London
  • A theatre show worthy of the audience and industry we invite to see it. 

We also want to give our audiences: 

  • an experience that they won't forget 
  • workshops that engage first-time theatre-goers. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Use the hashtags #jadecity #viewfromhere to help spread the word, follow us on Twitter (@viewfromhere__) and Instagram (@view.from.here__)
  • Share our campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat etc. email your address book and help us get the message out there! 

Thank you for your help, we can't do this without you!

We have made funding applications to Arts Council England, Culture Ireland and other smaller trusts to support the second iteration of this production. It was fantastic that the initial development of Jade City was funded by a Jerwood Performing Arts Microbursary, and the original Belfast production was supported by the Irish government's Department of Foreign Affairs. We want to keep building on these successes. However, the nature of this kind of event and programming in London, and a serious lack of funding in Northern Ireland,  means we haven't had a huge amount of time to turn that around.
We'd love to guarantee the artists involved a few things:

Being able to cover the cost of transport and accommodation in London
A theatre show worthy of the audience and industry we invite to see it. 

We also want to give our audiences: 

an experience that they won't forget 
workshops that engage first-time theatre-goers. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you're not able to contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

Use the hashtags #jadecity #viewfromhere to help spread the word, follow us on Twitter (@viewfromhere__) and Instagram (@view.from.here__)
Share our campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat etc. email your address book and help us get the message out there! 

Thank you for your help, we can't do this without you!

story:
My name is Dylan Crossman.

I was born and raised in France, studied dance at The Laban Center in London and moved to New York 11 years ago. I had the honor of working with Merce Cunningham as an understudy for the last 2 years of his life and then joined the Merce Cunningham Dance Company for its farewell tour. Since then, I have been teaching Merce’s technique, making my own work and freelancing as a dancer. Deeply influenced by Merce Cunningham's work and his curiosity for movement and its inherent drama, I created Dylan Crossman Dans(c)e in 2013 and started making work to express my own artistic voice. 

I am fascinated with human behavior and the different ways people interact depending on their culture. Specifically when it comes to intimacy and how it is portrayed generally on stage and more specifically in dance.  

Here We Are, my first evening-length work, is inspired by Milan Kundera's Unbearable Lightness of being ; by the different ways we express intimacy and by human behavior and its representation in formalism. I read Milan Kundera's novel in college and I applauded the honesty and the lack of judgement with which he depicted his characters. It echoes what I am trying to convey as an artist. How do I create a work featuring honest performances, story-telling, virtuosic dancing and an openness on stage, as if you were just listening to a friend tell you her/his story? 

I have received an emerging artist grant from the Jerome Foundation which comes with a fully produced show at Abrons Arts Center, 400 hours of free rehearsal space and a $5000 stipend. That is and has been invaluable. However, in order to pay all my wonderful collaborators, I need your help. My crew, for this show, is composed of 5 wonderful dancers, an extremely talented lighting designer, a visionary electronic composer and an incredible scenographer/ dramaturg. They have all given me time, commitment and trust and it is extremely important to me to pay them what they deserve. Today, when the arts are under attack, I cannot compromise on that.

The piece will be performed in the Playhouse at Abrons Arts Center, June 28-30th. Jesse Stiles will dressing the space with his electronic score, live, while my dancers- Jason Collins, Una Ludviksen, Sherah Shipman and Brandon Washington- and I take you on a journey, tell you about love, betrayal and doubt in the space carefully designed by Hubert Lafore.

If you cannot make a donation, please spread the word about our fundraiser and we would love to see you at the show!

story:
Help me fine tune my acting skills!

Hi, my name is Nicholas, and I’m an aspiring actor in Washington, DC who’s been granted an amazing opportunity to further my skills and career. I’ve gained admittance to the Theatre Lab’s Honors Conservatory, and I need your money. lol. The full tuition is nearly $6,000, which is a lot of money—especially for someone living in DC. After rent and my student loan payment, I’m short $6,000! So, how about it? Will you help me make this dream—my lifelong dream, no less!—a reality?

My rationale for completing this conservatory—or at least, the one I gave them! :) 

Recently, I became a part of a theatrical performance that changed me forever. I had the honor of playing Dickon in the Theatre Lab’s version of The Secret Garden. And I must say it wasn’t easy. For some unknown reason, I wasn't able to give 100% of myself to the role. In my mind, I felt I didn’t harness my talent, drive and confidence to fully create a performance that was inspirational—a performance that was truly successful. After each performance, I walked away thinking there was so much more I could do whether it be hold a note longer, stretch my arms further or speak a phrase slower. 

It had been a long time since I’d been on stage. As a child, I was singing and dancing all over Nashville, Tennessee. I was good—really good. At one point, a theater director invited a few New York talent scouts to my performance of a Country Christmas, where I played Tex, an ornery oil tycoon that discovered the true meaning of Christmas. The scouts loved it. They even offered me a chance to come to New York and audition for plays there. My mother, on the other hand, wasn’t too happy about an eighth grader moving to New York, especially coming from a small country town south of Nashville. And I wasn’t happy about my mother’s decision. I was livid. I wasn’t able to pursue a dream of mine—performing on the broadway stage and winning a Tony. From that point on, I stopped acting entirely. (See, I’ve been dramatic all my life.) 

I reemerged on the theatrical scene with a nudge from a friend in DC. My friend Mary suggested we start doing improv together. She’d researched the idea and determined that the Washington Improv theater’s improvisation classes were a good place to start. The classes taught me how to perfect my physical performance, think quickly on my feet, and listen to others. Most importantly, my year of improvisation classes brought back the familiar sensation of being on stage—a feeling I wanted more of. 

I chose the theater lab for more training. The first class I took was Singing Sondheim. I was extremely nervous. First, I couldn’t read music. Second, I didn’t know anything about Stephen Sondheim. As a matter of fact, I didn’t even know he was still alive. However, my nerves calmed, and I learned a great deal about theatrical lyric interpretation and phrasing. In my opinion, I thrived against a steep learning curve. The class taught me a great deal and became the connection I needed to secure my first role in DC, as Dickon. 

Few conservatory programs in the DMV have reputations as eminent and connections as widespread as the Theatre Lab’s Honors Conservatory. I feel strongly that the Theatre Lab’s Honors Conservatory will offer me the education I need to harness my talent, drive and confidence to create truly inspirational performances—performances where I walk away feeling I left everything on stage.

Now, what’s the Theatre Lab’s Honors Conservatory? (in their own words...)

The Honors Acting Conservatory at The Theatre Lab is a one-year intensive program for adults 18 and over who are serious about entering the acting profession but can’t abandon their other work commitments to enroll in long-term acting training.

Only ten students are accepted into the program each year. Students pursue a comprehensive Honors Acting Conservatory Curriculum with Washington’s best acting teachers, under the supervision of Theatre Lab Directors Deb Gottesman and Buzz Mauro and popular instructor Kim Schraf.

All Honors students meet as a group every Monday night for a full year of scene study and improvisation, exploring a wide variety of theatrical styles important for professional work.

Students take additional Theatre Lab classes throughout the year to build specific skills outside the focus of the core Monday night work. All classes and rehearsals take place on weekday evenings and during the day on weekends. Students are continually advised and evaluated on their progress, and the program culminates in public performances of two-person plays and a showcase for an invited audience of top area artistic and casting directors

story:
Good People!

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting Spaghetti Ramadan.

Beloved Great Small Works Friends and Supporters, we are trying something new with this campaign and ask for your help in spreading the word beyond those who know our work.

The “Spaghetti” in the name comes from Great Small Works’ 25-year tradition of hosting eclectic cabaret evenings where vegetarian pasta is served.  An Iftar is the meal that Muslims eat after sunset during the holy month of Ramadan to break the day's fast. It is one of the ceremonial observances of Ramadan and is often done as a community, with people gathering to break their fast together.

Now in its 4th iteration, Spaghetti Ramadan, a collaboration between Fihi Ma Fihi (Arian Nakhaie/collective) and Great Small Works (Jenny Romaine/collective), is growing. This year it will again take place online, on Saturday, May 8th, at sunset.

Jenny and Arian’s friendship started through political organizing and art making in New York City in 2015.  Each Iftar they have teamed up for since then has offered poetry, music, puppet performance, food and communal enjoyment.  Friends from Jewish and Christian worlds have shared songs and words and, since it is a Ramadan celebration, special time and space have been given to artistry from the Muslim world. This year's theme is "Jewels in the Crown."  The crew will fashion the crown from a spectrum of shining threads from Abrahamic wisdom traditions. We'll adorn the crown with light from the audience (you) in alchemical combination with sparks of ancestral wisdom from artists from the Arab world, greater Iran, South Asia, and West Africa.  We'll continue through the legacy of the African diaspora in the Americas, including Afro-American/Caribbean-diasporic cultures who have given life to many splendorous gems, including Hip Hop. 

Spaghetti, Silkroad, and Stratagems!  

We think of this venture as a horizontal collaboration.  Arian, now, based between Dubai and New York, has synthesized his community organizing background, pedagogical practice, and performance artistry [he raps in five languages: Arabic, English, German, Persian, and Spanish] to establish a management consultancy, Fihi Ma Fihi, named after the Persian mystic Rumi’s philosophical treatise “Signs of the Unseen.”The essence of his approach is that answers come from within the person bringing the issue; by blending best business practices, spiritual values and cooperative principles, communal and economic empowerment can be achieved.   

Great Small Works members, as survivors of rent gouging and endemic underfunding of the arts in the United States, want to learn (with Arian's mentorship) new skills for engaging with markets, promotion and sponsorship in the digital realm. While Great Small Works learns from Arian, the company is also mentoring him. With its decades of experience in production and design, Great Small Works supports Fihi Ma Fihi's ambitious creative ideas. 

Together they are investing in the artistic and economic capacity of both groups. Your contributions will go to artists and to secure the future of this collaboration. 

For those who like a list, here are five reasons to donate to Spaghetti Ramadan:

Spiritual Kinship

“Each one of us has our own language, our own way, our own means and medium of connecting to the divine. When Jenny came to me and said let’s do this project, we want to learn more about Islam, I told her this is how I understand this faith -- It’s about people connecting to a higher power of their own understanding in a way that is meaningful to them. That can look a million different ways. There is a saying that all rivers lead to the same ocean. That is the essence of the spiritual kinship.”

                                                                 -- Arian Nakhaie

            Culture is Essential

“Artists and culture bearers are essential to renewing our connections to ourselves and each other.  We see a link between new stories and new economic formations that literally put food on the table. Our fundraising centers artists in the visionary work of joint survival and communal well being.” 

                                                     -- Jenny Romaine

Deep Authentic Community-Building 

“Spaghetti Ramadan is intergenerational, multi-ethnic, multi religious, multi-lingual, local to NYC where it started, but also diasporic!”   

                                                      -- Arian Nakhaie

A Path to Social Change

“In these troubled and fractious times, Spaghetti Ramadan confirms my belief that creative collaborations between people of widely differing backgrounds are a path to true social change. Besides, the music is magnificent, the rituals are enlightening, and the camaraderie is fun!”

                                                     -- Trudi Cohen

A New Economic Model

"We are interested in making money through an experimental model that fits within our ethical boundaries. We are building inter-communal economics by taking work that has been happening for decades in the nonprofit sphere (community-based arts/culture) and connecting it to the context of commercial capitalism. Life gave our ancestors lemons, and they made their traditionally flavored lemonade. That's the art and tradition we are drawing from. All of those arts and traditions came out of the suffering and genius of our people. That’s what we inherited. They made beautiful art.  We are honoring them, and continuing their legacy in the awesome cosmic brew of Spaghetti Ramadan. “

                                                   -- Arian Nakhaie

Please come up and drink lemonade from our spaghetti stand!   

With digital wishes for wellness and Muslim/Jewish/White/BIPOC kinship,

FiHi Ma FiHi and Great Small Works

story:
What this play is about

Based on the real stories of gamers, The Video Game Monologues shares first times, legendary battles, and the lives changed by pressing “Start.” Part ethnography and part fantasy, this episodic play stages the adventures of hardcore and casual gamers alike, punctuated by cameos of notorious and beloved game characters. From arcade to console, The Video Game Monologues reminds us to learn from our fatalities and cherish our 1Ups.

TL;DR Version

10 short stories about epic video game experiences, performed by actors playing multiple characters. 

Why theater about video games matters

We are producing this because memories made around video games are as significant for our identities as music, books, or any other experiential medium. As misplaced proof of their influence, video games often become cultural scapegoats, but performing these stories amplifies the power of games and how they can change our lives. Please consider contributing to this campaign if you:

  • believe that art and technology make great bedfellows
  • value video games as important cultural barometers
  • support theater as an accessible expression of cultural experience 
  • value events that bridge demographic divides
  • enjoy pop culture, live storytelling, or fun spectacle

The One Behind the Curtain

Lian Amaris (writer, director, producer) has been staging original genre-bending performance for ten years. She's taught theater, new media, game culture, and creative writing at the college level; she's researched and published on video games; and she's even earned some great press from Backstage, The New York Times, and even Forbes. Vector Art Ensemble is her company of rakish comedians, repertory-trained actors, verbose dancers, and other rogue entertainers dedicated to "exploring performance trajectories."  

How we will use funding

$5000 goes to producing 2 runs in 2 cities:

  • Venue rental for four September performances in the historic SF Union Square Theatre District, with an option to extend to an additional weekend
  • Technical rehearsal venue rental
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Gels for lights
  • A person to run lights
  • A person to design lights
  • A projector
  • 3 plane tickets from SF to the NYC show
  • NYC housing for 4 nights
  • Printing programs, postcards, and posters
  • Hiring a publicist to get us some reviews
  • Buying props and costumes
  • Paying our actors for months of rehearsal and performance (we know, it's a rare thing)

If we don't make the target, we'll pay that 9% to Indiegogo and the rest will go to the venue rental, technical rehearsal venue rental, and lighting needs first. 

The Schedule

We are currently in the development stage, soon to move on to the rehearsal stage. The San Francisco performance is scheduled for Friday and Saturday, September 20-21 and 27-28 at The Phoenix Theatre, 414 Mason Street. The New York City performance is scheduled for Weds-Sat, October 2-5 at Nuyorican Poets Cafe, 236 East 3rd Street.

The Future

If we earn more than our target, that money will extend the run in SF and we'll take this play to NYC, Boston, or anywhere else that will have us! Following our production, we'll publish the play for folks all over to produce themselves! All of the money earned will go toward building out the project, doing more research, and telling more video game stories to more people. 

No coins, rings, or gems? There are lots of other ways you can help!

  • Share this with someone who might be into it
  • Write about this on your blog to help us create buzz and sell tickets
  • Design our costumes, donate props, do our lights or sound for us
  • Print out our programs from your office copier (don't get in trouble!)
  • Make us some stickers or buttons with your sweet sticker or button maker

Thank you for supporting independent theater! 

 

Please note: "Executive Producer" title is in name only and guarantees only the perks listed. It does not imply nor confer any partial or full intellectual property ownership, percentage of future earnings, nor any influence on work including but not limited to content, form, or message. Producer will not be held responsible for any publicity nor effects of publicity as a result of contributing to this project. Contributions are entirely volunteer and release Producer from any and all liability.

The New York City performance is scheduled for Weds-Sat, October 2-5 at Nuyorican Poets Cafe, 236 East 3rd Street.
The Future
If we earn more than our target, that money will extend the run in SF and we'll take this play to NYC, Boston, or anywhere else that will have us! Following our production, we'll publish the play for folks all over to produce themselves! All of the money earned will go toward building out the project, doing more research, and telling more video game stories to more people. 


No coins, rings, or gems? There are lots of other ways you can help!

Share this with someone who might be into it
Write about this on your blog to help us create buzz and sell tickets
Design our costumes, donate props, do our lights or sound for us
Print out our programs from your office copier (don't get in trouble!)
Make us some stickers or buttons with your sweet sticker or button maker

Thank you for supporting independent theater!

It does not imply nor confer any partial or full intellectual property ownership, percentage of future earnings, nor any influence on work including but not limited to content, form, or message. We are: A collective of International Artists developing a visually provocative theatre work that merges linguistic and cultural borders.  Drawing on our personal, cultural and linguistic histories we will together discover the universal tale surrounding the themes of love, desire and beauty based on the new play, Bird Song, by Ren Flannery.  This is the debut of Bird Song and through a two and half month creative exchange taking place in Taipei we will draw on our diverse artistic practices to create a work that communicates to a global audience and transcends cultural, linguistic and social divide.  Without your help Bird Song may never see the light of day and the boundaries of theatrical story telling may never be explored!!  Help us fly....

Qui sommes-nous ?
Nous sommes un collectif d’artistes internationaux qui travaillons au développement
d’un théâtre visuellement provocateur combinant différents horizons linguistiques et
culturels. Puisant dans les récits de nos cultures respectives, nous nous lançons à la
découverte d’un conte universel bâti autour des thèmes de l’amour, du désir et de la
beauté, basé sur la nouvelle pièce de Ren Flannery, Bird Song. Nous nous sommes
posé à Taipei (Taiwan) où, pendant deux mois et demi de gestation et d’échanges
artistiques, nous allons élaborer une œuvre qui a pour vocation de dépasser les
clivages culturels, linguistiques et sociaux, et de s’adresser au monde entier.


What we need: We desperately need a Taiwanese local with profecient English skills to act as a full time production manager/translator/administrator.  They will be the much-needed oil in the machine, bridging all language and cultural confusion that comes with working on foreign soil.  As this is a rare independant project working across different cultures we face many complexities most theatre shows wouldn't and we depseratley need a savvy local to help us achieve vital communications with the Taiwanese Government, immigration, the Theatre, the ticketing system, the insurance company, the local sponsors, various marketing platforms and the Taipei community. 

As this position will be the key to our success we need to ensure the appointed person has the ability to dedicate all of their time to this project, as it is quite a demanding role.  Living expenses are high in Taipei but wages are low so that most unmarried people have to live at home with their parents their entire lives.  The money raised here will pay the wage of this person allowing them to fullfill the role accordingly.  It will also cover the flights and accommodation of our overseas artists and the translation of the script and other important documents.

The entire budget of the project is roughly $50,000USD; with $10,000USD confirmed we can adequately begin this journey.  By supporting our project you will be actively participating in the beginning of an innovative exploration into communication across racial divide through the celebration of Art and humanity.  With your contribution you will be joining our ecclectic team in creating a visually provacative, visceral and profound new theatre work that will touch audiences world wide.

å‰µæ„æ–°ç™¼æƒ³!

De quoi avons-nous besoin ?
Mon nom est Ren Flannery. Je suis une artiste indépendante et je suis arrivée à Taipei avec une
connaissance basique du chinois mandarin et une valise pleine à craquée de grandes
idées. J’ai reçu jusqu’à présent un soutien et des retours extraordinaires. Aussi, après
quatre mois de dur labeur et un nombre incalculable de discussions, le projet est en
bel et bien en marche ! Je porte aujourd’hui entre autres les différentes casquettes
d’écrivain, metteuse en scène, productrice, administratrice et chargée de promotion.
Dans un tel contexte, et alors que le financement de la production me paraît extrêment
prometteur, ce dont nous avons vraiment besoin maintenant, c’est de pouvoir
employer à plein temps une personne locale et de lui confier les missions de directeur/
directrice de production, de traducteur/traductrice-interpête et d’administrateur/
administratrice. Vu le caractère extrêmement chronophage des difficultés rencontrées
jusqu’ici dans l’avancement des questions de logistique du spectacle, il va sans dire
que cette personne jouera un rôle d’une importance capitale dans la suite du projet.
Il s’agira pour elle de me servir d’intermédiaire auprès du Gouvernement Taiwanais,
du Théâtre, du système de vente de billets en ligne, de la compagnie d’assurance, des
sponsors locaux, des différentes plateformes de marketing et de la communauté de la
ville de Taipei. Ce poste étant la clé de notre réussite, nous devons nous assurer que
la personne qui endosse cette lourde reponsabilité ait la capacité d’y consacrer tout
son temps. L’argent que nous allons récolter ici servira à payer cette personne, les
billets d’avion et le logement de nos artistes étrangers et la traduction du scénario. Le
budget total de la production étant de plus ou moins 50 000 dollars, il est raisonnable
d’estimer qu’avec 10 000 dollars fermes, nous pouvons d’ores et déjà entamer le
voyage en toute sérénité. En apportant votre soutien à notre projet, vous choisissez
de prendre vous aussi activement part au lancement d’une exploration innovante de
la communication et du dialogue interculturels, à travers la célébration de l’art et de
l’humanité !

The Plan:  Bird Song will be developed through a two and half month creative exchange with a team of International Artists in Taipei City, where it will debut at Guling Street Avant-Garde Theatre in mid-September.  Once the production is up the next step is to tour it around the Asia/Pacific first and then Europe and the USA in 2013/2014.  Bird Songhas been intentionally developed to tour with the ability to adapt to changing audience and performance environments making it accessible to a broad spectrum of audiences, festivals and programs.

æƒ³ï¼Œæ¼”å‡ºå…§å®¹å¯é€éŽèˆ‡åœ¨åœ°æ–‡åŒ–çš„æ”¹ç·¨ï¼Œå› æ‡‰ä¸åŒå·¡æ¼”å€åŸŸçš„æ–‡åŒ–èƒŒæ™¯ã€‚

C’est quoi le plan ?
Bird Song sera développée dans la ville de Taipei (Taiwan), pendant deux mois
et demi d’échanges créatifs entre les membres d’une équipe composée d’artistes
internationaux et créée au Théâtre Avant-Garde de la rue Guling, mi-septembre 2012.
Une fois la production sur pied, nous entamerons une tournée en Asie-Pacifique dans
un premier temps, puis en Europe et aux Etats-Unis pour la saison 2013-2014. Bird
Song a été spécialement conçue pour pouvoir faire le tour du monde, et s’adapte
facilement à des publics et à des conditions de représentation variées, ce qui la rend
accessible à un large éventail de publics, de festivals et de programmations.

Bird Song is: a fantastical tale that traverses time and explores the universal themes of love, desire and beauty found within the intimate moments of self. Seeking the common voice of the feminine sensuality, Bird Song uses shadow and light, dream and song to narrate the quiet journey of two women and a mythological bird each entrapped in a world that dictates their fate.  Bird Song uses visual and performance mechanisms to explore the core essentials of humanity and the intimate moments that bind us as a singular race.

Situated in a private bathhouse Bird Song follows the journeys of two women from different worlds.  The lives of a Japanese aristocrats daughter from the late Qing dynasty and a well educated maid from the cultural revolution begin to intertwine through their relationship with a beautiful mythological Bird based on Chinese mythological pre-human woman who discovered theatre. Their discovery of love, desire and beauty comes from the most intimate moments with self as they go about their daily rituals.  The intersection of their lives no longer allows them to live within their naive pasts as they discover the most beautiful and tragic realities of their hearts.

A propos de Bird Song
Bird Song est un conte fantastique qui traverse plusieurs époques et explore les
thèmes universels de l’amour, du désir et de la beauté, tels qu’on peut les vivre dans
les moments d’intimité avec soi-même. Cherchant la voix de la sensualité féminine,
Bird Song exploite les jeux d’ombres et de lumières, le rêve et la chanson pour
raconter le paisible voyage de deux femmes et d’un oiseau mythologique, tous trois
pris au piège dans un monde qui conditionne leur destinée. Bird Song utilise le visuel
et les mécanismes du jeu d’acteur pour explorer ce noyau essentiel d’humanité, ces
moments d’intimité qui nous relient les uns aux autres en une seule et unique race.


How it began: Witnessing a break down of understanding between various cultural communities in Australia impassioned Ren Flannery to find the points where human beings connect as a singular race.  Three years ago, while riding a train on cold, grey Melbourne day she had a vision of a warmly lit bathhouse with a gilded birdcage by the window.  This image sparked the writing of her new work Bird Song, which explores the notions of love, desire and beauty from an internal source opposed to the external perspective of ‘what is?’  Bird Song was written with the intention of touring it across the globe and reaching audience beyond the typical 'theatre going' demographic.  By using a collaborative development process Bird Song will act as a platform for exploring theatrical story telling to a universal audience, connecting a linguistically and culturally diverse audience in a shared experience.

çš„å¹³å°ã€‚

Comment cela a-t-il commencé ?
Constatant l’existence de véritables fossés de communication entre les différentes
communautés culturelles australiennes, Ren Flannery s’est mise en quête des
universaux encore capables de connecter entre eux tous les êtres humains. Il y a trois
ans, perdue dans la contemplation d’un Melbourne gris et froid qu’elle traversait en
train, elle eut la vision d’une maison de bain baignée d’une lumière chaude et d’une
cage à oiseau dorée à la fenêtre. C’est cette image qui est à l’origine de l’écriture
de sa nouvelle œuvre Bird Song, qui explore de l’intérieur les notions d’amour, de
désir et de beauté plutôt que de s’interroger sur la nature de ces concepts. Bird Song
a été écrite avec le projet de montrer cette pièce au monde entier et de toucher un
public plus large que celui qui se rend généralement au théâtre. Envisagé comme
un processus de développement collaboratif, Bird Song se veut un laboratoire où
explorer l’art de la narration théâtrale, et ce, dans une perspective universelle visant
à connecter liguistiquement et culturellement différents publics réunis autour d’une
expérience commune.


Just some of the talented team that is growing daily!

Writer/Director: Ren Flannery (Australian) www.renflannery.com
Composer/sound designer: Thomas Foguenne (Belgian) www.thomasfoguenne.com
Visual Designer: Don Salubayba (Filipino) http://anino.sining.net/
Performers: Tzu-Han Chi (Taiwanese)
